Food was fine but when someone says there is a dairy allergy and specifically asks multiple times... I would hope a restaurant would take it seriously and not assume adding it in any way would be acceptable (and on top of this, not mention that it was added). 

In the beginning we enjoyed a nice meal (I had the baked oysters and he had the roasted chicken and potatoes because we were assured it could be made with no dairy). After the meal we asked how the chicken was prepared simply hoping to come away with a new cooking tip and found out it was prepared with CHEESE. At which point we got fairly upset explaining that dairy is cheese to which the server said "I knew, but the chef assured me it would be minimal since it was cooked down." We notified the manager of the issue and he jokingly asked if we wanted the cheesecake and did nothing more regarding the situation other than saying he would be sure to speak with those involved. 

I am APPALLED at how poorly the situation was handled, especially after making very clear one of us had a severe dairy allergy.

I have more issues with the Yelp reviews for this place than the actual place.
After reviewing everyone else's comments on the place, I'm not sure I went to the same place. It has a total hotel bar vibe (which, it technically, is). Kind of weirdly bright lighting and somewhat loud pop music.
A review below stated "very French and very upscale"??
I can't agree with either of those. "Upscale"? How is it? "French"? There are some french-themed paraphernalia on the wall. "Pretty dressy"? There was a family sitting near me all in shorts with kids covered in ketchup.

So. I don't get the other reviews on here.

This place is a casual restaurant that is attached to a hotel. As a sidenote, I left my hotel to eat dinner here and was kind of irked when I realized I was eating in another hotel restaurant. #FirstWorldBusinessTravelProblems

Solid raw bar with a seemingly ever changing selection of fruit of the sea. Pretty solid wine list as well - better than I expected, actually.
I also enjoyed the shrimp and crab etouffee - although I kind of thought the portion was a tad small (which is ironic because every other meal I've had in this town I thought the portions were a tad big).

So, go. It's good. You'll enjoy it.

It's a John Besh joint, so I expected a lot, and it delivered. More casual than some of his other spots, total French Bistro vibe. The service was exceptional, and the food predictably good, especially the fresh oysters. On the loud side, for those who are concerned about such things...

With the vibe of a brasserie and a kitchen cranking out southern classics, it's hard to go wrong. The service was slow, but they quickly appeased these customers by bringing out complementary bread pudding (perfectly crisp with hints of caramel- seriously delicious).

We ordered the Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "En Cocotte" and the Étouffée. The Étouffée was slightly dry and could use a more complex flavor profile. The shrimp was the clear winner as it was served on a bed of roasted jalapeño cheese grits and Andouille & green onion sausage. No further explanation required!

I wouldn't make a point of visiting this restaurant again with so many stones left unturned in NOLA, but I thoroughly enjoyed trying it once.

Don't judge this place on their lousy breakfast. Dinner is amazing! 
The pro's- they make a great French 75, bartender adds some brandies cherries and swirls the cherry juice. The ribeye with lump crab meat was worth every penny! Great flavor and served on a cutting board. Wasn't impressed with the fries but that's my fault. I should have read the menu closer and subbed in mashed taters. 
The con's- breakfast was lousy. Eggs were sent back. Toast was burnt and very hard to chew. I gave up before they brought over butter. Who wants cool hard toast? Menu said hash browns but they're new potatoes quartered and burnt. This one was free as I'm staying at the hotel. This meal was also worth every penny. Lol 
Side note. Hotel voucher doesn't include a drink or breakfast meat. $9 for a small diet coke and a side of bacon. The bacon was very good. Could've bought a pound for $9 but eh.

Poor quality Sunday breakfast/brunch service for a messily party of 3. Would have liked to try the food, but we couldn't even get served water within 20 minutes so we left. Won't be returning for sure. Went to Palace Cafe instead (which I highly recommend for Sunday brunch).

This is one of my favorite spots for Happy Hour.  We stopped by yesterday after watching the Southern Decadence parade.  The hostess was lovely and offered us a table but my partner and I choose the nearly empty bar.  In no time at all, we had two dozen raw oysters at 50 cents each with half price drinks.  The new River Bend cocktail is delicious and there's always good beers on draft.  It's a great location, and a terrific happy hour (3-6 pm daily) spot.
Enjoyed a very nice meal here and liked it so much, returned for a second dinner the next day.  Will likely come here again.  Service could be just a little but sharper, otherwise a 5 star.

Just came in for the .50 oyster happy hour, will be back for dinner tomorrow.  FYI, despite some previous tips or reviews the oysters are fresh shucked and fantastic.  I watched them go from stack of oysters in the sink to my plate. Fresh.  Staff is great.

We made reservations here during happy hour. They have 50 cent oysters and half priced drinks! We ordered 2 dozen to start and was very happy with what we got. Huge, meaty, and mild oysters! yummy. We were so excited we ordered a total of 6 dozens :) It's happy hour.... I figure why not?!?!? So, 6 dozen oyzters and two drinks later, we paid the check and walked away happily. 

It is a MUST GO place! I absolutely loved it!

I had never heard of Luke before until a couple weekends ago my fiance proposed, then surprised me again right after with a weekend trip to New Orleans to celebrate, and had made reservations at Luke's to end the weekend with a bang! 
I am so glad my fiance found this place. It was wonderful. We are both originally from the East Coast, now in the Midwest, so we have never really experienced cajun food before done right. After our dinner here, we are now huge fans! So many flavors and too many choices to leave hungry. I think between my fiance and I we ordered plenty, but every dish that came out and went to a different table we were wide eyed and asking "Whats thatttt", drool and all. 
Hopefully we will be back here soon and can try the rest of the menu. The service is also extremely friendly and they make sure to take their time with explaining the dishes and making you feel comfortable.

Came back to Lüke today expecting the pecan pancakes, but alas, they have changed the menu. I was disappointed but ordered the Croque Monsieur. The presentation of the sandwich was beautiful. It looked delicious. Maybe I didn't like the cheese or the texture, but I wasn't a fan. The French fries were good. The service was awesome, but I don't like the new brunch menu!

Luke is one of the places I try to go every weekend that I'm in New Orleans. The food has never disappointed. It looks like the brunch menu was changed a little. I didn't find the selection to be quite as good as it used to be, but my Croque Monsieur with a fried egg was delicious. The $9 mimosa is equivalent of a $3 mimosa somewhere else. I'd like to see them using freshly squeezed oranges for that price. Overall good experience.

Had the onion flatbread as an appetizer and was impressed.  Jalapeno shrimp & grits was exceptional as well as the BLT with fried soft shell crab.
After eating - luckily after eating - watched bartender open large jar of olives and pick out with bare hands to skewer as condiment for martini's.  Three olives per skewer - she must have done 100 of them with her bare hands while handling cash, credit cards and register and then back to touching the olives.

I have long been a fan of Chef John Besh so I has to stop at at least one of his places on my trip. And Lüke did not disappoint. The meal was fantastic, well worth the cost, and with it being restaurant week they had down great specials as well. Best part of the meal though had to be the bread pudding which was hands down the best I have ever had. Also it was. Also sitting near the kitchen as you could watch them at work. And finally the exclusive beers made for The restaurant are also really good. And the servers can offer great paying suggestions.

Right downstairs of the Hilton and across the Intercontinental, it's a spacious restaurant that seems good for locals and tourists alike. Went the first night for dinner and I have to say it was alright. Maybe cos I'm a native New Yorker where options are endless and there are quality restaurants everywhere. Service was a bit lacking for a Monday night where the restaurant was about half full. 

A lot of other patrons ordered the schnitzel which was humongous. Our entrees of blue crab cavatelli and shrimp n grits were very flavorful. The ragout lamb pasta however was a bit of a disappointment. It wasn't bad but wasn't great either. The presentation of it didn't help either. However, we came back the night after for solely the happy hour 50 cents oysters!!! That is unheard of in NYC so we had to try it. It was shucked more clean, but the flavor wasn't as great as the other famous seafood chain that starts with a D and rhymes with Lego. However, you can make reservations here. Three dozens came in a matter of minutes so this is worth a stop.

This place is awesome! Luke's has a very lively atmosphere and the food is superb! I ordered the fish of the day. I can't remember what type of fish it was, but it was a local gulf catch and was as fresh as it gets. It was also a very large portion, which I was not expecting.  It was prepared lightly-pan fried and served on a bed of perfectly yummy vegetables. I also order a side of creamy potatoes, which are small red potatoes. Very good!  For dessert, I had a steamed chocolate dish with salty caramel ice-cream that was to die for. I really  enjoyed my experience and would recommend to check it out.

Eh. Tasty food but careless, amateur service. I've honestly never seen a wait staff not give a shit about service as I saw at my meal at Luke. Randomly distributing plates as they came our of the kitchen with no apparent thought to having apps out before entrees.  Literally they stacked the tiny table full of appetizers and entrees all at once with no acknowledgement seemingly that fine dining establishments don't do that. Saved only by tasty food.

Ahhhhmazzing. 
We had some mishaps with our drinks not coming and soup being a little on the cold side, but they remedied the mistakes immediately and sent us desserts at the conclusion of our meal. 
Raw oysters were divine. 
I had a special of grits with pork belly. Only compliant was that it wasn't served to me in the comfort of my bed. I would loved to have curled up with that cast iron dish and dreamt sweet dreams next to it. 
This place is a must. Fairly priced, too.

Luke was a go to for years. But my past two trips have been underwhelming. Appetizers forgotten, Oysters juices dumped in our guests purse by a waiter, shouting an cursing coming from the kitchen and less the courteous staff has removed Luke from my list. I always enjoyed the raw bar, mussels and fries when I did go.

We had the coffee, grillade & grits ($15) and shrimp & grits ($24, plus I added crabmeat for $12). Matt J. was our server  for breakfast and he was outstanding! The food was simply amazing. So fresh, flavorful and richly seasoned. The best seafood in town!

The experience left such a great impression that... We returned at happy hour (3-6pm) that same afternoon. Wow! Great choice! We started with Ugni Blanc Champagne, French 75 and the St. Charles Streetcar. Their handcrafted cocktails were absolutely amazing and at half off (happy hour) they were even better! Also, their shucked oysters on the half shell were only $0.50 each. We literally ordered 48 oysters (4 dozen). We also enjoyed their flamenkuche (quite unique), which includes onion tartar, bacon and cheese on a cracker crust. 

The whole experience was outstanding because of the food, drinks and exceptional service by Richie Rich. We were pleasantly surprised that they honored happy hour prices restaurant-wide! We sat in the section with Richie Rich (Rich Whatley), who was so knowledgeable about their menu. He even recommended great combinations of food and drink to enhance our experience. Also, Richie had great recommendations for things to do in- and around the local area. Top level service, with a smile. When I return, I'll ALWAYS ask to be seated with Richie Rich. His high level of service sets the example for others to follow. Kudos to Lüke!

Steamed chocolate. Make sure you save room for dessert and make sure it's the steamed chocolate (or bread pudding) absolutely delicious. 

We ended up here because this was one of the few nicer restaurants in the area that could accommodate a large group of 12 at one table and man did they take care of us. 

Most of us started off with one of the fruits de mer (seafood platter). I had half a dozen jumbo shrimp and each one was nearly as big as my hand. Our table also got mussels and clams. The shrimp were amazing, probably the best I've ever had. Several guys started with the bisque soups and oyster salad which they all said were fantastic. Most of us followed that up with burgers. The burgers while very good, weren't necessarily anything special (which was a little disappointing) although a really special burger is hard to find. Dessert though, other than the seafood, is where Lüke really showed off as I said before, the steamed chocolate and the bread pudding were amazing. 

I will definitely go back next time I'm in the area, but I think I'll order something other than a burger. The chicken dish and the fish looked amazing-oh well, live and learn.
Oysters, oysters, oysters.  Happy hour=amazing. We got our oyster fix at this place.  The lunch specials are good. Service is good.
Awesome! Great place and excellent service. Sat at the bar during Happy Hour and had .50 oysters and half price beers. Will come back!

My husband and I dropped in around 8:30 on a Sunday night and it was full with a 15 min wait, so we sat at the bar. A reservation would be ideal. It's small, not too loud, romantic, and lovely.  I wanted something smaller so I had the cup of crab bisque and the goat cheese stuffed squash and they were both delicious. Hubs just had a burger (shameful) but said it was awesome. The drinks were great too and not weak. Staff was attentive and friendly, so I don't think you could ask for more.
Had a very enjoyable dining experience. Loved the oysters. Shrimp boudin, shrimp and grits, and etouffee were all delicious.

Came in for lunch during the week and went with the daily special. Service is slow but staff is friendly enough. The high ceilings make it a loud place. They can accommodate larger groups. Crab bisque is a little too heavy on the corn and almost no crab, the base is creamy and just a tad spicy which made it quite savoury. Shrimp with ham, vegetables and jasmine rice are only bearable because they come with an ok sauce, but the items separately (except the very fatty ham) are bland, really tasteless. Portions are small even for lunch, specially because there's no complimentary bread or anything but given the price I guess it's ok ($17).

Best food and service of all the restaurants we visited in New Orleans. If your group is small, sit at the bar-Brandy is an amazing bartender/waitress that will make your experience great. So much flavor in everything we tried!

Best drink: French 75
Best food: shrimp and grits with crab
Best dessert: bread pudding 

The atmosphere is welcoming, fun, comfortable, and the waiters were very accommodating and helpful with selections! The French 75  is awesome, they make it with cognac and an egg white, which definitely mellows out the lemon and champaign. GREAT DRINK, FOOD AND SERVICE.!

Lüüüüüüüüke, I am your father! 

Returned here for a very nice Sunday brunch with our group of six. I hesitated a bit on the five stars because our food took forever to come out, but we all had a great time and the meal was beyond amazing. 

We were still smashed from the night before and were taking it a bit easy rather than order a shit-ton of seafood and go family style, as we had been doing. Everyone had individual seafood plates off the brunch menu, and it was all top notch - but boy did we want to go for the seafood tower.

When you hear from your friends best _____ I've ever had, in this case the Crab Bisque and pâté in particular, then that's as good as it gets, right?

Peach Champagne was delightful.

If you want to escape the heat and the crowds for a great lunch then pop into Lüke. 

This place has a wonderful old worldly gentleman club feel about it. With old school belt driven fans hanging from the pressed metal ceiling panels. Great swivel top wooden bar stools and a lovely glass display case with the catch of the day sitting on ice. 

Food is good and the waiting staff are friendly and know their job. Top marks to the gentleman who looked after me. 

Price is like most good places I'm finding in the States a bit on the high side. I had a cocktail, 2x appetisers, bread pudding and a coffee $56.53 + tips so $65 for lunch for one. But hay it's not the Golden Arches... 

Enjoy.

Saturday
The food was great even the coffee. Had grits and a cup of crab bisque. Loved all the flavors. It was like a party in my mouth. The only thing I would suggest is that they add to their staff not enough help for the amount of people being served. But other then that everything was great

We spent a boatload on brunch but received an incredible meal. The squash blossoms were crunchy and creamy, savory and sweet. I was mesmerized by the creativity and complexity in the menu without feeling exhausted by it. The shrimp and grits had a truly special sauce that had a really dimensional flavor. The soft shell crab and grits could have used some more heat but were good. Delicious.

I'm a Canadian through and through, but today I felt like a real Southerner with Fried Chicken and Waffles glazed in Tabasco honey and creamy butter.  OMG it was superb.  Mint Julep to sip and I was loving it!  Wife had the Luke burger and was in heaven!  Service was impeccable and atmosphere was grand.
Great ambiance and awesome food... What more do you want!!!??? Every bite of this restaurants food is something to savor.

I have truly never had a meal as good as what I had at Luke last week. The oysters and squash blossoms were so delicious! I had a bisque and salad for my meal, both of which were perfect. Then the desserts....the bourbon sauce on the bread pudding was to die for! I would buy that and have it shipped home to michigan if I could! 

The only reason I took a star off was that our server wasn't easy to find.

Delicious shrimp and grits, and Crocque Monsieur. We thoroughly enjoyed this nice little spot adjacent to the Hilton for a Saturday afternoon lunch in the CBD. The service was great and we loved the food. Highly recommend stopping in here!

this was a good last minute brunch find for us. we miscalculated timing of when we needed to leave for the airport given saints traffic, so we bailed on our reservation and headed around the corner to Luke's. 

Server was very nice and the brunch menu had several appealing options. i enjoyed my shrimp and grits though could have used a larger portion (maybe it was just bc we had eaten nonstop during our trip and my appetite was extra big). i ordered a glass of prosecco that was just ok and my friends both said their bloody mary was just ok as well. 

overall was a good, quick brunch stop near our hotel before leaving town.

The best shrimp and grits I have ever had. Period. The wait was long but they have full service at the bar. The bartender was extremely polite and recommended I try the shrimp. Definitely coming back for more.

menu was very simple and great choices for everyone. 
appetizers were also a good selection
atmosphere is simple and quasi farmhouse feel

service, was slow..it was crowded but very slow.
I ordered a burger and it took nearly 45 minutes.
Dinner for 5 took over 2 hours, way too long.

if service was more prompt it would be a 4 star rating.
Best meal so far in New Orleans. Undiscovered treasure, the ceviche. Order it, it's not on the menu as a single item.

Lüke has been on "our list" for a while now. So happy that we finally visited. Everything was perfect. The layout of the restaurant, the friendliness of the staff, the ambiance. I wish that I could have sampled everything on the menu. The Salad Lüke was exceptional as was the Crispy Goat Cheese Stuffed Squash Blossoms. You could tell immediately that the pasta was house made. The roasted jalapeño grits were so good that I would go back just for them.  I highly recommend the "Gâteau Basque" and the Bourbon Vanilla Bean Crème Brûlée. Both, "to die for" desserts. They also have a great drink menu and they brew their own beer. Try the River Bend. You will not regret it. I can not wait to visit again. The brunch menu looks mouthwatering.

So it is Saturday night.  I arrived in NoLa Wednesday and am leaving Sunday.  I have eaten my way through most of the city and this is to be my last stop on the gluttony train.  

My wife is a big John Besh fan so this was a very exciting finale for her.  

The outside of this restaurant is nothing special.  You could walk right by and not even notice it.  As soon as you walk though the door, however, things change.  

It is lively!  Great music, warm wood finishes, cool old school tile floor and a kick ass 
raw bar!  It was piled high with mountains of ice, covered by shellfish.  You could belly right up and start your seafood adventure.  We were a party of four so sadly we opted for a table.  I do NEED to sit at that bar next time.  

We at least sat NEXT to the raw bar.  I immediately ordered a mint julep (after the ladies ordered obviously).  It was served very traditionally and it was delicious.  Everyone at the table ordered different drinks off of the cocktail menu and they were all good.  

For starts I went with the liver Pate'.  It was extraordinary.  I am not using that word lightly.  I love pate' and order it almost every time it is offered.  This one was velvet, like Coming To America velvet.  I was in love.  (Insert second mint julep.)

For dinner...oh for dinner I had Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "En Cocotte."  This was a culinary masterpiece.  The best shrimp and grits I have ever had.  Creamy, spicy, perfectly cooked grits. The shrimp were huge, again perfectly seasoned and cooked. (Insert third mint julep.)

Now you might say why the four stars?  Two things.  First:  The chairs in this place are crazy uncomfortable.  I am not kidding.  Who picked these torture chairs?  They have a raised lip around the edge of the seat that digs into the back of your legs. Check it out I swear.  Second:  When we arrived I told the waited we were going to be on a slow roll.  Please give us some time to eat and enjoy.  Five minutes after the first course came out the entrées showed up.  We obviously had to send them back which I hate doing.  Now the manager came out and apologized and they fired us new meals which was nice but that kind of stuff makes me nuts.    

Besides these two points you must go here.  The food is amazing.

I went to this restaurant with friends from New Orleans, and the company for dinner was fantastic.  I had a great time.  Unfortunately, the restaurant had nothing to do with my great dining experience. The food was just average. The service was inattentive, and the restaurant is set up in a way that every table is in a pathway with people walking right on top of you.

For my appetizer we shared the charcuterie plate, and it was good. Then I have a couple of the crab bisque which was very tasty, but didn't have any crab in it. For my entrée, I had the Viener schnitzel oh, and the pork was like breaded paper the meet was paperthin dry and tasteless the breading was nice and crispy but extremely salty. For dessert, I had the bread pudding which was touted by the waitress as the best dessert on the menu, but it was tasteless and dry.

I love this place! I had just landed in New Orleans for the first time and wanted to catch a meal before it got dark. I yelped and found this place to be conveniently a couple of blocks or so from the hotel I was staying at. Traveling alone on a budget, I wanted to catch their unbelievable happy hour, which I believe runs M-F from 3-6pm. Can't beat their $0.50 raw oysters and half-off drinks!

I arrived at the restaurant around 5pm on a Thursday and was immediately greeted by a hostess. No wait whatsoever! I decided to sit at the bar, which probably sits around 10 people. Sitting at the bar is great if you want to be immediately seated, watch sport games, or chat with the friendly shuckers.

The first thing I ordered were the raw oysters and they were amazing!! I never knew my love for raw oysters until I came to this place (I don't get to experience this kind of freshness back home in Los Angeles). I also ordered the Luke burger and French 75. The burger was huge and it also came with homemade fries. I ended up taking half my burger to go. Even as microwaved leftover, the burger still remained juicy and tender. I would rate it as #3 on my list of best burgers. The French 75 is a must-try! It's a nice blend of cognac, lemon juice, and champagne. Best cocktail drink I have ever tried!

I would definitely come back to this place next time I'm in New Orleans. Since it's located in the Business District, it beats the constantly overcrowded French Quarter restaurants if you just want a quick fix of oysters and drinks.

How does a chef ruin chicken and waffles? I went for sunday brunch and the food was horrible...soggy waffles and greasy chicken. The waiter was nice and offered me another entree but I had already lost confidence.  I would not recommend it!

While researching places to go while in NOLA, I came across Luke and their famous happy hour. Yes, the place had great ratings and reviews for their food. However, I wanted oysters. This was probably one of my favorite meals in NOLA. 

Their happy hour special is just crazy with 50 cent oysters, 1 dollar/fried oyster and half off their beers.  It was like a light was shining down on me and I hit the jackpot. Needless to say, we had 2 and half dozen oysters and 4 fried oysters. The raw oysters were tasty and huuugee. Our waiter, bless his heart, didn't even bat an eye when we ordered that many. He was attentive and very polite. The fried oysters came with a ranch dipping sauce, seemed a little odd. However, ranch taste amazing with them! Who knew! Next time I am back in NOLA, I will for sure come back here and hopefully try their other dishes!

Amazing service!  I'm so glad we checked out this restaurant.  There is no signage indicating happy hour is taking place and it is pretty ritzy looking so I thought I was at the wrong place.  I came down to New Orleans for oysters and I had already tried Le Bayou and Royal House, but nothing beats the fifty cents oysters here!  Amazing value, good oysters and people are so pleasant without being overbearing or stuffy.  Also, wine and beer is half off.  It was only two blocks from where I was staying so I tried to go every day.  I ordered the Luke salad off of the regular menu: the buttermilk dressing was wonderful, the Bibb lettuce was fresh and paired so nicely with the root vegetable(?).  I ordered dressing on the side and I don't think the server remembered, but it didn't matter because the dressing was lightly tossed in. I'll definitely come back next year when I visit new Orleans again.

Was really pumped to try this place Bc John Beche has such a good reputation but it was totally mediocre.  I'm from NYC so have access to excellent food and maybe that's why I found everything to be lacking but generally there wasn't anything j couldn't cook at home myself. Don't bother.

this place SUCKS. Terrible service and overpriced mediocre food. This is my second time with the same results. I gave them the benefit of the doubt -perhaps having an off night the first time I went, but it was the exact same the second time around. Nothing innovative. They churn tables out and could care less that you are spending upwards of $150 for two. Save this one for the tourists.
Hands-down my favorite restaurant in New Orleans. Fantastic happy hour with $.50 oysters and half-price drinks from 4-6. Amazing gumbo, tuna, and even the burger is phenom. Wow.
I thought Luke was pretty good, though I wasn't blown away.  We tried a selection of dishes that we all shared.  The pasta was great-really fresh. The grits were a bit too heavy for me.

In preparation for my recent vacation to New Orleans, I had done a lot of research on great bars, historic hotels, dinner spots, jazz clubs, etc, but realized when I arrived that I hadn't looked for many great lunch deals. So I preface this post in saying that we came here on a whim based on the location to our hotel and a quick Yelp search - and boy was Lüke a great choice!

Situated in the CBD within a hotel, it was a short walk from our spot on Tchoupitoulas St., right outside the French Quarter. The atmosphere was sort of antique and classy - even the waiters/waitresses had doctor-like white coats on with ties - which I kind of enjoyed.

Prices were a bit high, but the portions were sizable as a consolation. My boyfriend and I weren't starving so we decided to split a cup of the crab bisque ($6) which was plump full of succulent blue crab, and the Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "En Cocotte" with roasted jalapeño cheese grits, Andouille & green onion ($24). Lets just say this dish changed my perspective on grits... and holy hell, it was delicious in all of its smoky, spicy, savory glory! 

But the best part: their happy hour, which we happened to stumble in for because New Orleans is an amazing place where it runs all day beginning at noon! The lowdown: .50 cent oysters, 1/2 off all beers, cocktails & wines by the glass. Really impressive wine and spirits selection. Great beer list. Fantastic cocktails. Attentive service. This place really has it all. Stop in if you're in town and if you're a native, you best get on that pronto.

Oh this is wonderful.  Classic bistro vibe and fantastic food.  Raw bar is amazing.

Service was slightly awkward, like a trainee, but very friendly.  The neighborhood feels a little corporate office-ish.  Not the super cool NOLA vibe you want.  Those are the only markdowns.

Absolutely with a visit for the food.
I have always enjoyed the food at Luke.  They have a wonderful happy hour with cheap oysters and drinks.  They also make one heck of a burger.  My only problem has been the inconsistent service.

Luke is one of my favorite restaurants in the city and by far my favorite of all of the Besh restaurants. It's in a slightly weird location that doesn't really stand out but you will be happy you went. They are my go to place for weekend brunch and have a great happy hour special. 

Oysters are amazing however you get them and their version of shrimp and grits is absolutely 100% my favorite out of any shrimp and grits dishes I have had anywhere. I seriously order it every time I go. I don't eat meat so I can't personally vouch for it but my boyfriend loves their rabbit dishes and the liver pate.

Check this place out if you are visiting or a local. It is a must!

I came here recently with my mom to relax before a big interview, and we had a great time! 

We started with the marinated crab claws form the bar. They were good! I really liked the sauce they came in, but I wasn't expecting them to be cold. Still good! I ordered the Shrimp and grits dish, because of course. The grits were some type of jalapeño cheese grits and very good. I liked the dish a lot overall. I just wish they took the tails off of the shrimp for you. It just makes things messy and harder to eat when you have to remove the tails. 

The service was a little lacking. I felt like the waiter always had somewhere else to be. He seemed very removed from our conversations. If they could fix this, they would be a 5 star place hands down.

I had this awesome southern breakfast with eggs, bacon and hash browns. It was all delicious but the hash browns stole the show with little bits of bacon in there (never enough bacon!). My boyfriend got the pancakes which were good too. It's a cute spot in a hotel. I'm glad we tried it but it's not the kind of spot I'd be dying to go again.

Went for Monday happy hour.  Oysters were great, shrimp spicy, wine 1/2 price. Service was very good.  Not wild about the layout and sound level.  Would go back for lunch or happy hour but not the ambiance I'd pick for dinner
The best French 75 in the world bar none.  And the food absolutely delicious. One if the places I never miss when going to New Orleans.  Good vibe in the place as we'll, quite lively.

My boyfriend and I arrived a couple of minutes before our reservation - was sat quickly and far from the noisy bar (thank you!)

Our server was so sweet but I forgot her name ...( she was pregnant) we got our drinks and appetizers super fast but our entrees a little slower than we expected.

I recommend the LÜke burger and the roasted chicken... Soooooo yummy!!!


It was a great restaurant to dine at for my first dine in New Orleans :)

Came here for the famous 50 cent oysters and other happy hour specials starting at 3pm, apparently every day tho I am not positive about that.  Selected drinks were half-price and certain appetizers reduced.  Didn't stay for dinner but would have had we not had other plans.  Did have dinner here a few yrs ago and don't remember any details but that it was good.

This was my first taste of New Orleans. I visited Luke on a Tuesday night with two others. We had a reservation at 7pm and when we arrived waited just a few minutes to be seated. Our servers were Kevin and Kyle. I was encouraged to order a mint julep by my dining companions, which was difficult to enjoy because it was an insanely heavy pour. We ordered a dozen raw oysters for the table to start. For my entree I enjoyed the Louisiana blue crab cavatelli, which was spectacular. I was starving and I could only wish there was more of it. My companions had the Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "En Cocotte" and one of the fresh fish of the day, both were satisfied. Everything was very tasty and our servers were attentive.

This is one of my parents' favorite restaurants in town so they asked that we go today for brunch, as they are visiting. I've been to Lüke several times for dinner and have had really great food and service.

After a five minute wait spent listening to a hostess literally whine about her inability to use OpenTable in front of several customers, we were sat in the back dining room, right up against the windowed kitchen. My boyfriend remarked that everyone in the back was dressed more casually/looked less like bobble-heads and lawyers than those seated in the front, but hey, it was crowded, whatever.

I got a Bloody Maria and the Bloody Mary mix was pretty much just tomato juice. No spice to it whatsoever. My boyfriend got some sort of River Boat fruit-y rhubarb concoction with gin instead of vodka and the flavors fell flat. I'm a cocktail snob, so maybe I'm being too picky, but whatever.

We got the charcuterie and it was decent. The chicken patê and housemade mustard were really excellent but nothing else was exceptional.

I ordered the fried soft-shell crabs, poached eggs and grits. When our entree came--and my mother's entree was dropped 2 minutes after the others--I attempted to cut into a poached egg with my fork only to find that the white was not cooked AT ALL. It was in a liquid state. I took a bite of the soft-shell crab before sending it back to be recooked because ew.

When my entree came back, it was all too evident that the kitchen was clearly like "well, goddammit, we'll cook it again if they're that demanding" and threw the whole dish into a pan so that when it came back, all the textures were disgusting. The hollandaise sauce had boiled over and was puffy and full of air bubbles, the grits were congealed together into hard little grit balls, and the second round of cooking resulted in a lot of the breading on the crab falling off. My eggs were cooked, but the dish was in such an lukewarm, unappealing state after the second cooking that it was inedible.

My parents and boyfriend forced their leftovers upon me and everything was thoroughly mediocre.

Our server did comp the single entree but the bill still came to $118 before tip for 3  mediocre entrees and an appetizer. Service in general was mediocre. Not very apologetic. Did not offer to get a manager.

I do think that the restaurant puts its D-Team in the kitchen for day service, but there is no excuse for such poor execution especially at the price point. Also, why even have a D-Team at your restaurant?

Came for an early dinner and caught the tail end of happy hour-50 cent oysters and half price wine, apparently every day from 3 to 6.  Both were great!  Charcuterie plate was very good as well.  The menu is fairly brief (six entrees), and only two could be made gluten-free, but the redfish I ordered was delicious.

In my humble opinion, New Orleans is one of the top 3 dining cities in the United States, and John Besh is arguably the best chef in town (granted, he has some strong competition in Donald Link and Susan Spicer). Whatever issues I may have once had with this restaurant have dissolved completely, and I joyfully and enthusiastically pronounce my love for this wonderful little bit of heaven on earth. When we arrived for our latest evening of indulgence, we discovered that the menu had been changed and some of our old favorites were missing. My husband's mood downshifted from expectant to irritated very quickly, but he need not have worried; the items we chose were sufficiently delicious to turn things around. We started with our usual 2 dozen P&J oysters, which were better than they usually are here. I usually get a French 75 and/or a bourbon old fashioned here, and they're still some of the best cocktails in town. We had a little glitch with my husband's drink, which at first had no vodka in it and then, after being doctored up by the bartender, had way too much vodka in it. He switched beverages and all was well. 
So one change in the menu was to add shrimp and grits (Shrimp En Cocotte), and, as this is one of my favorite dishes, I chose it. Good move. Their's may well be the best executed of this Southern standard that I've ever had; creamy and spicy roasted jalapeño cheese grits with smoky Andouille and green onion sausage, redolent of that full shrimp flavor that lets you know they've infused the dish with some stock, and sizable Gulf shrimp. Perfection. Really, if they never added another dish to this menu, I could be happy with this one forever. We didn't save room for dessert, but that didn't stop us from ordering one to share. If the Chocolate Bourbon Pecan Tart with Coconut Sorbet is still on the menu when you read this, get it. Coffee as always is great here too.

The only reason they get two stars is that when we mentioned the 2 entrees we ordered were barely lukewarm, they took them off the bill.  Otherwise it would be one star.

We went with another couple, ordered wine and appetizers, which were alright but unremarkable.  All of the staff seemed frazzled and disorganized, stuff kept being dropped all over the place.  After we were served the entrees the waitress didn't check back until we called for the bill.

That's when the other couple and my not-shy wife complained, and the manager came over and apologized and did the right thing.

We ate at another Besh restaurant nearby, Domenica, the night before, and it was outstanding.  Go there instead.

Love this place for the crab omelet...the ingredients were fresh and uniquely put together.  The service was great.  A bit loud and very busy during the day so definitely call in advance for a reservation.

I've been a longtime fan of John Besh (via his PBS series), so when the opportunity came up to visit New Orleans, I jumped at the chance to try one of his restaurants.  

It was definitely a mixed bag.  The rabbit/chicken pate and gumbo were well done, but once we moved on to the entrees the blue crab cavatelli and louisiana shrimp were served lukewarm, so it was hard to warm up (so to speak) to these two dishes.  We didn't mention this to our server until the end of the meal, at which point the manager came over and had those two entrees removed from our bill.

Service overall was not up to my expectations  Our server only checked on us once during the course of the meal, and a folding tray twice crashed to the floor near us, this should have been fixed after the first occurrence.

Overall, the food rated 3 stars, minus another star for the service, plus a star for adjusting our bill.  Given the number of "star" restaurants in New Orleans, it's doubtful if the Besh offerings will be a priority for me in future visits.

Love this place!! My husband and I went during happy hour. We took a bike taxi from the French quarter area. Enjoyed a delicious Sazerac. The best seafood gumbo I had ever had. Made to perfection!! Also had fried oysters!!! Yum!! Service was excellent. Not to be missed if you are visiting NOLA.

If I had to choose my deathbed meal, it would probably be shrimp & grits. I'd like to think I've become somewhat of a connoisseur of my favorite dish. Luke's s&g are pretty darn good, and the lunch size is perfect. The crab bisque is also delicious. We had a table right by the kitchen and it was so fun to watch them whip everything up. The chef even sent us over an appetizer which consisted of pork belly, pecans, brussel sprouts, pomegranate seeds, and who knows what else- it was an amazing combination of flavors and we couldn't get enough!

I come here strictly for their happy hour: 50 cent oysters and half off dranks.  The fries and pate are also outstanding. The staff and service are consistently on point. My only complaint is their French 75 is bad. Just badddd. Like I had to send it back it was so bad. Other than that, couldn't be happier with gem of a restaurant.

Cool place, great happy hour and raw oysters are delish. Front desk could use help...we walked in at 3:45pm on Wednesday and noticed barely half the restaurant was occupied. Many empty tables. We were told it will be 10min. The two hostesses just stood there looking around and we wondered why can't we be seated with all these empty tables. Our frustrations began. Then at 10min exactly she walked us to a table that was one of the empty ones the whole time. Why were we told to wait?? Whether a restaurant is short staffed or not with servers...it sets up the first impression of a place when it's half empty and you are told there's still a wait. Bad bad bad business etiquette for front reception. If there is a situation you can't sit a guest then you cahoots advise them of it so we can be understanding. Fix front desk staff

Returned for happy hour, and was not disappointed. Word seems to have gotten out, so best make a reservation. Happy hour oysters are fresh, cold, and the perfect size raw(and the perfect price at 50¢.) The fried oysters are also worth the price at $1 apiece, and are so flavorful that you could skip the sauce if you wanted(but that is excellent, as well.) Drinks are half price(I get the River Bend...Okay, I got 3,) which is a really good deal for a craft cocktail at under $5. Another favorite is the salad Luke; I'm not a salad eater, but the beets are spectacularly sweet, the lettuce is actually beautiful, and it's dressed just right. The servers are really friendly/personable and attentive(our guy switched a wobbly table for us even though we didn't ask or complain,) and they even check on you to let you know that it's getting close to the end of happy hour, so you can get in more orders at the special prices. The only people that are a little lacking are the girls at the front; they always look us up and down and make me as if we need to pass inspection, but once you've been seated, the rest of the experience is wonderful. This will be one of my regular places to eat during oyster season. Just don't tell too many people, b/c it's getting awfully crowded.

We had fresh P&J oysters, the bisque, the tuna tartine, the roasted chicken entree, and the king salmon entree. All were sublime. The puzzling part of the meal was the cold, rock hard, factory produced (little nubs on the bottom) baguette. In a restaurant dedicated to the place and in a city where every restaurant serves hot, fresh, light baguettes, this just seemed like such an obvious miss and such an unnecessary misstep.

Overall Great food with a few minor hiccups. Its a little cluttered in the restaurant, it does get Busy so make reservations ahead of time(a must). My meal which will probably be my next one also is by far the LUKE BURGER WITH FRIES....amazing. I'd definitely go back and the hiccups I wrote don't bother me that much but if I'm being anylitycal than Yes. GREAT RESTAURANT

Came here with my marine vet and best high school friend in New Orleans 11/1/14. We were in good spirits and wanted to give this place a chance.
Nestled on St. Charles in the business district surely gave the experience a different a twist than what I'm used to-very metropolitan. Once inside, the ambiance had a degree of warmth yet the seating was cluttered and uncomfortable. I did like the tin copper ceilings and wall decor. Everything flowed and nicely put together.
We ordered the crab bisque and flamenkechu as appetizers. My friend ordered the burger and I had shrimp and grits, as a suggestion taken from our waiter. 

Everything we ordered was good, almost borderline great but not quite there.

Why? PORTIONS. 

The crab bisque tasted really good but it was served in ounces  in what resembled a shot glass. 
Same thing with my $24 shrimp and grits. 
My friend jokingly asked me "you got the shrimp, but when are they going to bring you your grits?". (the flavor was great but definitely not unmatched anywhere in a 2 miles radius- the Wank and Chalmette included)
My buddy is a marine and I'm 6'2/230lbs and the waiter brings us ONE roll for both of us prior to the appetizers.
My buddy was extremely pleased with his burger and we shared the flamenkechu which really was a home run.
The service was good but not great. I accompanied my meal with water since I don't booze and the waiter didn't offer me any options for non boozers. I literally ate my entire entrée with an empty glass the whole time. And I had to request a roll because that shrimp and grits was beyond skimpy and an insult to the "paying hungry". In all seriousness, those grits were ridiculously overpriced and should be an appetizer if they insist in serving sample portions to the "paying hungry".
I understand that the location is probably very expensive and in my conclusions it is clear that this restaurant is over hyped. Thank you Travel Channel.

Would I come again? Sure. (as long as someone else pays) Not worth the cents off a food lovers hard earned cash- there are others places in New Orleans worthy of charging like they do here. Lükes definitely hit the right notes in flavor but have yet to provide the experience as some established and legendary restaurants  do in this city.
 
If you read this and you're already sitting down at Luke's; get the burger and the flamenkechu. 

One thing to note. I'm a true local and have in New Orleans since the 1980's. The people sitting inside around me... All tourists and transplants.

I was very excited to have a meal at Luke. I wasn't in town long enough to be able to get here for dinner so my fiancé and I grabbed brunch here the Sunday we were flying out. I made a reservation on opentable just a few hours before and our table,was ready about 10 minutes after we arrived. We were seated right by the kitchen watching the chefs work through the glass. 

  They have a really nice raw bar with a variety of seafood from around the country.  After asking what kind of oysters they have the waitress went and grabbed us a raw bar menu which she forgot to give us when we were seated. I ordered some Kumamoto oysters as a app which are my favorite and hard to find in NOLA. The kumos were fresh and very tasty.  My fiancé ordered the chicken and waffles and I had the soft shell eggs Benedict. The service was pretty slow and seemed understaffed. While we waited we watch all the work go on in the kitchen. 

  I have to say I was a little disappointed at some of the practices going on in there.  They don't make the waffles fresh, they were kept in a warming drawer then put in the salamander to heat up. Which showed when the waffles arrived, they were pretty rubbery and the chicken was slightly undercooked.  The soft shell crabs were good, nice and crunchy and the eggs were poached perfectly but the sauce was a little overkill. It would have liked it to be an accompaniment rather then a soup of sauce. 

  What was disturbing to me was watching the grill man touch raw hamburger patties then touch cooked foods like French fries and the waffles. Not once in the 45 minutes we were there did he even once wash or wipe his hands. I hope they revisit some of their sanitation practices.

The food here was great, but honestly the experience was not worth 16 dollars for a chicken and waffles dish. The menu is very pricey, we had a dirty utensil, and the complimentary bread comes out uncut and the waiter seemed annoyed when we asked for it to be cut, at least they could have given us a proper knife to cut the bread so the table could share. Just found that strange but the food was ol, the fried chicken in the chicken and waffles was great, the waffles butter I could have done without, I would have liked my own syrup on the side as there was only a very small amount of syrup on the waffles so I was not impressed. I have had a better chicken and waffles at Cheesecake Factory. The gumbo and crab bisque were phenomenal and they had great fries and burger. It is an ok place but not somewhere I would make a point to go back to.

Came here for dinner and had very unfriendly service. Two people at our table's food was cold when served to us, so we asked for them to take it back and heat it up...They only took one person's ignoring the second person. When they returned the second person asked again for them to heat up their food. 

The tablecloths had paper on top, which was not classy at all and reminded me of a cheap family restaurant. 

Was not impressed with our visit.

Oh my, the food!  We are now big John Besh fans. We were lured here for the 50 cent happy hour oysters. I think the local beers during HH were $4. We also tried the food other than the oysters and it didn't disappoint. So far we've had the rabbit and chicken pate, Tabasco fried chicken smothered with red beans and rice, crab bisque. The flavor of the red beans and rice was so good and smoky. If you like red beans and rice, this is something you have to order. We've only arrived 3 days ago and have been here twice and plan to eat here more times.
Tip: make ressies for happy hour- I've seen the hostess make people without reservations wait a while and it gets busier as the evening progresses. Order your oyster in batches. That's right, go for it and put in your order for 3-4 dozen at the beginning. It's a busy place and the waitstaff may not get to you right away. Service is ok for a busy place. The waitstaff do try. There was this one guy who was our main waiter- he was a sweetie. Forgot his name but he was tall and lanky with long braids. Give that guy a raise!

Like many others I'm still confused as to why there is an umlaut in Lüke. I almost laughed out loud when the couple next to me thought that there would be German food served. Silly nolans. 

I came here due to the fact this place was walking distance to my hotel - well at least my original hotel reservation at Intercontinental. 

It was "We Live to Eat" week in NOLA which was an equivalent of restaurant week. So I made reservations to try their prefix menu.

I started off with the oysters (not part of the prefix menu). They were really good and fresh. I was disappointed I missed out on the happy hour special as I would totally come back for the oysters. 

For the prefix menu I had: 

Lobster and ricotta stuffed squash blossoms
This had an interesting lime-y taste - yet savory. The thing I can compare it to is the lime, salt, pepper sauce you dip french cube beef in. The squash blossoms were good and the lobster was a bit negligible. 

Slow cooked swordfish with heirloom tomato, olive, caper, garganelli
If I learned anything on this trip, it is that I don't care much for green olives. I don't know what I was expecting with this dish -  and I think this is my fault for perhaps not reading  the menu carefully or asking questions. I suppose this is a good dish if you like swordfish, tomato sauce and green olives - however because I don't like those things that much I really shouldn't have gotten dish dish. 

Fig tart, brown butter ice cream
This is really good if you like fig newtons. It was basically a giant fig tart with ice cream. It was pretty good - but I don't care for figs that much. The ice cream was delicious though. 

In all I couldn't really understand the flavors that were presented at Lüke for restaurant week. I think the ambiance is great for an after work kinda deal as it's very french brasserie. The happy hour specials I understand for the oysters are also very good. I would come back for happy hour if I lived in the area.

Yelp wasn't kidding about the Oysters. I can sit at LUKE and eat them all day like seeds, they are fresh and delicious. 

The shrimp and grits was also the best I've had! Atmosphere inside was nice and sophisticated, definitely more of a business district type of establishment vs. One in the French Quarter. 

I highly recommend Luke!
Best cheese burger around and gorgeous place. The service was on point. Not a thing wrong with this gem.

Located in the business district of New Orleans, just right outside the French Quarter, I would definitely recommend trying Luke. You can't beat 50 cent oysters and $1 fried oysters during happy hour everyday from 3-6 PM. Super fresh and yummy! The shrimp and grits were also a favorite here. Although, i wouldn't be able to eat this alone for a meal because it is so rich. So I would suggest sharing this entree. The bread pudding was to die for! It is served with hot buttered pecan sauce and vanilla bean ice cream. Perfect!

The only reason I give this place 4-stars is because of the hostess. When I originally tried to put my name in with the hostess for a table, I was told there was no more availability for happy hour seating. I asked her some other questions and I was given such attitude! So I walked out, looked at open table and found a 3:00 reservation, which was in 20 minutes. I was secretly laughing at the lady when i strolled in 20 minutes later with a reservation. The hostess was probably not happy about this, but she had to acknowledge this open table reservation. Despite the reservation, I still had to wait another 30 minutes while she seated all the other parties that came after us. 

Overall, I was pleased with this dining experience minus one grumpy hostess.

Went to Luke for dinner with several friends Halloween evening and it was incredibly good. Our server was exceptionally on top of things, offered great suggestions and was very personable. All of our cocktails were delicious. I had a chicken dish that was amazing and my fiancee's steak was good too. The portions were very French. It was a great setting for a wonderful beginning to our evening. Definitely will go again next time I am in New Orleans.

I found out about 50 cents oysters happy hour and had to visit. The place was busy but I was seated at the table fairly quick and the waitress was very attentive. Mint julep was so strong but it was good & the gumbo was pretty good as well. The oysters took a while but I was expecting it and was happily sipping my drink - but a lady (I'm assuming a manager) was very nice and came to apologize.

I don't know what I can say about this place that hasn't been said before, however I am still compelled to add my 2 cents. It's really difficult to get beyond the awesomeness of 50 cent oysters during a 3-hr happy hour with the delightful mild horse radish sauce and amazing drink specials to boot (try one of the 2 house brews!) but we ordered the charcuterie plate which featured 4 housemade pates that were unique, rich and very substantial for an appetizer. Fresh bread got to us halfway through our pate tasting, but better late than never (especially with the delicious meat spread awaiting it!). The pickled watermelon rind was a fun refreshing surprise. We wanted to sit at the bar, but waiting for the back to open up was fine since we got a view of the kitchen. Our servers were friendly and very knowledgable. Great experience and we didn't even order a meal. Can't wait to go back for one (or two or three or more)!

We have dined at the San Antonio location several times previously and enjoyed the occasion. 

Walked in around 1.30pm on a Saturday - where the host desk ignored us before saying it was a 30 min wait. I don't mind waiting but it is concerning when the place is only 60% full. While we were a waiting 2 other couples walked in without reservations and we're seated promptly - the difference? We were casually dressed while the people they seated were more formal. A complaint to the Manager before we left - she couldn't care less - pretty much ignored us again - only saying "I understand". 

We left for Dragos on the Riverfront - where we were warmly welcomed and had a host and waitresses that understand the concept of customer service and not profiling beforehand. I am sure that the Staff at Dragos appreciated the large tip on a $90 lunch check. The Host desk at Luke feel that looking down on People is more important than their paycheck and those that fund it.

UPDATE - 11/23/2014 - 2 weeks later - neither this review - nor an email to the John Besh Restaurant Group has got any response. I know reading this review sounds like an embittered customer - that is what I would think, but I am more than willing to praise places that do a good job and care about their customers - just bear my experience when making your dining choice.
We had the lamb dish and the shrimp and grits which were both served piping hot. Our server was pleasnt but very busy!

Breakfast, Lunch, and Happy Hour -- Triple Crown

Spent 4 days in New Orleans on business and had breakfast, lunch, and one happy hour here and all were stellar.  Breakfast -- recommend the beignets with chocolate to dip them in and the pancakes with the yummy honey pecan butter.  Lunch -- huge sandwiches and great soups (especially the crab bisque).  If you're really hungry have the jumbo shrimp, andouille sausage and spicy cheese grits for lunch.  I had the fresh fish (Drum) prepared amandine with chunks of crab.  Happy Hour -- 75 cent oysters and half price beers, wines, and cocktails. I'm not an oyster fan, but was with two people who love them and they said they were fresh and flavorful.  Recommend making reservations, especially for Happy Hour.   Stop in -- you won't be disappointed.

If I could do half stars it would be a 2.5 but I'll give them the benefit. Disclosure: we came at 10:15p and they close at 11p so it probably affected service but it is a John Besh restaurant and therefore I expect a bit better.
Our 2 waiters clearly did not communicate with each other in regard to our service, one was professional and the other was not. Neither explained any sort of special and mainly showed up to take our order rather than guide us through the meal.
We ordered a tuna tartare for an appetizer and it took roughly 15 minutes and was average at best.
Our main course was a ribeye that was cooked perfectly but lacked the substance of a good slice, my wife's Blue Crab Cavatelli was good but nothing special. We ordered a side of sautéed seasonal vegetables and were met with brussels sprouts, with sparse amounts of green beans and yellow squash, which took a side of bearnaise sauce to get through.
Dessert was a bread pudding that was above average but not the best we have had in this city.
All in all this meal was sadly forgettable, I will definitely give another Besh restaurant a try but this was definitely not the impression a restaurant of this caliber hopes to makes.

Food quality was amazing although the price was definitely on the upper end. Good environment with a friendly atmosphere. You HAVE to get either the crab bisque or the seafood gumbo as they are both amazing. We ordered the roasted chicken, and it was one of the best entrees I've ever had. The other items sounded really good as well, but I was broke from spending all my money on booze all weekend, and decided to go for the cheaper alternative. 

The only reason I'm not giving it a 5 star is because the servers took forever to seat us and get our food ordered because they were too busy watching the LSU Alabama game. We had to talk to the host so that she can get the servers to come serve us...

Overall, I recommend it, as you get what you pay for.

The food was excellent.  The service was ok.  The fried oyster salad was very good.  The seafood gumbo is silky smooth.  The atmosphere is a bit noisy, in the front dining room.  The bar looked very old and cool.

Go to Lüke and enjoy their .50 oysters and half-off drinks!  

Having said that, the service at Lüke was less than sub-par.  Maybe the restaurant is understaffed or the staffs just don't care enough, but we sat next to dirty table for at least 30 minutes.  What blew my mind was how the waiter who was responsible for attending the table went to get the tip left by the previous diners and left the dirty dishes sitting there.

I hate writing this review. Luke is really my "go to" in the city. While the food is consistently good the service has diminished to the point of embarrassment. When dining we were seated promptly, as I had reservations. That is where it all went down hill. No one even acknowledged us for twenty minutes. We were not even brought a glass of water. When a waiter did finally arrive he offered no explanation for his tardiness. We ordered our drinks and meal all at that point, as it was lunch time and we didn't have all day to wait. Little did we know all day was what they had in mind. We
waited over one hour for two sandwiches. The waiter never apologized for never refilling our drinks or for the long wait times for food. An observant manager noticed our perplexed faces, and lack of food or drink, and asked if everything was alright. We informed him that all was not in fact alright and he brought us water and was very apologetic when we told him we are locals that come in all the time. If they were busy maybe I would give them a pass, but that was not the case. John Besh, if he's still involved, needs to get a handle on this place or it is going to be a memory. Unfortunately for me I am afraid it is now a bad memory.
Happy Hour from 3-6pm. If you love oysters this is the place for that at 50 cents a piece with half off on selected alcoholic beverages.

-Great Atmosphere 
-Great Service 
- Terrific Food
- Loved!
I seriously don't know where to begin.  This wonderful John Besh creation is purely delightful.  

The location is only a few blocks from Canal Street but seems like miles from the tourist feel of the Quarter tourist restaurants.  

Upon entering we were greeted promptly and warmly.  We had reservations and in just a few minutes she walked us back to our table almost in back (which was really great)

The tables are fairly close together so chances are very good you will hear your neighbors' conversation so be warned.  The overall feel reminds me of something from time past; the restaurant is in a beautiful old building with many unique details on the walls and I love, love, love the bar in the middle of the room.  The whole feel was very lively and energetic yet in our little table from afar still relaxed.

Onto the food.... I had built Chef Besh up so high in my mind I honestly thought he couldn't live up to it. Too unrealistic.  He did live up to my expectations and surpassed my dreams for a perfect dinner.

Appetizer - Baked Oysters - sublime

Appetizer 2 - Crab bisque - made many other crab bisque I have had pale in comparison (more soupy than bisque-y by the way)

Appetizer 3 - (hey we were sharing!) Cold Shrimp- these were very good quality.  Only odd thing was I had to ask for horseradish / only served with ketchup.  A note on the horseradish.  If you like horseradish - order some on the side here just to try.  I don't know why or how but it is the best horseradish you will ever try and the most potent.  I wish I could get my hands on it to keep at my house. 

Entrée 1 - Hamburger.  Just so wow you can't imagine how good until you taste it.  The meat is probably the tastiest hamburger meat I have ever had and I have had some pretty great burgers.

Entree 2 - Blue Crab Cavatelli - pasta with red sauce with blue crab.  Just perfect.

Dessert - are you kidding?  After 3 appetizers and tasting a little of 2 Entrees dessert wasn't even a consideration.

Bottom line: Go, go, go, go, go, go!  (but make a reservation)

Wanted to eat here, tried to eat here, reservations are merely a stab at a time you may be seated and expect the curly haired blonde at the desk to treat you poorly.

We had a handicapped person in our party and even after asking for a chair for her 2x we were ignored.  No worries, thanks in part to the poor service we found The Pelican Club which we enjoyed immensely.

I was very excited when I found a John mesh restaurant in my hotel. Than extremely disappointed with breakfast. The meal started with a miscommunication with our server and continued downhill from there. I ordered the egg white frittata which came out over cooked and tasting like it was fried in bacon grease. The side of potatoes were fried in bacon grease and contained bacon. As a vegetarian I was pretty dismayed the menu failed to mention this. 

My husbands plate was lackng the accompania to advertised. The grits were dry and the requested butter to put on them took 15 minutes to arrive. 

I would try this restaurant again but would choose lunch or dinner.

Great eats! The food here was fantastic. Service was a bit slow but the waiters more than made up for it. They comped us a second round of drinks and even our dessert (and frankly it wasn't that slow compared to restaurants I've eaten at elsewhere and none of whom have offered much apart from apologies). After profusely apologizing for the delay even though we didn't say anything (honestly didn't even notice it was that long) we enjoyed the shrimp and grits which was great and fish. The best part of the meal was the bourbon bread pudding, incredibly delicious! Unlike other reviewers everyone we encountered was extremely friendly and accommodating, we were immediately seated even though we were 15 minutes late for our reservation, so maybe there has been some recent staff changes? Either way I will definitely be recommending this restaurant to friends!

Arrived late into New Orleans Sunday night and nothing seems to be open later than 10 pm. What??  I supposed I should be sympathetic being in the industry but my wife and I were starving so....  

Luke was open till 11pm. Yes!!!!!  Walked a few blocks to it and was not disappointed at all. A mint julep and an old fashion later, we were in a good mood. 

A little gumbo was full of shrimp and andouille sausage rice and green onions. We have arrived. 

Shrimp sausage and grit was amazing. My wife's. Mahe mahe was perfect as well. Crispy fried kale to go with purée of cauliflower was fantastic. 

Our dessert was a bread pudding that was absolutely the best. Broiled till crispy and topped with candied pecans butter bourbon caramel.  I couldn't be hungry anymore at this point but we flying through the bowl like there was no tomorrow. 

I can't wait to eat my way through my trip to NOLA. Visiting gracious bakery tomorrow. Awesome trip to come.

So many restaurants in New Orleans - so many! Why did we subject ourselves to the poor service at Lüke? 

Food is better than average. Short menu and everything was well prepared and tasty. Though if you're gonna serve big whole pieces of bibb lettuce best to use a larger plate eh?

And the local trend for serving bread seems to be in a napkin - for me this get's old and cliché real quick....

Again, everything tastes good on the food menu - though the prices do seem odd/high, especially the starters - 

I could tell you about dessert but none was offered....

Now I can go in detail about the awful service - or you can just trust me that this place a. Needs to train staff from the top down. B. Needs a new personnel manager.

I saw a "manager" clear a table by putting her fingers in used glasses and carry them away -- tacky and unsanitary; the hostess was overwhelmed to say the least and had the personality of cardboard (and not new box cardboard - like used three times for moving box under your bed that you prolly should have thrown away card board), the bartender gave looks of "why are you trying to order more drinks look and every time she made my drink (three times) it tasted different - same drink three different tastes - yea....  And the busboys/expediters were so ballsy/pushy you better hold on to the table when they landed with your order.

Oh our server you ask? I have no idea because he was barely around unless you ask another server to find ours - 

So yea, maybe three stars is generous, but the food was good.

Dear John (Besh):

The last time I was in NOLA, I fell in love with you at Luke.  So why, John, why do you forsake me now?

Don't get me wrong: your $0.75 oysters during happy hour, up $0.25/each from the last time I was here, were cheap enough and the size of your head.  But it took so long to get them at 4:30 on a Saturday that your guy gave me half a dozen extra and a sheepish apology about being in the weeds.  Okay, well, these things happen.  

But tonight, my dear John, tonight was another story altogether.  I went with two friends of mine for dinner.  We had reservations at 8 and were promptly seated.  Our waiter was very nice, and tried real hard to remember your bourbon selection, but could only come up with Maker's Mark and Jim Beam.  We placed our drink and dinner orders, and waited.

The appetizers came out very quickly.  I was pleased because the service was so speedy.  But as we watched the kitchen activities from the table in the  back corner of the room, it became apparent that the speed with which we received our appetizers was not to be replicated with the entrees.

We waited. And we waited.  And we waited.  Our waiter never came back.   Not once!  He seemed to be ignoring us. Then a waitress came by. She said, "I've just been to check on your order, and it's not ready yet. What did you order again?" Does that make sense to you, John? It doesn't make sense to me. And we kept waiting. We could see our waitress in the kitchen. She was clearly trying to get something for us.  Finally, after five or seven minutes, out she comes with someone who must have been the manager, who is carrying a purse (something we all found to be very odd) and they were carrying two salads and soup.  The manager said that there had been a misunderstanding or a mix up or something, and dinner would not be for a little while, and for that reason they were offering us two different salads and a lobster bisque. She said, "I don't know if you are hungry for these, but I hope that they will tide you over while you were waiting."  But all we really wanted was our dinner, John.  Was that too much to ask?

When our dinner had finally come out, it had been close to 45 minutes after we finished our appetizers. Yes, the food was delicious, but there is no reason why we should've set onto it like ravenous vultures. There's no reason why it should've taken that long to get the food in the first place.

After dinner, the waitress asked if we would like some dessert. We ordered one dessert for the table with three spoons and some coffee. It took a full 15 minutes to get the desert and the coffee on the table. In the process of eating the ice cream on top of my dessert, I found a small ice cube embedded in the ice cream.  How do ice cubes get into ice cream? The answer is beyond me.

In any case, John, the food at your restaurant was very tasty, but the service leaves a lot to be desired.  Do you think that it should take two hours and 15 minutes for three people to have a few appetizers, three entrées, and a shared dessert?  I don't.  

Dearest John: you need to do something about the service in your restaurant. Giving your customers extra food because your kitchen or bar can't keep up with the orders is just shooting yourself in the foot.  Giving your customers extra food because your servers forget to place, fire, or hand off an order is also just shooting yourself in the foot.  Instead, you should probably just get the order right the first time. It seems pretty straightforward to me.

I want to love you, John. I really do. Do you think you can improve on these things for the next time I'm in town?  If not, I may have to dump you for Donald Link.  

Love, 
A foodie from DC

Another great Yelp tip. It was really cold the weekend I was in NOLA and I wanted
to have breakfast somewhere other than Mothers (which I really like) but it had to be close to my hotel. Read the reviews and went for breakfast. Had traditional breakfast of scrambled eggs and bacon (no grits and no biscuits cause of diet) but they
happily substituted a terrific fruit cup instead. Bacon was really good. My wife had the crab meat omelet and devoured it. Service was very good and I was very happy with the choice. Thanks again Yelp reviewers.

We had a reservation for three at 730 and arrived around 715.  We were seated at 725 and greater promptly by our server.  We received our drinks and the server answered all of our questions.

The gumbo was full of shrimp oysters and okra, very tasty with great consistency.
The baked oysters were just "fair", cooked only half through.  

Two of us ordered the Luke burger and one had the crab legs.  The burger was huge and has a great flavor brought out by the caramelized onions and bacon.  The fries were decent but a bit over cooked.  The crab legs presented nicely and were full and delicious.

All in all a great experience and would go back again when in NOLA!

I just wanted to let you know I thoroughly enjoyed my lunch. I know people are quick to complain but I prefer to be quick to compliment. I had the river Bend drink-excellent. I had the gumbo for app and shrimp and grits for entree. Both were awesome! Great taste! I also wanted to compliment Johnny as a waiter. He knew his foods and how to explain them to a tourist as me and made sure everything was to my satisfaction.  I never had to ask for anything as he was quick to make sure all was filled (drink) and food prompt. Thanks for a great experience!

We spent 4 days in NOLA and of all the restaurants we went to (Cafe Amelie, Stanley, Felix,Antoine, Commander's Palace, Revolution...all excellent), this place is the only one that proved to be the black cloud of dining experiences. 

Believe me when I say the previous reviews regarding their service are all true. We truly believe their waiters are selective and discriminate. For example - our waiter walked to every table asking "How are things going guys? Anything else I can do for you?" and clearly ignored our table. I had to literally raise my hand high in the air to flag him down for a refill of water. I refuse to believe he simply forgot to ask us. It was in no way a busy time when we were there. And his attitude had to be as plastic as a five cent plastic rose.

It's a shame that our memory of NOLA is based on this restaurant's clearly discriminatory practice although this time it's been replaced with prejudice against Non-blacks and non-whites. 

Discrimination is alive and well in NOLA and you'll find it in Luke. Best to stay in the French Quarter where you're treated with genuine courtesy.
Food was very good and according to my French friend the Pate was very authentic. Considering the quality I must say it is reasonably priced.

Although we had a 9:30 reservation we weren't seated until at least an hour later. They truly tried to be gracious about this. However when we were seated this is where the graciousness abruptly ended. The waiter was horrible.....rude and very unprofessional. Never checked on us after our meals were received....and removed dishes prior to being finished. Even after I made a comment! 
The food was absolutely divine and i will be back for this reason....however if we are seated with the waiter we experienced this weekend.....we will wait for someone else.
Lots of great places in NOLA and some people won't put up with rude wait staff but will go somewhere else.

As we were visiting NOLA for the first time we wanted to have a great dining experience. Luke's was sadly lacking. The menu was not interesting or innovative.
The dinner arrived cold and the server was too busy to check in with us. If you plan on The best part of our meal was the outstanding Oysters, which were Kumoto and from the west coast. We should have saved our money for dining in San Francisco.

Do not recommend this place for a great dining experience.
Their oyster happy hour is the best!  Good drinks, but it's always full so make reservations or go during off times.

I visited Luke on my first time to New Orleans. I had read a couple blogs that had mentioned the restaurant and being a big Top Chef fan, and knowing who John Besh is, I had to try it. I really enjoyed the atmosphere however, there isn't anywhere to stand inside while you wait for your table. They do take reservations, so I definitely recommend doing that.

For starters we got a couple of bottles of red wine for the table. They were moderately priced, not too expensive. Then we got the Assiette de Charcuterie for an appetizer. I thought this contained cheese, but it didn't, so that was my fault for not being too excited when I saw a tray of unrecognizable meats. However, I will say all the ones I tried were good.

For my meal I had the Louisiana Blue Crab Cavatelli. It was really great but the portion was pretty small in my opinion. Since we were gearing up for a night out on Bourbon Street, I was hoping a pasta dish would provide me the perfect base. I did get the chance to try some of my friends left over Entrécote Grillee et Frites which was my favorite of everything we ordered so I wished I had spent the extra $8 for it.

Overall, a good restaurant, but I think for the amount of money spent, I might have found a more filling entree.

My business partner and I had lunch at Luke yesterday and it was terrible. We ordered the tuna and Brussels Sprouts appetizers to start off with.
