The Brussel Sprouts were hard and under cooked and the tuna was nothing special. My friend ordered the soft shell crab sandwich for his meal and I had the burger. His soft shell crabs were greasy and so were the fries that came with it. My burger was over cooked, the cheese was burnt and it was barely edible. We were in a hurry so sending everything back and complaining to get new food wasn't an option. All I know is this will be the last time I go here for any meal.

This restaurant was nice. The food was very good with the exception that it was a little salty. We got several entrees here, varying from a turducken to fried fish. I personally got the shrimp and grits. It was very good - just a little salty. We also got a bottle of wine that was very tasty. My only regret is that we came in on Thanksgiving night and they had a smaller thanksgiving menu, I thought that was all they had to offer that evening - so I ordered off that menu. Then I see all these other diners eating things that are not on that menu. I wish I was told the full menu was also available. But regardless, the food was delicious and the ambiance was very nice.
50 cent oysters 3 to 6 for happy hr. Some of the best in town. Gumbo is also amazing. Ask for the homemade mignonette sauce. Amazing

Fantastic service and delicious food. There were a few vegetarians at my table, and our server Ritchie Rich (fabulous server) was able to make great recommendations and accommodations. The service was personal and attentive. The food was tasty and priced reasonably for a nice sit down restaurant. Another bonus is being able to make restaurant reservations since so many places in NOLA don't take reservations.

went here in the beginning of October for brunch and oh my goodness was it delicious!! we ordered: Baked P&J Oysters, Louisiana Blue Crab Cavatelli, and the Beignets. Everything came out in a timely manner, our server was exceptional! He gave us suggestions on what to order for food and drinks; he seemed very knowledgeable. The place is a bit small so make sure to come early so you won't have to wait. I would definitely come back!

Being a regular in the NOLA dining scene, I usually opt for French Quarter but staying in the business district and being a John Besh fan, I couldn't resist trying this spot out. I went a few times for brunch ordered crab omelet and Southern breakfast. While they were both tasty, I expected more from John Besh than what I got. At these prices, I would certainly choose several other more tasty brunch options for the same or less in cost. 

The other disappointment was their service. I went in alone and had the waitress both days be a lot more attentive to men that were there alone who came after me and got their food before. Maybe it was the suit factor but it certainly wasn't Maybelline. 

The place is a bit cramped too which should make attentiveness for the service staff easier (less running around)- at least one would think. Would love to try out their dinner next time I am there though to give myself a more accurate sense of the Besh-ness deliciousness.

Seeing as though this restaurant was directly across the street from our hotel, we opted for convenience, and safety (as it was Bayou Classic weekend).

Luckily, having no reservations, we were immediately seated. Our servers were great, and had excellent product knowledge. I was sold on a Blantons, and the Wife went with some vodka concoction, that was also excellent. For a starter, we went with the seafood gumbo. Amazing.

For our entrees, the Wife had a white fish, with crab meat, and I went with the shrimp and grits. We scarfed down these entrees like starving Ethiopians. The food was really that good. As far as my shrimp and grits, it was, by far, the best I've ever had.

Perfect food, excellent drinks, and great service. I can't wait to try a John Besh restaurant again.

Oh my goodness. Eggs in a jar. 

Based on my sentence above, you may be wondering what the heck I'm talking about. Well, Luke has an incredible breakfast dish called Eggs in a jar. Now, I'm not one for grits....they're too....."gritty" (heh). I actually demolished these cheesy, jalapeno-y goodness. The eggs themselves were very straightforward and poached, but once you pop the yolk and that lovely golden center runs over the already cheesy grits...all I can say is, "heaven". Now, throw in several batter-fried shrimp to rim the jar, and you have a meal that will keep you full far past lunch time. 

For an added treat, get the beignets with the chocolate sauce and preserves. While they aren't as good as Cafe du Monde's, they are still quite delicious with a cup of coffee.
I have to agree the chicken and rabbit pate was outstanding!   Though the pickled watermelon tasted like a jolly rancher!

I attended a private event here in Luke's wine room. The staff and the food were amazing! The manager and banquet captain were named Robert and Robert, plus there was a really helpful female server whose name I did not catch. 

Excellent, attentive and sincere service. The servers met and exceeded expectations. The food was excellent. I had the fried oyster salad, gumbo, catfish meuniere and vanilla cake. Everything was five stars. Highly recommend!
Plump and juicy $.50 oysters during 3-6PM happy hour!! Parking was also across the street as well, reason for 4 stars because service wasn't very great.

Brussels sprouts and bread pudding ... Is how you stole my heart! 

Here's a few juke tips to keep in mind before you arrive: 

1.  You need a reservation (at least on the weekends). The hostesses were not taking any walk ins. 

2.  The menu changes often, so do g come with your heart set on anything... Even their menu online is boy current. 

3. Try to get a table in the back room so you can watch the kitchen work their magic. 

What I ordered: 

1. Old fashioned: 4 stars because they use the good luxardo cherries. Beware they use Jim Beam if you don't ask for something else. 

2. Crispy Brussels sprouts with cheese and awesome sauce: 5 stars hands down best sprouts I've ever had 

3. Juke salad: 4 stars: tip you can order 1/2 sizes on the salads. Awesome house made buttermilk dressing and yummy yellow beets!

4. Squash crepes: 2 stars ... I sent it back it was not flavors I enjoyed.. Heavy sage and thanksgiving stuffing taste. 

5. Jalapeño cheesy grits: 5 stars ... Best grits ever! 

6. Pecan bread pudding: 5 stars. We were drooling over this in the window do the chef sent one out for us... It was as amazing as it looked. 

Despite sending my entree back, we had a great meal. The service and food was spot on. Thanks Juke!

I attended last night's Sunday Supper at Luke's.  It was really rather fun sitting with a bunch of strangers and sharing food and conversation.  I enjoyed the overall experience.  Three of the four courses were great but the coq au vin was one tough, dry bird-even with the yummy sauce.  It was authentically made with rooster, but I thought if you slow cook something long enough it would eventually become tender.  That didin't happen.  On the other hand, the oysters, baked and raw, the king crab legs thermador, the butternut squash with shrimp bisque, and the baba au rhum were all great, even if the shrimp in the bisque were a bit salty.  If only they'd been able to pull off the main course, this would have been a five star review.

We were very excited to check-out John Besh's restaurant and were extremely disappointed. Ambiance was not romantic or friendly at all. Lights were too bright, very loud as all tables are located right next to the bar that had tv screens. It gave a feel of sports bar, but definitely not a fine dining restaurant. 
Food was ok, but it was not anything special to recommend or return for. We ordered charcuterie platter and rigatoni Bolognese. One of the pate's had really bad taste. Wondering if anyone in the kitchen tried it before serving it to the guests. Pasta was al dente, but nothing special. 
Service was absolutely unacceptable! First of all stuff was not friendly. They acted like they really did not want to be there. Their uniform was dirty and not ironed. Made me question quality of the food and cleanliness of the kitchen right away. They never smiled or asked us if we like the food or offered 2nd round of drinks. When we told server that our sauté vegetables were steamed and looked unappetizing, he just took the plate from the table and woke away without apologizing or offering anything else. We were given check before we asked for it or had a chance to order desert. Shockingly disappointing service! I will make sure to write a review everywhere I can. Maybe John Besh will pay his restaurant a visit and take off his name before it's too late!

We were so happy to find a place that served the very rare Kumamoto oysters and made our way there. Although they had a Happy Hour going on featuring .75 cent oysters, we opted for the $45/dozen Kumamotos from Washington. The oysters were divine. They are buttery and about a 1/4 of the size of a gulf oyster, but wow! Worth every penny. We should have stayed to eat entrees there (as we love John Besh), but we were there for the rare oysters. Next time, we will def order other entrees.

Really wanted to give a five-star but the service was...hmmm kinda slow

What we ordered: 

i) SOUPES ET SALADES
Crab Bisque
Matzo Ball & Roast Chicken Soup

ii) BAR À HUÎTRES
"le Plateau" Of Gulf Oysters

iii) PLATS PRINCIPAUX
Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "en Cocotte" (roasted jalapeño cheese grits, andouille & green onion sausages)
Poulet Grand-mère (herb roasted local chicken, allan benton's bacon, farmers' market vegetables & whipped potatoes)
Étouffée (brown shrimp, garganelli pasta)

iv) DESSERTS
Brendan's Bread Pudding (vanilla bean ice cream & hot buttered pecan sauce)
Chocolate Bourbon Pecan Tart (bittersweet chocolate, coconut sorbet)
Bourbon Vanilla Bean Crème Brûlée (madeleines de commercy)
Gateau Basque (vanilla cake with creme fraiche & louisiana berry marmalade)

An ok-experience, nothing to be missed.. We ordered-
Chicken n waffles- meh, the meat was ok, waffles were soggy and extremely sweet. not worth the price at all.
Shrimp n grits dish - pretty good
Coffee - meh
Best part was they accommodated couple of vegetarians in our party.. The server was very attentive and checked with the kitchen for options.. N everybody ended up with a decent breakfast.. Portions are small though.. You need a reservation .. service is pretty slow, even the coffee refills took forever.

Must! Must! Must stop! Especially if military, and definitely if Marine Corps. This is one of  our own who made it big, but did it right. Food is phenomenal! Staff is extraordinary! Great times, great place AGAIN!!! My fourth time

Happy hour is now $0.75 per oyster! (Not $0.50) Still one of the best deals in town. Oysters taste so fresh that you don't need to put any sauce on it. Seafood gumbo has huge chunks of oysters in it. Yum!

So many glowing reviews and the fact that this is John Besh's latest restaurant made us want to dine here. I was meeting a dear friend I have not seen in 10 years, I wanted the experience to be memorable. Looking at the reviews and considering my previous experience at Mr. Besh's other restaurants, I made reservations for four at Lüke. 

The experience from start to finish was mediocre at best and rude at worst. Our friends arrived before us and they were having drinks at the bar. I greet them at the bar and walk over to the hostess stand to notify of our reservation. I couldn't get to speak the hostess for a good 10 minutes even though I was standing right in front of her because she was busy taking calls. She never acknowledged anyone standing in front of her, nor did she ask us to wait for a while. There were at least three parties that stood by the hostess desk waiting for her to get off the phone. Finally, after she got off the phone taking calls, she asks if I have a reservation. I gave her my name and said it is for 7:30pm but we are early and she says she cannot find the reservation. A moment of panic set in because I made the reservation two months ago and I was worried it may have been lost since then. After putting me on hold again to take a call, she resumes the search and says - with an eye roll - "you made the reservation for 7 not 7:30". Oh, ok. How dare I not remember the time?! And then she walks away...no words said. Baffled by this bizarre reception, I go back to the bar and order a drink with my friends. My husband offered to take over the "wait at the hostess stand" duty while I get a drink. The River Bend cocktail made with vodka, lemon juice, basil syrup, blueberries, and ginger ale is excellent. The ginger and basil make the drink exciting. 

After another effort at the hostess stand we are finally seated. 

We peruse the menu while catching up on the past 10 years and decide to order. Our server - Ben - was aloof from the start. Never once asked if we have any questions regarding the menu, didn't offer any drinks, and disappeared for extended periods of time. Halfway through the meal and noticing that every table around us has a bread plate, my husband asks for bread. Ben brings us some bread nonchalantly. After trying to get his attention a few times, and finally getting him to come to our table, i request a glass of wine with my meal, which arrived as I was about to finish my main course. A glass of wine should not take 20 minutes to arrive at the table...not in a restaurant of this caliber. All through the meal we had to flag other waiters to get water and wine because Ben was MIA.

This would have been a one star review if not for the food. The pate of Louisiana rabbit and chicken livers was a great start to my meal. Simply delicious! For my main dish I ordered the Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "En Cocotte" - a different take on the traditional shrimp and grits. It was excellent with the green onion sausage bits being my favorite. My dining companions all enjoyed their dishes. 

We did not get dessert because we were asked or offered any. In fact, after being ignored for another extended period of time, we were offered the check, not dessert. I would have loved to try the chocolate bourbon pecan tart, but alas!

While the food at Lüke is stellar, the service from start to finish is abysmal. Somebody at this establishment needs to train their staff well. The silver lining of this entire experience is that I got to see my friend after a long gap of 10 years.

Good things:
1) As with many of the John Besh restaurants, this place has a great happy hour
2) Good oysters

We go here for happy hour pretty often, as they have 1/2 beer, wine, and specialty cocktails, along with 50 cent oysters. And they are the good, briney, yummy oysters! I would recommend the happy hour to anyone and everyone. 

Since its near where I work, Ive also been there for a few "fancy" lunches for celebrations. The food is pretty good, its just not my favorite in the area for the category of "fancy lunch".

In a world class restaurant city, Luke shines above all the others.  I wish I could have tasted all the menu but I can recommend the crispy brussel sprouts, the beet salad, shrimp in cheesy grits and the ribeye steak.  Can't remember the wine we ordered but the pricing on the wines list was very fair.  The two of us shared the four dishes and it was more than enough food.  Hope to be back when we visit next year.

My husband and I ate here last night for our anniversary! Our waiter was so awesome and the food was delicious!!! I had Shrimp and Grits and my husband had roasted chicken! Both were delicious as well as our cocktails! Great authentic NOLA food!!

I love oysters, and not the skrimpy mini ones that are "more sweet" and are "fuller flavor"...I like me some big ass oysters. You'd think a place like Luke, with its Parisian vibe would be trying to sell me on some babies, but they're not pushing the petites at all. 

You listen to mama Morgan and you go in during Happy Hour, 3-6, errday (last time I checked) and get you some big ass oysters. They don't call them that, cause that's how the businesses in the Quarter try to reel you in, but they are!...They're big and I love them AND they're 50 cents. Yes, 50 cents each, so splurge on a dozen or two. Of course, if you don't like oysters, just take me and I'll help you out. I have been to Luke a few times, and just recently discovered the humongoness of their oysters, only rivaled by Cooter Brown's, thought they may be a little cleaner here at Luke. Can you tell I like oysters?...

I love the vibe at Luke with a long bar that's great for dining at as a couple. If you are a people watcher, then request the front. If you enjoy your privacy, the back is perfect and intimate. I recently sat in the back here with my boyfriend's family. I must say I experienced some serious entree envy (which duh, don't order an appetizer then) when my boyfriend's dad ordered the HUGE burger and fries, and I went with the Crab Maison. I do have qualms with the price tag on this petite Crab Maison when comparing with similar restaurants, and it wasn't as flavorful as I had hoped though the temperature was perfect and the bread that it came with was a nice crunchy texture to go with the meat. Size-wise though this IS an appetizer so be forewarned this is not an entree substitute which of those who got entrees are rightfully sized.  To fill my belly, I ordered a side of their jalapeño grits though it wasn't specifically on the menu (thanks!), and they are damn good. Perfectly creamy with a spicy kick. I will definitely have to try their shrimp and grits some time that they cook with these grits. 

Our waitress was attentive without being overbearing, and handled a neighboring situation of ornery guests very well without missing a beat with us. 

I'll definitely be back for Happy Hour at the bar sometime very soon!

Lüke was a nice find during my visit to New Orleans. 

The large dark wood bar takes up most of the restaurant. There are lower level tables off to the side. Every bit of usable space is maximized, so the tables are a little close together. The noise level can get loud, but the energy in the room adds to the vibe of the restaurant.

While there was no separate gluten free menu, there are several dishes that can be modified to be gluten free.The Washington Parish Roasted Chicken served during lunch is an extremely large portion and cooked well. It was juicy throughout and the potatoes added to the heartiness of the dish.

The service was friendly. I do have to commend the server for being extremely helpful and patient when I continued to question about the cooking practices, i.e. sauces, pan fried vs deep fried, etc. If he wasn't sure, he went back and verified with the kitchen rather than just making up an answer on the spot. This alone goes along way in my book.

Old school decor - dark woods and copper tile ceiling (real?)  I was there for the express lunch, a good deal.  You get a choice of soup with the entree of the day.  The gumbo and crab bisque were spot on. Gumbo - rich with the andouille sausage adding just a bit of heat. Crab bisque - flavored with old bay style seasoning but not overly salty and just a bit of shredded crab. The entree was a garganelli with roast pork ragu, mushrooms and creole tomatoes.  The sauce was light and blended the flavors well.  The roast pork highlighted the dish - fork tender, caramelized and left me wanting more.
Was visiting NoLa and happy I came to Luke everything was awesome!!! Great seafood, definitely a must when in NoLa

I had high expectations because Chef John Besh goes on Top Chef and gets to critique promising chefs, but I don't think his dishes at Luke would have succeeded on the show. 

For reference, we were a well dressed, party of 8 with reservations made two weeks in advance. 

Pro:
-Rabbit/Chicken Pate: It was a delicious pate that was served with mustard seeds, pickled watermelon, jalapeño/rasberry (i think) jam. Great flavors.
-Mint Julep cocktail has fresh and tasted nice

Cons:
-I ordered the second most expensive entree (Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "en Cocotte" aka shrimp and grits) and was looking forward to a flavor explosion. It was served in a cast-ion casserole dish with a broken handle. I also noticed the portion looked small and like it was shoved to the right side of the dish (I compared it to the same entree that someone at my table was served. It looked like half the portion my friend received). There were also french fries in my entree, which didn't come with my dish, it just fell from other dish on the server's tray onto my dish. The server asked if everything looked good and I responded "No, my dish has a broken handle, my portion looks half of what someone else got, and I got french fries in my dish that don't belong in the entree". If this was a Chili's or some burger restaurant, no big deal, extra french fries, but I didn't know Chef John Besh was looking to create an upscale Popeye's. 
-Three of my friends ordered the grilled ribeye at different temperatures, but none were accurately served at the request temperature. The meats were not cooked consistently at the same temperature all the way through. Someone ordered medium, but the center of the ribeye was rare. 
-The service was really lackluster. The manager never came by to apologize about the shoddy plate they put in front of me.
-The bathroom was actually in the Hilton and it was messy. I don't know about y'all, but if I'm in a nice restaurant, the bathroom also has to be well-kept.
-It was my birthday dinner and my friends told the restaurant so they brought me out a dessert, but it said "Congratulations". I'm not sure what they meant by that. Congratulations you turned 30? It was just odd like they weren't paying attention and someone in the back was like "Oh, there's some occasion at that table. Write 'Congratulations' instead of asking what the occasion was". It just an example of lack of attention to detail from the famous Chef John Besh. 

The more I write this review, the more annoyed I am that our group dropped all that money at this "nice" restaurant which was basically a glorified Red Lobster.

I can only speak for their shrimp and grits as that's all I tried but it was extremely delicious. The shrimp are plump and sweet and the grits are intensely packed with flavor to compliment their seafood partner.

Came here for lunch.

Pros: Great food, well prepared, fresh and full of flavor. The bread pudding and Fresh fish were beyond expectation. The bread pudding is just moist enough to be both soft and of good texture. The fish though was just listed as fresh fish on the menu but it came with a bed of nicely cooked vegetables (carrots, reddish, long beans squash and etc) with pesto underneath the pan "fried" fish. The service is good, though not the best I have seen. 

Cons: if I'm being picky, the table cloth is kinda wrinkled and a bit old. Also, the chair is so light that when my group were leaving, two of our chairs fell back to the floor due the weight of the coat alone and our coats were pushed right on the floor by the falling chair :(. Fortunately there weren't a toddler behind or many people around. (So be careful!).

Amazing seafood, service, and authentic Cajun cuisine. A bit pricey but worth it for the fresh quality of the food. Right next to the hilton French quarter and they have an amazing happy hour most afternoons from 4-6pm .

Happy hour 3-6pm for 50 cent oysters. And indeedy, it's a happy day for my boyfriend and I. We immediately ordered three dozen oysters plus cocktails without wreaking havoc on our wallets! This is the GO TO spot if you love oysters and cocktails for a steal. 

Lüke, we will be back!

Got a burger from here abd it was awesome,  the fries were delicious as well and for take out it was pretty quick!  I also tried the oysters salad thing and let me tell you why that'd have me in a coma!  They're so delicious!

Lovely atmosphere and great food steps from the French Quarter. Price per person is on the top end of yelp's $$  range. Our table enjoyed the seasonal champagne cocktails, the fried oyster salad, the shrimp & jalapeño grits with added crab, a pasta dish, and the crab bisque. Was able to cater to a Celiac / Gluten-Free diner with ease.

Had breakfast.  Average french press coffee, wife got yogurt and granola which was overpriced for $12. I got the egg white fritata which was excellent.  Overall I would want to come back but restaurant was average on this visit.

This restaurant is on the higher end of $$, but has the service and food to justify the price. I was surprised to see Matzoh Ball soup on their menu along the crab bisque and lobster bisque that I expected to find. I had a bowl of the crab bisque for lunch, which came with a piece of french baguette and butter. It was a lovely lunch, and I would do it again.

Love their happy hour raw oysters, 0.75 each. I like mix the radish and catch up sauce together. As for drink, I get Their French 75 every time, and it is really tasty. I am not a big fan of their fried oyster. 
I like to sit at the bar area, but it gets packed quickly around 3:45. It could slow down the service.

My hubby and I ate here on Christmas Day when it seemed almost impossible to get a table at a hip restaurant in NOLA. We lucked out with our early 5:00 dinner reservations it was still happy hour where the wonderful plump oysters were on .75 cents each.  We ordered one dozen and promptly ordered another.  We could not get enough so we went back the next day during happy hour where we wanted to sit at the bar but the bar seemed to be the most popular spot with all full chairs and three people deep standing behind them.  I would definitely go back as the menu was limited because of Revilion but we thoroughly enjoyed our fresh fish and shrimp and grits.  Lastly if you get lucky enough to sit adjacent to the kitchen you won't be disappointed viewing the food being prepared.  The place is also much larger than it appears.

It was my first time visiting Nola!! This place came highly recommend for my local friends. So of course we had to find out for our selfs. It was a 5 min walk from the hotel which was nice. The atmosphere was very nice and welcoming we ordered the p and j oysters. We didn't pay close to the what the menu said and how they were prepared. But when they arrived they were green and delicious!! We both ordered sandwiches that were very tasty and filling. i recommend if you ever get a chance you should give it a shot!!

45 min wait for a table, for a Saturday lunch after Christmas, so we sat at the bar. The burger was built around a generous and juicy charbroiled patty. The fried oyster salad featured large chunks of fatty artisinal bacon and was equally tasty, though the dressing was uninspiring.

The food was amazing. The fire alarm (which went off three times during our meal) was really horrible. That's something that should be fixed immediately. If I was with my parents, we probably would've walked out. The service was also fantastic, our waiter was great.

That said, I had one of the most delicious steaks of my life. This is one of those places that is the sweet spot for food/price. Most everything is between $15-30 and is almost as delicious as much more expensive restaurants. The appetizers and desserts were also fantastic.
One of the only places open for Christmas Day brunch... Absolutely amazing! You have to try the crispy brussel sprouts and shrimp and grits.
Oysters here were so good, as was the bread pudding. Atmosphere is relaxed and inviting.

Best meal in NOLA! !
First the service was spectacular starting with the hostess when we called to get the only remaining reservation on 12/26. 
The Happy Hour Specials are the best in the City. 
We started with fresh oysters, fried oysters and build shrimp with several rounds of drinks 

The seafood was soooooo fresh! 

Back to the service two words:
KYLE & KENNY!  
They were so cute and friendly,  they gave us just enough attention and made fantastic recommendations.

Tip: get a table in the back to watch the kitchen!  

On the rest of the meal... we has the crab bisque which was fantastic.  The bread was fresh with a really great butter.

The shrimp and grits were out of this world!  
The Roasted Veggies Were Amazing#
The wild boar ragout was the the best pasta dish I have ever tasted.

Luke is my new favorite restaurant of all time. 
 Tip: make a reservation and go now!!!

The Happy Hour is an absolute must for oysters lovers! HH is Mon - Fri 3 pm to 6 pm. $0.75 per fresh oyster is hard to beat. The oysters are of a very good size and are fresh. All the drinks are half off!!! The drinks are really good! The bar is small though and gets crowded very fast. Please note that HH is at the bar area only. Service was alright, but they were crazy busy.

This review is for the happy hour only. We got off to a rocky start - only one seat at the bar, and the not very helpful hostess insisted that all of the tables were reserved. The entire time we were there no one ever sat down at the five empty tables and the place emptied out even more. 

Luckily the bartender and oyster shucking guy were very nice and we soon forgot about the awkward start. The fried oysters were ok but the raw oysters were delicious! We kept ordering more and more rounds of oysters. The local p&j oysters are sweet and a good size. I was told they go through about 1500 oysters a day! They also have a good selection of beers on tap.

Being a first timer in New Orleans, this place was high on the list of things to try. Unfortunately, it did not meet expectations. 

Our waitress was rude and acted like we were dumb each time we asked a question about the menu. We also had trouble getting her to take our order in the first place. The bread was hard and tasteless. You could get better day old bread from Jimmy Johns. 

We ordered the oysters. They had a funny taste to them, yet being hungry, we ate it anyway. Later on that night I had a bad reaction from them (I am not allergic, something was just off about them). 

Do not recommend.

From the start to the end, the dinner was a great experience. We arrived at our reservation 20 mins early and was able to get a table no problem.

I thought the restaurant was a good looking restaurant that felt nicer but not too stuffy. The wood floors are gorgeous but could probably use a nice polish.

We had two servers who were both friendly and very easy going. We had a little help ordering a nice bottle of pinot gris to go with the seafood that we planned to ordered. 

Appetizers: The petite seafood platters was the perfect for us 3 ladies to split. The seafood was so incredibly fresh! We also ordered the fried oyster salad which was very good. Bacon and fried food is always a good combo.

Entrees: We ordered the mahi mahi with the crispy kale. The mahi was cooked perfect  and the citrus topping was a great touch. The kale was a bit over salted for me but the texture was great! We also ordered the Shrimp Cavatelli. This was definitely my favorite out of the two dishes. The pasta was perfect and the sauce was amazing. 

Dessert: Brandy Milk Punch to close off dinner and an amazing Steamed Chocolate cake which was rich and fudgy and warm and a perfect contracted to the coffee ice cream. 

Definitely one of my favorite meals in NO.
Great food, fresh oysters, and a helpful staff. I have only good things to say. Happy hour is great.
Great selection of German, French, Cajun cuisine. Excellent experience with hostess Alex. She was very welcoming, charming, and sweet! What a nice, young lady! Awesome experience and amazing food!

Came here for my last stop until I went back to Cali and it wasn't a bad choice. I've been reading that this place is to go for happy hour raw oysters. So come and check it out during those hours if you can. Other than that the food was good. We had the shrimp and grits and the Croque Madame with an egg. These were really good. Also you can have Sunday brunch without a Mimosa. Also try the Crab Bisque, very good as well. The only problem we had wit that was not ordering a bowl of it.

My wife and I love New Orleans and visit about once a year. We have our favorite restaurants but always try to sample a few new places as well. I have said before that its hard to find a bad meal in that town but Luke certainly provided for that this time. First off we showed up a little after 10 AM and was told the wait would be about 15 minutes, no big deal. We were seated within about 10 and the place looked fine. Well the hipster waiter that came over seemed to be in another world but did eventually convey to me that the listed breakfast menu on line was not available and we could only order from the brunch menu. I found this very odd and completely limiting at 10:20 AM on a Sunday morning. The brunch menu is very small and heavy on the seafood and nothing there sounded appetizing. I was going to just pass and have coffee while my wife ate but she insisted I order something. So I told our odd waiter that since I couldn't order any of the delicious sounding biscuit sandwiches or other "Breakfast" fair I would just have a hamburger. Well it took awhile but when it finally came it seemed the server had a real problem as to where to put things down on the table, I even joked that they hadn't really worked the whole "table thing" out yet. Well, the burger was messy and cold so after about 4 bites I just gave up. My wife also just ate her grits stating the shrimp tasted odd, and not good.  Now, as I looked around the room at people seated after us I noticed tables that had menus that looked much larger than our brunch menu and I saw plates with things like sausage and eggs on them. I was going to ask why I couldn't have ordered something like that but at that point I just wanted out of there. Now as if this meal wasn't weird enough the waiter came back to the table and insisted on shaking my hand as some sort of apology for how bad the whole experience was I guess. Anyway, we went around the corner and down the street to a small cafe and I had a delicious biscuit smothered in sausage gravy.  I would suggest that unless you enjoy the bizarre to forget about Luke  and try any of the many other places in the CBD

We came here on Sunday 12/14 around 7:30 to celebrate an anniversary. As soon as we sat down, the servers came over to wish us a Happy Anniversary and made us feel welcome. They also served us a champagne toast (we were so grateful!) and not only did they give us well wishes upon arrival, the servers kept checking in, gave recommendations prior to ordering, and when we left, were consistently friendly and smiling. We ordered the following appetizers: baked P&J oysters (6 in an order- they were good but I think we normally prefer them raw - we just wanted to try them since we're from out-of-town); the gumbo (tasty, so much flavor, not overly salty); the small raw seafood platter (Le Petit Plateau de Fruits de Mer) which came with raw clams, raw oysters, a squid/calamari ceviche/antipasto tasting, cooked mussels, and shrimp (if I recall correctly), and we added a half order of the jumbo king crab legs. The seafood platter was good (a good amount for 2 people if you want to try other appetizers). For the main course, I had the grilled louisiana mahi which came with kale chips at the time. The fish was fine (not overly fishy) but perhaps a bit overcooked, and the kale was too salty (felt like you were sticking your tongue in sea salt). My boyfriend ordered the Luke Burger medium rare but it came out medium well-- we didn't want to bother the servers since they were so great but the gumbo was probably the best dish that night. You can't be the service here, I would come back again!

I came to Lüke for dinner late one night and really enjoyed my meal! It may have been because I had really low expectations after reading several negative reviews about the service here. 

My sister called ahead to see if there was a wait and the person said that the restaurant was busy and that they had reservations coming in throughout the night. My sister checked OpenTable though and was able to make a reservation for four a few minutes after she called. We walked into the restaurant and there were several empty tables so we were confused. While we were waiting to be seated, a couple at the table next to the area we were waiting in left without ordering so I got worried. I was debating whether or not to go to a different restaurant when our table became available. 

I would recommend sitting in the back near the kitchen if possible because I loved the atmosphere! It felt like an entirely different restaurant back there. The kitchen is entirely surrounded by glass so you can watch the chefs prepare your food. Our server was friendly and attentive. We started off our meal with Flamenkuche, Baked Oysters and complimentary Garlic Bread. My mom and I shared the Shrimp and Grits and Steak Frites. I loved everything!

I love this place. It was first place I ate at when I was in New Orleans. The food and service were incredible. I had the  grits and shrimp which were each flavored deliciously. I also had the rosemary  and champagne  drink.

There is not too much more to say but what an outstanding  place. Happy to give 5 stars.

Cons: bad service: 1-host kept us waiting for 10 minutes, although a 4 tables were empty and not reserved. 
2- server was really bad. We asked him about his favorite appetizer and he gave us every item on the menu. He was very slow and unhappy. We didn't get refills fast enough.
3- tables are very close to each other

Pros: food is simply great. Everything we ordered looked and tasted fresh and delicious. I ordered French 75 drink and it was really good.

Excellent experience! Had some bad customer service talking to other top restaurants in the quarter. Luckily got an opening at Luke's and the food and service was fantastic! Our waiter was great but another waiter "Richie rich" stopped by and was Awesome! Ask for Richie rich :) !!!

My fiancée and I ate here in August per a recommendation from our hotel and ever since we have been dying to get back to NOLA to eat at Luke. I think their etouffee was the single best dish I had in NOLA. Great atmosphere and definitely lived up to the "John Besh" hype.  Excited to try again this weekend for NYE. Try and ask for Richie as your server. He is the best!

Fun time for happy hour though they raised the price to 75 cents for oysters. A little too busy for my taste. Waitress was pretty terrible. Never brought us bread, no oyster forks, would walk right by our table without refilling water or asking if we wanted more drinks. Got 4 dozen oysters total and wait was not bad. Oysters were fresh, tasty, and meaty. Ordered an extra spicy bloody Mary and it was not spicy but extra bitter so not really sure what they did

This was, hands down, one of our top meals ever. Our waiter, Richard, obviously enjoyed his job and really set the tone for the evening. His suggestions of the Louisiana Shrimp and Ribeye entrees were spot on. He's one of those waiters you let pick your meal for you- he just gets it.
We ended the evening with the Creme Brûlée and it was AMAZING.

Service was awful! Food was probably good but because the waiter served it cold we were unimpressed. Unfortunately the fella that served our table was training a new waiter so don't expect the service to improve. We had to ask who our waiter was after 15 minutes with no service. We weren't offered bread that other tables had. SIL asked for his beer to be served with his meal and it didn't come until he has finished his meal. 
On the positive side the crab bisque was nice and hot and delicious.

Lüke, what can I say that hasn't already been said.
Yes, it has the cache and expectation level of a John Besh restaurant.
And in my opinion, it meets and exceeds them on every level.
The P&J Oysters are of course, a sublime treat.
When I went there with my bride on our Honeymoon, they were 25cents now I hear they are 50 cents..
But still not to be missed.
Look, you know Besh will never steer you wrong and you will not leave there disappointed.
Give it a try, and let me know what you think..
Big Easy Daddy..

Had lunch here on December 13 with my very picky parents!  Everyone loved it!  Outstanding baked oysters with herbsaint, lobster bisque, and caramelized onion and pork belly flatbread.  Shrimp and grits, one of the best in the city, pork sandwich and croque Monsieur were yummy.  Great wine by the glass and dining in front of the kitchen was delightful.  We love Luke!  Living in the quarter makes it tough when it comes to dining in other neighborhoods.  We love to walk to the numerous great eats around us but Luke is worth the "effort" to grab a cab and go across town.

We were happy to discover Luke thanks to the concierge at the Hilton that recommended it. We were hesitant to try it since it was adjacent to the hotel. Shame on us. We quickly discovered that celebrate chef John Besh ran the place and it truly was hopping. Our first visit was for happy hour shortly after we landed in New Orleans. Half price oysters and drinks, you can't go wrong. We quickly reordered another dozen as they were fresh and the sauces ere great. The sazerac was delicious.They have a nice wine and beer list too. We didn't originally order the fries but the table next to us were enjoying them and they looked so good, we had to try. We weren't disappointed. We liked Luke so much that we went back for Christmas day brunch. Equally good. Note that you really need a reservation at any time of the day. It's always busy. They say that you can wait and sit at the bar but it's packed too. If you call and they say that they are fully booked, try opentable, it seems like there are tables hidden away and available.

This place is hip.  Perhaps too hip for many over 35 but if you can tolerate the boisterous and extremely casually attired youth--I haven't worn a suit in 20 years either but even 20 year olds should have something besides skinny jeans and T-shirts with borderline obscene slogans in their closets--the food is worth it and the staff copes well.   

I had a 6:00 reservation (obtained the day before) but the sky seemed threatening a downpour so I came early to avoid it and was seated 20 minutes or so before the appointed time.  I often don't even make reservations and have no trouble getting seated at popular places by being there when they open or, for those open all day, coming before the popular dinner hour, but that didn't work the day before at Lüke.  Even at 4:30 the place was packed so I did make one for the following day.

My meal started with the crispy Brussel Sprouts.  Even if you hate Brussels sprouts (I like them), don't be afraid to try this dish--if no one told you you might not know what you were eating.  They are in some sort of sweet/sour sauce/dressing and fried both slightly blackened and crispy as advertised . . . tossed with almond slices, small bits of jalapeño and sprinkled with shavings of cheese on top.

Then I had pork schnitzel and "pommes frites" (that's shoestring fries to the Galliphobes).  It came with whitish gravy in a pitcher, I suppose to make it "Southern".  The gravy was good but I skipped eating it, doing that the usual way with a squeeze of lemon.  It was excellent and the fries were fine too.

I finished with some excellent decaf and a glass of Kahlua--I had had iced tea with the meal so some alcohol was not an excess.

A lady who was some sort of hostess dropped by my table while I was eating to make sure everything was OK and when told I needed ketchup (for the fries), went and got me some (in a dainty little single-serve Heinz bottle).  My waiter also checked several times but didn't hover.

I am giving it 4 stars.  The 5th star is withheld because of the crowded dining room and noise level . . . nothing to do with the food which I greatly enjoyed.

I had reservations for two at 6:30 and I was seated right away within two minutes. The atmosphere of this place was nice but that's where most the good stops. 

I honestly don't understand how this restaurant got such high reviews. Either people had low expectations or they entered here drunk from an adventure at bourbon st or Frenchmen.

I ordered a river bend and it was made absolutely horrible. It tasted like medicine or as if the vodka was randomly thrown in grape juice and ass. 

I ordered a charcuterie board, little neck clams, oysters, Brussel sprouts, and the shrimp grits. The charcuterie board and Brussel sprouts were amAzing. The Brussel sprouts had a seared and sweet vinaigrette flavor. Even though I really prefer the charcuterie sampler at cochon butcher over the charcuterie here it was still good. It came with a rabbit pate which was wonderful.

As we waited for our clams to come out, the server came to notify us that they were out of clams (thirty minutes later btw). So we ordered a half dozen oysters instead. Those came out within five minutes. However instead of getting a half dozen oysters, we ended up receiving only five oysters on our plate. WTF?!?! We notified our server and he ended up bringing us two additional oysters which was nice, but seriously?! How does a restaurant like this hire people that don't know the basics of counting? That right there made me question the quality of the restaurant and how overhyped this was due to john besh. The oysters were shucked wonderfully but that's really all I can give them credit for.

Anyways, we finished all of our appetizers and waited an incredibly long time for the shrimp and grits. After waiting too long, we canceled our order with another waitress and our server finally came out to tell us that our order was ready but he wanted to wait for us to finish our appetizers to bring out the plate. I don't know of any restaurant that would make you wait an hour for your entree but sure... When the shrimp and grits came out I was honestly disappointed. 

I'm sorry to say but this restaurant may be nice but it absolutely does not deserve to be a four star restaurant. If you want good prices, good taste, and service I would go to royal house instead. Otherwise Ya no..... I would never go back here again nor recommend this place to someone else... I am so sad that this place was such a disappointment. Thanks John besh. Left the place hungry. :(

We had New Year's Eve dinner at Lüke. Two of our party of three ordered the 4-course set menu.  The waiter skipped the second course entirely, and then said it wasn't a course at all when we pointed this out.  We sought clarification and the waiter was indeed wrong and did not understand the set menu.  Another waiter stepped in, offered to serve the second course after the third, and to give us complimentary champagne, more wine, money off our check, and extra food.  

The solution was not ideal - the order of dishes was off, we did not really want the extras, and the "champagne" was horrid, but it was New Year's Eve and we wanted a pleasant evening, so said fine.  Most of the dishes were excellent. However, our final tab did not show the promised deduction.  

Overall, a bit of a disappointment.
With local chef John Besh at the helm of this  awesome place you can't go wrong with raw oysters for happy hour.
Besh has done it again. A beautiful blend of fancy foods and a French menu with a casual feel and very affordable prices. The shrimp and grits are to die for.

Really awesome, oysters were super fresh, well shucked, good size and variety. 
Wine was excellent, good selection but nothing too extensive or bamboozling, just a careful choice of old and new world - they have been chosen well! 
The pate was incredible, I spent an hour just grazing.....seriously yum. 

I would have given this place 5 stars but tv with football screening makes me give it 4. Yes, harsh I know, but personal preference! 

They had been really busy over the holidays so I think the staff were a little beat but they were still great, friendly and nice, only tip would be if they had more knowledge of the seafood especially, they couldn't tell me the different oysters but whatever, still a great experience.

It's a beautiful place with very good services, and it's cross street from our hotel (intercontinental). I picked it to have brunch based on the good reviews and it's so close. It took about 15 minutes to sit at our table with reservation. I saw people just couldn't wait any longer and just left. So if you decide to try it, MAKE RESERVATION. 
As for the food, it's okay. I had the shrimp grits (a little salty for my taste) and the rabbit/chicken liver. They are not bad, nothing special either. 
I did enjoy the clean table cloth and attentive service for a change (since most of the restaurants in New Orleans are situated in old-dirty buildings with minimum service).
When I was there, everyone around me ordered burger,fries,or po-boy. I would suggest you go else where for more authentic local cuicine.

First meal in NOLA .. Went here cause it was the highest rated place that was open and in walking distance to the hotel.. The Brussels sprouts were awesome.. Definitely get these..  Ordered the shrimp n grits and crab bisque.  Very heavy on the salt.. Overwhelmed the delicate shrimp and crab flavor..  Ordered the Baked oyster .. It had a nice herb flavored in the crust but was over powered by the concentration of butter ..  Yeah, its New Orleans, yeah the food is supposed to be rich and decadent...  But our plates were a bit much..

John Besh fan here... and I think Luke's has one of the best burgers in town. I was working on the weekend and stopped here for lunch. I didn't have a reservation and the place was packed. I was able to grab a seat at the bar  and their staff was very attentive. I don't know if I'd spend $16 on the burger again unless it was a special occasion. Though I also think I need to go back here again for dinner and try other things and I'm sure it'll get it a 5/5 rating then. The building is really cool and interesting, with an old time, rustic feel. I guess the one knock I would have is for all my vegetarian friends out there as their entree options are slim for y'all.

The service is impeccable. The servers are in what I can only describe as white butler jackets and I had no less than 5 people waiting on me. Each smiling and friendly and making it seem (to me at least) that their only goal on earth was to make me happy. And then there is the food. The menu is different and unexpected (if you aren't doing the "oh, I'll just have a raw bar meal" kind of thing - not that there's anything wrong with that). If you aren't careful, you can work through your appetizer (I recommend the beet salad for flavors you can't duplicate) and your mini personal loaf of bread with whipped butter and then struggle through the large portioned, rich and overwhelming (in the best possible way) entree. You must save room for dessert (bread pudding with a sauce that could cause cardiac arrest) and then just call it a day - go home and go to bed and revel in the adventure you just experienced. Expect it to be pricy and don't expect a "normal" menu and don't be fooled that it's connected to a hotel. It loud and lively and worth the trip.

The food is great!!!!  Only reason for the 4 stars!  Deal with the room service through the hotel and its a joke.  It's terrible to give a bad review of the food so I can't do that!  It was great, but when we called back down for a few things missing the girl on the phone was extremely rude.  I'm sorry we did not ask for silverware or bread with our dinner.  The place is great just wish I could rate the room service a zero!

Would definitely come back to try more and more. From the buttery bisque to the buzzing atmosphere I then tried the much acclaimed baked oysters.  Although my palate prefers the raw and ripe, these are worth the try!

4.5 Stars

We came in on a Monday night around 4PM for the oyster happy hour and were surprised that the wait to be seated was a little less than two hours. I guess we should have done a little more research and made reservations, but it was a spontaneous decision, so it was what it was. Once, we were seated, we ordered:

Baked Oysters: A must must get. They were phenomenal. I don't even know how to describe the flavor. It was just really tasty.

Raw Oysters: Fresh and good. And they're really big in size here compared to all the other places I've been to for raw oysters outside of NOLA. And at $0.75 per oyster? Couldn't get any better.

Gumbo: I'm not usually a fan of gumbo and I wouldn't order it ever, but had to try it here after hearing the next table over raving about it with the waitress. I wasn't disappointed. Not too salty and the overall taste is clean and flavorful.

They have a happy hour where oysters are special price.  I went with high expectations but it was just okay.  My food wasn't seasoned enough and lot of it tasted bland.  The fish was not crispy.  Too bad because it could've been really good.  Wish they salted the water more when the potatoes were boiled because no matter how much salt I put on them, they didn't stick and it just wasn't the same.  It was super busy as usual and I waited a long time to get my water refilled.  It was my last meal in NOLA and I almost wished I had gone to Cuchon Butcher :(

Awesome steak, burgers, shrimp and grits and the fresh oysters. 

Take note that come for happy hour weekdays (3-6) for 75 cent fresh oysters

Excellent breakfast. The grits were so creamy and good. We had the southern breakfast but after having the grits I wish I had the shrimp and grits breakfast.  Oh well next time!!!! The service was outstanding and friendly to boot!!!!

My friend went here for the oysters. They used to be $0.50 during happy hour, but I guess that was awhile back. Now it's $0.75. They weren't really big either. But then again, if you're coming during happy hour, they won't serve the better choices since it would be gone fast. We were here mainly for oysters, but my friend did order a side of fries. They were pretty good. Nothing too too special. They were thin and warm when it came out to us. There was also the complimentary bread that came out. I am unsure why there was no plate provided with it as it just sat causally on the tabletop. Lol. 

The service was attentive. The restaurant's atmosphere was one of a dimly lit bar scene. I guess this place is good for drinks and oysters during happy hour.

For the past few weeks, I've been craving the crab omelet.  Went in once but there weren't any seats at the bar and no open tables with a 30 minute wait.  Went back a few weeks later and was able to get a table.  Unfortunately, I was really disappointed that the menu changed and the crab omelet wasn't even on the menu.  I double checked to see if they could make it but they couldn't.  :(  I wish I could get an email reminder when they add it back to the menu. lol  

I ended up getting the crab bisque and fries.  The bisque was was flavorful.  The fries were good as always.  (I knew the bisque wouldn't be enough alone but didn't see anything else that really stuck out to me...probably because I really wanted that omelet.)

Nice waitstaff.  Pretty fast and acknowledged us.  I'll be back again though because I really like this place.  Hopefully my favorite dish will be on the menu again. :)

This is a popular restaurant, so I won't try to add on anything that hasn't been covered already. The reason I am writing this review, though, is to throw some wind into their sails since their service on Christmas Day was outstanding.

Place was packed, kitchen got a little behind, and servers were scrambling. Food finally came out, was delicious, and at the conclusion management came by and personally apologized for the wait. I love to see this level of concern for the guest experience, and would happily return to experience it again.
Can't say enough good things about this place. Great drinks, affordable oysters, fantastic atmosphere. Classy atmosphere without pretension.

We went there around 9 pm on Saturday without reservation. We stopped at this restaurant on the way back to our hotel. I ordered seafood gumbo, which was tasty, maybe a bit salty, and it didn't have any seafood in it except some shrimp. The service was awful. Once we were seated, nobody came to our table except taking our order and delivering out food. Other tables were getting all the attentions. I don't know whether we didn't order expensive food, or we arrived late, or we dressed casually. But we were complete ignored. I can see that their food is good, but I don't think I want to come back to this place again.

Good food. Mediocre service: ask about specials ( before 6 pm), they may not tell you, ask them to repeat your order, because they may forget about some of it. Ask them to repeat details ( if you want to make some changes to your meal), because they may not be able to remember. Produce is fresh. I can't tell you about my fish order, sorry, they just forgot about it.

4 stars for happy hour.  3.5 stars for the regular fare.

we came with a party of 8 for happy hour.  easy to make reservations online, which i suggest you do, because it was really packed when we got there and that was at 5pm.  raw oysters are 75 cents each and fried oysters are $1.25 each.  specialty cocktails, beer and wine are half off.  good deals all around.

we got some brussel sprout and fries for appetizers.  good, but not great.  and for entrees, the shrimp cavatelli and the wild boar ragout.  again, good, but not great.  

our waiter was super nice and accommodating... even separated our checks for us.  that's a nice touch.

overall, come for oysters during happy hour :)

Everything here was amazing.  We got there before 6 and found out there were 75 cent oysters and half priced glasses of wine. And it kept getting better.  Amazing tuna nicoise tartine and rabbit/duck pate.  Incredible Brussels sprouts and cheese burger.  Great service too.

It was our first time, and we had NO IDEA that it was a "betta have a reservation" place! But, Deirdre, who we found out later was the manager, found us a table for FOUR! She, Kevin, & ALL the servers were FANTABULOUS!! We had SOO much fun pickin appetizers & drinks & the place was just buzzin with HAPPY! The food was AWESOME, even tho we'd never had many things on the menu, like Crispy Brussel Sprouts, Yellow Beet salad, & Pate'! The stuff we were used to like raw/fried/baked oysters, & crisped french baguette sliced was PERFECT! Oyster ACTUALLY tasted like OYSTERS...even the FRIED ones (they & the raw ones are part of Happy Hour fare, along with half priced cocktails & wine)! I kno this is LONG but it's worth EVERY WORD! I'd recommend this place to EVERYONE, from locals to tourists! THANK U guys for makin us feel SOO at home!

The service is slow (in a good, southern kinda way y'all) and the concierge had a bit of an attitude. That being said, our last day there a server named Kevin listened to our need to be done and out of the door by 5 to be at a wedding in the French Quarter. He accommodated all 6 of us amazingly and made every dish arrive and had us ready to go in less than 45 minutes. Amazing. Then he made sure we wouldn't forget him by gifting us a complimentary dessert (whoa...that brownie had us fighting to lick the plate) 

Great recovery by a wonderful server. The food is always excellent, you just might want to be really clear with your service expectations.

All I an say is "Brussel sprouts" you have to try this unique preparation. Who would have thought this pairing of sprouts and jalapeños could be so delicious?  Tired of seafood in NOLA - get the burger, I promised you will be entirely satisfied!

My goodness what an absolutely terrible experience! 

We came to New Orleans for New Years with a bunch of my well-traveled, well-brunched friends. We picked Luke because of the great reviews for brunch. We got a reservation at 10:45AM for 8 people.

We were seated in the back room by the kitchen, kind of in a long booth n the corner. Our server was not warm or welcoming. She took our initial drink order - one bloody Mary and a bottle of champagne for the table with a glass of orange juice (as they did not have any specials for mimosas, apparently). 25 minutes later... only the bloody Mary had arrived. 35 minutes into our visit, a man shows up to the table with one glass of champagne. Ugh.

We eventually got the champagne debacle sorted out and began enjoying our brunch drinks 45 minutes after we arrived. We ordered food - the lobster bisque is fantastic. I ordered the croquet madame. The presentation is awe-inspiring, but the taste and overall "eatablity" of the dish is not great. The cheese on top is overwhelming and makes the whole sandwich very soggy. i wish I had ordered something else.

The brussel sprouts were very good.

By the end of the meal, we had only seen our waitress maybe one additional time to order a second bottle of champagne. We even tried asking other servers and a manager for assistance or to find out where she was. 

The waitress struggled for an additional 30 minutes after we wanted to check out to split the check into 4 couples. Our checks were all incorrect. As a group, we decided to just pay and then settle up later due to the amount of time it was taking to get through this meal. After putting our credit cards in the payment slots, it was still another 10 minutes for her to pick them up, and an additional 10 to get her to run them. The whole meal took about 2.5 hours - was kind of expensive, and we had absolutely terrible service. I won't be suggesting this place to anyone traveling to Nola!

This is a cute little restaurant/bar within a hotel. We came here for the Saturday from (11am - 4pm). 

Service: 
- We were immediately greeted by a friendly hostess
- We didn't have to wait long to be seated 
- the service was a slow (perhaps they're understaffed?) 

Food: 
- Delicious seafood gumbo - it's a rich dish with a variety of seafood, the rue was not too thick but not too viscous, flavorful, but I would give it 4/5 stars because it was smaller than I expected it to be 

- Baked oysters - I usually don't eat oysters, but these were AMAZING! It was coated with a pesto coat and the "taste of the sea" was not overpowering 5/5 stars

- Jalapeno grits - it's a signature side in the south, but jalapenos?!?! Brilliant! The jalapenos added a nice kick to the cheesy grits and my taste buds were rather pleased 4/5 stars

- Croque Monsieur (without an egg) and Croque Madame (with an organic egg on top) - grilled chisesi ham & emmenthaler cheese sandwich with house-made fries - it was a little too heavy of a sandwich, so it's good for sharing, they're generous with the portions 3/5 stars

Ambiance: 
-casual setting
- there are tables as well as bar seating 
- it has a creole decor theme (especially at the bar)

Wow. I am all the way late on this one. I told y'all I hadn't been to New Orleans in 10+ years. It seems as though I am the very last person to have heard of and eaten at Lüke. #fixed

My experience at Lüke reminded me of why, even after that damned storm, New Orleans is the center of American culinary awesomeness. It just can't be helped. When I lived here, no matter if I was at a shack or an upscale, coat-only establishment, I don't think I ever had a bad meal. Ever. I'm serious. Lüke keeps the streak going. 

I came here to meet and upon recommendation from my mentor. Yes, I have one. You should as well. This fellow set me on way wrt career choices, timing and strategy and it had been far too long since I'd seen him. Plus, he has fantastic taste in food/drink. We sat and were immediately greeted by that warm, chewy bread (with butter) I'd missed for so many years (yet instantly remembered once I smelled it). To my surprise, neither my mentor nor I wanted a drink. Where was I and who was I? No drink at lunch... in New Orleans? Something was amiss. I think I wanted to stay fully present in the conversation and meal. I stuck with my tonic and lime and availed myself of the $17 express lunch of the day. For less than $20, you get a cup of soup and the entree of the day. Being that it was Thursday, that meant my choice was the jambalaya. Done.

In no time, I was slurping on a bowl of hot, spicy, filling, decadent crab bisque. OMG. I'd missed eating like this. Eating is such a joy/(first world/privileged, I recognize) pleasure. To eat food that make your endorphins light up and mouth sing... it's a blessing. It is. The sweet crab meat was the star of the bowl. Not to be hidden amongst heavy cream, the shellfish was up front and present in every spoonful. I was feeling a wee bit full when my large plate of jambalaya arrived. The description said something about green onion sausage and andouille cracklin'. I dunno. All I know is as soon as the smell hit my noise, I couldn't get it in my mouth fast enough. Wait. I lie. I took a bite. Then took a bite of the corn bread. Then I crumbled the corn bread into the dish. Then I topped everything with a metric ton of hot sauce. THEN I put it in my mouth as fast as I could.

Our waiter was pleasant, accustomed to the lunch crowd and delivered the type of service that I remembered, service that helped make New Orleans restaurants famous. Bellies protruding and mouths achy from laughter, my mentor and I bid farewell to Lüke and got on with the business of the day. I was not even four hours into being back in The Big Easy and I didn't want to leave. A good meal and good conversation will do that to/for you.

What a disappointment.

We went on Christmas evening and ordered off of the shortened menu. Our oysters and cocktails came quickly and were fantastic. And then we went another 45 minutes without seeing our server again.

Eventually someone noticed we were sitting their hungry and unhappy. This was not our mysterious server. She comped up another round of drinks and sent over an appetizer neither of was interested in, and then our food finally arrived. I understand that the kitchen can get backed up, especially if you're short staffed due to a holiday, but you've got to keep the customer in the loop. Not just ignore them and hope for the best.

Now to our food. I actually enjoyed my shrimp and grits at the time, but with the hindsight of waking up the next morning with my mouth still tasting of salt I'm not sure I'd recommend it. Her pasta was over cooked and overtly sweet with tiny unappealing shrimp compared to the big tasty jumbos on my plate. She barely ate it.

If this were any other night, and every other restaurant in town wasn't either booked up or closed, we would have told them to bring us the bill instead of the mains, paid for our drinks and oysters, and left to find dinner elsewhere. Instead we were stuck. 

Even with the comped drinks and app, this was the most expensive meal we had in New Orleans. it was also the worst. And that's a shame.

W.T.F.

This place was a disaster from the first minute, when we walked in the door to be met by an apparent hostess with a spray bottle in her hand (getting a jump on closing duties, presumably, despite it being more than 90 minutes till closing...) and a grimace. We informed her that we had reservations and she allowed us to sit. Thanks!

We sat at the bar. Our corner thereof was covered with sticky dried oyster leavins, like, nasty. The bar guy took our order and we asked for maybe a wipe-down. He gave it a quick swipe with a DRY towel, explaining "This is where people eat a lot of oysters." Ah! Well, that explains it! If only people didn't eat here, it wouldn't be so nasty.

A little later another person came (maybe a floor manager or something?) and gave it another once-over with a DRY towel. Have these people been working in a bar more than a combined 4 minutes total? Anyway, the sticky oyster leavins were unaffected.

Unfazed, we ordered a dozen oysters. BOOM! Talk about quick service! Should be a plus, but what it means is that they took the thing out of a fridge. We saw it: a platter of already-shucked oysters, pulled out of the fridge. And the oysters were just what you'd expect under such circumstances: a bit dried out and rubbery (maybe the hostess could have spritzed them with her spray bottle?). Not what you're looking for in raw oysters.

We ate a couple, then asked for the bill. Total time elapsed: 10 minutes. Time to cut our losses and find something to eat.

To their credit, they noticed that we only ate a few of the oysters, so they took that off the bill. But seriously - for a fancy place with a great rep, what was going on this night?

The baked oysters are a must they are unbelievably wonderful.  It was one of my favorite dishes of our stay in Nola.  For our entrees I got the shrimp and grits and my husband had the hamburger.  Both we good and would order again.

lucky luke is always good, at happy hours time... a miracle
better than the vatican
Great restaurant but it's more expensive than noted on Yelp. Great shrimp and grits, great oysters, amazing soups and chowder too. But should be rated $$$.

Best happy hour deal ever! 75cent raw oysters and 1.25$ fried oysters with half price drinks.  My kid must have eaten two dozen by himself!  72 raw oysters and 12 fried with 3 drinks only 70 something $!!!  Make reservations since its a well known deal.

We arrived in New Orleans on Christmas night ,just before 8:00 pm -- the first time, we realized, we've ever landed at night -- and quickly (I've *never* seen so little traffic on I-10!) made it to our hotel, the Le Meridien.¹

We actually arrived at Lüke for dinner a bit early, in terms of our reservation, but it was Christmas night and being seated early wasn't a problem. Lüke, however, can itself have its share of problems .

-- The front room can be (and often is) on the loud side, so much so that as a party of five at a rectangular table, it became difficult to hear. This is, of course, systemic and doesn't change. (The back room is quieter.)

-- Bring Christmas night, I have to say both the kitchen and service were a bit "off," but only in terms of timing -- NOT in terms of food (see below). Certain things came out almost too quickly; other things seemed to take forever. For example, Lüke offered two types of oysters, and we ordered six of one, and a dozen of the other. The order of six came in a relatively timely fashion, but the 12 seemingly took forever, arriving long after the (cooked) appetizers were finished, and just before the entrées. It also took a (relatively) long time to get the wine we ordered to accompany our entrées. This, however, is more appropriately chalked up to Xmas night, rather than being "the norm" in our experience.

That said, the food was, as always, wonderful and delicious! The rabbit & chicken liver pate was silky smooth and satisfying; the brussels sprouts crispy and tasty; the crabmeat maison flavorful and tangy. The Drum was perfect, as were the shrimp & grits and the moules frites.

Lüke remains, for us, one of those places you can count on for good food and good drinks. It may not be our favorite place in New Orleans, but it always satisfies.
_______________
¹ Formerly the Hotel New Orleans, formerly the W Downtown -- I guess it depends upon what day of the week it is.

Wow where do I even begin?? Remember Spicoli from Fast Times at Ridgemont High? OK well that was basically our waiter, Rich. He was EFFIN HILARIOUS! We heard the following phrases during dinner:

"Wha wha?!"
"This shiz is going to be awesome!"
"Here are your vagtables."

There were so many other gems, but honestly I can't even remember. Regardless, we were there for a birthday and Rich went out of his way to make our experience special. We were giggling all night and his persona.

We had the onion tarte and brussel sprouts to share and I had the Grilled Mahi. Honestly the descriptions on the menu don't even serve the food justice. Mahi with caper butter? Sounds rather ordinary. But no that's where you'd be wrong. It was so good I actually wiped my clean, which I NEVER do. It was served with kale, but not regular kale salad. These were more like spiced kale chips. I was like HOW DO I MAKE THESE AT HOME??? I wanted a bag to take with me just so I could snack on them.

The birthday cake was a little piece of chocolatey heaven. I'm not sure what it was but it tasted like flourless chocolate cake with ice cream. It was super moist and dense. Not too bitter and not too sweet. 

When I go back to New Orleans, Luke's will definitely be on my go to list.

Came in with the BFF and did not have reservations. The hostess said the next reservation would be about a 30 min wait so we sat at the bar to watch the Greenbay vs. Seattle game since it's first come first serve. I was determined to eat here with all the great reviews about this place. 

The guy sitting at the end of the bar ordered the crispy chicken and it looked so good I wanted to get it. The BFF was craving a burger. The bartender/waiter guy Brian told us the Crispy chicken and the stuffed French Toast just came out on their menu this week so we decided to go with that. 

I tried to go the safe route and ordered the Stuffed French Toast. It was very delicious! Almost like a dessert! Not your average French toast though. It looked like 3 crispy breaded patties but stuffed with chocolate, almost like Nutella and had a berry sauce on top with lots of cream on the bottom. Omg, it was really good but a little too sweet that I needed to take a couple bites of the BFF's Crispy Chicken which I regret not ordering. He always gets what I wish I should have ordered. 

The Crispy Chicken was amazing! The biscuit was soft and sweet and the chicken and egg on top of it had so much flavor. Kind of reminded me of chicken and waffles sort of. But the downside was his chicken wasn't big enough. More biscuit than chicken. I should have ordered this! Slap myself for not going with my gut! 

Since we were at the bar we ordered a French 75 cocktail because it was a popular drink. Reminded me of a mimosa because it has champagne in it. It was really good! 

This was my last day for now being in N.O. on 1/18/15! Nice day to spend Sunday Brunch with my BFF! Good times!

Wonderful place for Sunday brunch.  We arrived at 10 AM just as brunch started.  Before that is a small breakfast menu.  The bloody Mary was great.  Nice and spicy just the way I like it.  My husband and I had the Croque Madame.  A really great choice.  The bread was nice and toasty covered with delicious ham and a smooth bechamel sauce with Emmental cheese covered with more bread and grilled with more cheese and bechamel on top.  Then a perfectly fried egg on top of that.  It was delicious.  It was served with a cup of very good fries.  The coffee is french press, so it will have a few grounds floating in it.  A very  good meal.  We had to walk down to the river afterwards before the drive back to Baton Rouge.  We will be back- it was that good.

Nice place. The service is very friendly & very fast. The best part of our meal was the chocolate pecan tart for dessert.

The food was okay. Not fabulous. And when we ordered we specifically requested our food not come immediately after our starters.. It did. Maybe we were too full to enjoy them, I don't know. But I feel strongly that when a request like that is made... It's not difficult to honor. I was disappointed. We had the Mahi & Wild Boar Ragout, again, average food. The kale with the Mahi was DELISH though.

75 not 50 cent oysters at happy hour. It was still my favorite food experience during my short visit to NO. The ambience is cool bar but not dark.  Would definitely come here after work for drinks. Had half off wine glass and draft beers. And happy hour is 3 hours!!! Also had the amaze balls deep fried brussel sprouts with apples and cheese - so friggin delicious. Tried the rabbit and chicken liver pate which was pretty good. Almost tasted like bleu cheese and had so many nice relishes and mustards and chutneys. Had a dozen raw oysters all to myself. Best with just lemon juice and bit of fresh horseradish. yummy!!! Wish we had a place like this back home.

Loved this place good ambiance - great food ( only complaint would be wishing they served real butter w/ their bread instead of margarine?!) I had the seafood gumbo - very good but not much seafood in it - the roasted chicken was delicious ! Burgers are great too ! Best part of the meal was the Bread pudding ( I don't even usually like bread pudding but this was Amazing !!! )
Yum yum !!

Went for lunch our first day in NOLA. Everything was wonderful: the service, the wine selection and the food. Had life changing crispy brussel sprouts with jalapeños and honey! Also tuna crudo was beautiful and delicious. I will go again for sure.

Best shrimp and grits I've ever had.  On our first visit we did to-go and brought the food back to the hotel room (the Hilton connected).  Eating Luke's food in bed in front of the TV after a long day on the road was one of the highlights of our trip.

The only reason this is not a 5 star review is because on our second trip they didn't cook my wife's burger correctly.  She ordered medium.  The center was perfect but the edges were raw in the middle.  We sent it back and the 2nd burger was exactly the same.  Honestly, I'm curious how they cook the burgers to get the center more cooked than the edges.

I have nothing but praise for the flavor of the food.  It's just pure deliciousness.
Fantastic gumbo and fresh gulf oysters.  Oh and the Sazerac's were really great too!  I will definitely go back!
Great spot for lunch or dinner.  Food and service are amazing.  Fried oyster salad is awesome!

Had a lovely lunch here.  The hostess was friendly and full of energy as she showed be back to my table.  The server checked in on me regularly and made a good suggestion to help me with my order. The brussel sprouts were delicious.  Fries were not the best-they weren't hot, were soggy, needed salt.

If you aren't prepared to pay for an upscale meal, don't go.  This is a restaurant about a certain style of food using some of the best local ingredients available.  Breakfast is okay to good, Brunch sensational, Lunch very good, and Dinner outstanding to sensational.  The wine list is good to very good. (the sancerre is the weakest, the pinot gris my favorite)  All of the express menu specials are meals to remember but the Court Bouillon is my favorite, with the veal a close second.  Don't look for boring, standard, or 'comfortable'.  Northern France meets New Orleans is not something to be bashful about.  Order something new and exciting and don't think about the bill.

Happy hour review:
OpenTable made reservations a breeze. Happy hour began at 3p, our reservation was for 3:30p. I recommend this as a midday meal, as the food and drink is top-notch, my husband's and my favorite meal of our trip. 
The cocktail menu is strong, featuring perfectly executed classic cocktails. I recommend the French 75 and the Old Fashioned.
The oysters lived up to the hype - $0.75 oysters are delicious, large, fresh. Accoutrement are not lacking - lemon wedges, ketchup, horseradish, saltines. No shame in ordering dozen after dozen. In addition to the fresh oysters, we also tried a half dozen fried oysters. These were the most perfectly seasoned, perfectly fried oysters we'd ever had (and we've had oysters). They're served with a spicy buttermilk aioli - scrumptious! In addition, we shared a crispy brussels salad; as others have shared, this is how brussels sprouts should be done! Delicious!
