After our oyster feast, we weren't too hungry. We shared the daily special, a fried chicken served over red beans and rice. I did not have high hopes for this dish, as I perceived the oysters as the main event. Boy was I wrong! The shared dish was served separately plated, each in its own mini cast iron skillet.  Each bite of chicken was spectacular, succulent and flavorful. The beans and rice were perfectly upscaled peasant food and were the best thing we ate all day, perhaps all trip.
Service was excellent. Our servers kept our place settings tidy and our drinks replenished. I recommend dining here during happy hour in a tapas-type mentality, ordering dishes as you decide on them. Dishes were all prepared fairly quickly, and cocktails were there in between "courses." All in all, it allowed us to have a long, luxurious meal at a very smart price.

So we went back for dinner the day after New Years with friends and it was just as good if not better. Best bite this time was the stone ground grits that came with the shrimp n grits. Wow! We also got lucky again and had Richie as our server - you won't find a better waiter!
Gumbo was fantastic!! One of the best roux's I have ever tasted.
Delicious lunch at this very fine restaurant. An excellent vibe with top notch service and food.

Service is excellent. Atmosphere is great. The raw bar was fantastic. Those were the best Alaskan crab legs I've had. Well worth splurging for them. 

My friends were drawn in by the awesome looking burger they had, and indeed the burgers were all they hoped for. It came with a generous portion of crispy fries. But if you want anything else besides the $17 burgers, expect to spend over $30 for your entree. While the ambience feels and looks casual, it is fine dining.

Unfortunately, the waiter did sell the shrimp and grits with the additional crab as "heaven in his mouth", but that it was not. I've had better shrimp and grits in Atlanta, and there is no reasonable way you should be paying $30 for shrimp and GRITS. Without the crab, it was still over $20.

But everything else was great. Drinks were delicious. Everything came out pretty quickly. Oh, when we mentioned we were visiting from out of town, the waiter was nice enough to give us a complimentary appetizer of the cool pizza to start. It was great but the name is hard to say or remember. And the rabbit and chicken liver pate was super worth since it comes in a huge mason jar.

I recommend sticking to the drinks, appetizers, and burgers and you'll be a pretty happy camper.

My girlfriends and I went for the Happy Hour and it was AMAZING.

The service was great from start to finish. 

e all ordered some cocktails to start as well as 2 dozen oysters (raw and grilled). We also ordered a variety of sides to share: pate, brussels sprouts, grits, and fries.

Our table raved about all the sides particularly the brussels sprouts were sweet and caramelized (perfection).

We went another round of oysters before we asked for the check. The oysters were so fresh.

I can't wait for the next opportunity to venture back for another meal here.

My wife and I visit New Orleans regularly, and every time we're there, we go to Lüke every day for Happy Hour. Their oysters are stellar, and at half price, I eat four dozen at a sitting. We have tried quite a few of the items on their menu, and my wife recently had their Ragout of Wild Boar and loved it. I tried it too, and it was a fantastic treat. Their Crab Bisque rocks, and it's a decent sized portion. We've also had the Flamenkuchen, which is like a flatbread pizza with bacon and onion; it's quite tasty and crispy. We've had their giant Lüke burgers and loved them too, they're fantastic, and prepared perfectly. In fact, we brought their burgers back on the plane last year, and they were delectable. They serve a bevy of beers, whiskeys, cognacs, wines and other spirits, all of high quality and drinkability. I actually drink the Mountain Valley Sparkling Water most of the time, with an occasional beer or wine, which are also half price for Happy Hour. The servers here are great, and we drew one of the same friendly waiters, Kyle P., that we had last year, for a couple of our visits this year. He was exceptional and warm, as well as genuine. The service is fast,  but not rushed, and the manner is warm and professional. The atmosphere is upscale, but not pretentious or haughty, and the dress is from business, to t-shirt-casual. The prices are not cheap, but the food is outstanding. Owner John Besh runs a tight ship, and we owe our lovely friend Marci for turning us on to their Happy Hour. Thank you Lüke for making our afternoons between 3 and 6pm in New Orleans, oyster-packed, comfort-food-filled and very enjoyable.

When I was looking for dinner options in NO and came across Luke, I got excited in learning it was a John Besh restaurant! I am a big Top Chef junkie so I was really happy to have the chance to dine here while visiting NO for a day. Even better, it's a casual French restaurant (hubby likes casual, and I like French!). 

The service here is friendly and efficient. I wish the complimentary bread was warmer though. We started with a cup of the crab bisque, baked oysters, and the Flamenkuchen. Crab bisque was to die for. I especially loved the little kick it had. Bake oysters were also incredible. The Flamenkuchen, while highly recommended by other Yelpers, we thought it was okay. The flavor was nice but if the onion was warmer or closer to room temp, it would have been better. It was on the cooler side. 

For entree, we split the Steak Frites. We weren't given steak knives, not sure if we were supposed to or not, but we didn't even need them. The steak was so tender and juicy that it could be cut with a butter knife :)  Because we split the steak, they gave us each an order/side of fries. It was too much! but so wonderful at the same time. 

We also had a side of the jalapeno grits. Amazing! So creamy and delicious. Probably means it's so bad for you :)

For dessert, we split the bread pudding. I was so stuffed by now I couldn't finish, but hubby happily downed the rest on my behalf.

We wanted to like the Flamenkuchen, but just didn't.  Those big pieces of ham/bacon with all that fat was just too much.  And we encountered the most arrogant server, Kenneth, that we have ever had.  After the first course, we decided to cut our loss and not stay for anything else.  We expected so much more from a Besh restaurant.

Luke is in the Hilton New Orleans.  It was late, raining, so stopped in for dinner.  I was impressed by the number of people that came in that weren't staying at the hotel.  The service was good, food was okay - but not particularly special.  Breakfast was better than dinner.

Masculine and classy vibe, beautiful brasserie, they have a bar and tv in case you wanted to watch something during happy hour 

Had the baked oysters, these were yummy, a bit greasy but yummy(needed a squeeze of acid)

Had the brussel sprout appetizer, yummy, lots of flavors and textures going on in there, good serving for 4, could probably order this as a meal to go for one

Ordered the shrimp en cocotte (shrimp and grits) asked for pouched eggs on top. Grits were jalapeño flavored but GOSH, they must have put a brick of jalapeño jack on there cuz that was all tasted! Shrimp was smaller than expected, gravy was good, not much grits under all that cheese, I had to pick all these cheese out cuz it just overpowered the whole dish (next time, ask them for less cheese or none cuz it didn't need it), best part was the 65 degree sous vide egg(I'd probably love the 75 degree egg more), it was just perfect!

Had the chocolate steamed something with salted caramel ice cream. It was ok. The salted caramel ice cream tastes like pure sugar  no depth and ridiculously sweet (bi-rite makes salted caramel way better). I had one bite and that was enough

I'd probably only come back for happy hour prices raw oysters and such but that's about it

Luke's Happy Hour 4-6pm M-F. 75 cent oysters as well as half priced cocktails, wine, and beer. Nice lively atmosphere with a good mix of locals and tourist alike. Come early as the bar fills up quickly. Oysters were fresh and plump and the house gumbo has to be one of the best in town.  Come on by and enjoy a dozen or two.
Been here when happy hour when it was 50 cents an oyster. We also ordered burger which was good too. You better call beforehand when u wanna come during happy hours.

Very great decorations and service. The place looks awesome. 

We first ordered the half dozed jumbo gulf shrimp. I'm not from the gulf but I didn't think that they were that jumbo. They were also a nightmare to peel and eat but the cocktail sauce was really good. Kind of pricey for the size and quality of the shrimp. One was mangled and awkward looking.

I ordered the gumbo just to have a Nola dish with my meal. Unfortunately the gumbo itself was room temperature, but the rice that they put on top was refrigerator cold. As soon as i stirred it, it was completely cold. Kind of sad since I was paying $6 for 4 bites of gumbo. Small portions here too.

We then ordered the pate and the green salad. The pate was good, and was a huge portion. The pickled sides were probably the best part. I had never tried pate so I can't be the best judge but I liked it. It had a mild flavor to it. The salad was $17 and was 5 leafs of butter lettuce drenched in a basic sauce. 

Overall this place isn't bad, it just seems like one of those places where you pay for the ambiance and not the food.

I recently spent several days in NOLA and just stopped in to Luke for a quick lunch on my first day.  I kept going back, because it was so good. 

Oysters on the half shell...some of the best I've ever had. Ended up getting a second dozen. 

Gumbo...very good.  Roux could be a bit darker, but still top shelf!

Croque Madam...excellent.  High quality ham.  Toasted just right.  Delicious.  

Fries...very, very good.

Charcuterie board...excellent variety and very, very traditional, with pate', blood sausage and several other delicacies.  Probably one of the best I have ever had.

All meals served with great, crusty French bread and butter.  

I ate at the bar each time, and service was always top notch.

If I were smart, I'd lie and say this place stinks and should be avoided (so that it won't be impossible to book in the future), but I will be honest and give Luke the five stars it deserves.  

The food is fantastic and the service attentive, but the best deal by far is the happy hour when you can stuff yourself with raw oysters or scrumptious fried oysters for almost free.  The wines by the glass are half price, but I found them disappointing.  The cocktails are also half price.  the ambiance is posh but the service is not snooty.  The one weird thing is that I asked for fresh grated pepper and was told they did not have one that was operable. WTH?  Small quibble though.  

The brunch is also outstanding even if it's a bit pricey.

Our server was really great and the food was pretty tasty as well. The reason why I'm giving it three stars out of five is because the ambiance was very loud. They have a cabinet next to the hostess stand which holds all of their silverware and about every five minutes you'd hear ridiculously loud noises of forks,spoons,etc. being dropped on the floor or being thrown into a drawer in the cabinet. I know it might sound petty but it's really annoying when you're trying to hold a conversation with someone.

I'll keep this simple and straight to the point, since I'm on my iPhone. 

Best fried oysters I've ever had. 
Best shrimp and grits I've ever had. 

Fried oysters... The crispy batter on the outside is surprisingly good, and then you have oysters just pop in your mouth from freshness. Delicious.

Shrimp and grits... The shrimp was good, but those grits... Those grits!!! The hint of jalapeño is the perfect touch to this perfection. 

Although I have only 20+ reviews I eat out all the time. Take my word, and thank me later. 

Enjoy the pics! :)
Wow, spent 200 bucks on food that had  NO FLAVOR. From crab legs to soup, boring and tasteless.  Hostess totally forgot about us. Not worth the $$$ or time

Went here a few weeks ago expecting something grand and that definitely wasn't the case... I had the corn & crab bisque (when ordering this I expect CRAB... There was none) & the Washington Parish Roasted Chicken... The chicken was seasoned well & the potatoes were too. I enjoyed it for sure BUT back to the bisque. To be quite honest, the bisque was tasty even though it lacked crabmeat so I won't just say it was horrible when it wasn't... I give the food an overall 3.5 because of taste BUT the service was not great. My waiter was very nonchalant and not attentive... I really like when waiters ask if you're enjoying your meal & ask about dessert amongst other things regarding your dining stay but this guy didn't. Seemed as though he wasn't happy to be at work. But all in all the food wasn't bad, and if you'd ask me if I'd go again... I'll just have to decline.

Despite the shaky service I still find this restaurants to be amazing.  Shrimp and grits were amazing. The balance of flavors was perfect esp since I hate spicy and it made with jalapeño peppers. Dont be afraid of the dish its not spicy at all! Cocktail just put me to bed. Will go back soon. Yes.

This place is a must when in nola! Our server, kristeffer, was on point! Had great timing & tempo with our food, made great recommendations, & was very friendly. The small fruit de mers was enough for 4 people but oh so addicting. Shrimp was spicy but we love spicy. Brussel sprouts with Marcona almonds was delish as well. Hands down, best entree, shrimp & grits! You won't regret it!

Luke is a great joint. The food is all delicious, a fusion of French, German, and New Orleans specialties. Drinks are expensive, but happy hour is a great deal with half off their own draft brews, wine, and cocktails. The oysters at happy hour are only 50 cents, and sure, you say, you know of a 25 cent oyster joint somewhere. I guarantee those oysters aren't as big and fresh as those at Luke. Just the best raw oysters I've had anywhere.

I love their lunch, especially the two course daily lunch special. And the burger, dear me, you might not thing of this as a burger place, but it's got one of my favorites in town. The only reason I don't get it more often is because it's hard to get anything done after eating that mid-day.

They serve Cokes in the individual small bottles, so they aren't bottomless. But you aren't coming to a place like this for bottomless Cokes, anyway.

The biggest drawback to the place is the loudness, especially in the back room. New Orleans restaurants really need to cut this crap out. Having a loud place doesn't make you seem more popular. Also, I have no idea how to pronounce a u with an umlaut, so that's annoying.

Went to Luke for happy hour expecting to come away with a smile on my face and a belly full of delicious $0.75 oysters.  Little did I know that retribution would be inflicted upon my bowels for my gluttony and stinginess.  Food poisoning from these oysters ruined my entire Mardi Gras weekend, leaving me starving and sober during one of the most hedonistic festivals in existence.  Perhaps management felt the need to cut costs along with increasing prices by switching to cheaper oysters.  Steer clear of this place until they reevaluate their suppliers.

This restaurant sits inside of the Hilton St. Charles hotel where we stayed while in New Orleans. You can enter right off of the main street. Located in the Central business area on the very outskirts of the French Quarter. Walking distance from the trolley and all of the Quarter's sites, this is a good area. (If you ever want to stay in The French Quarter but not too close to the craziness of Bourbon St, stay in this area.) This quaint little spot with it's intimate sitting area is crammed with tables and seems a bit congested however, is billowing over with old southern charm...the black and white tile floors screams old building. Elegant yet casual. The food is moderately priced and boy oh boy it is yummy!!! New Orleans fare. The jalapeño grits are to die for!! Get a side order just because!  You will not be disappointed!! You MUST try their Bloody Mary!! I think this is by far the best Bloody Mary that I've ever had; spicy, bold, and very flavorful. No, I didn't see the bill and thank goodness I didn't lol. 

The dress code seems to be business casual from the looks of the customers. The service was fast. The waiters were freaking awesome( ate here three times while there). They offered items that they enjoyed! Oh, and get the bread pudding!!! Oh goodness, you're in the South, bread pudding is a must!! The bread pudding was savory and sweet, moist and deliciously tasty. Go for breakfast!!!!!!

This place is awesome, great signature drinks and great atmosphere.

Food is delicious and wonderfully put together the dishes are designed to enjoy all the best of Cajun/ American food.

The proportions run smaller than a regular place but the taste is worth it.

We enjoyed the Gulf fish and shrimp jambalaya, champagne au poire and all was perfect!!
Shrimp and Jalapeño cheesy grits with 2 eggs over easy minus the andouille sausage only cause it's ash Wednesday today was by far the most amazing we have ever had!!!! Flavor explosive!

Great Brunch, I was here during Mardi Gras weekend and ordered the Jambalaya.  I asked for it extra spicy (how the locals like it) and it did not disappoint.  The Sausage was extremely flavorful and the pork belly was succulent.  My fiance ordered the Croque Monsieur which was doused in a layer of baked emmentaler cheese and served on a wooden cutting board.  The portion was enormous so she only ate half.  Very enjoyable meal and our waiter was extremely friendly.

This place is more casual than I initially expected, but it still has a nice ambience. My friend had the shrimp and grits (which was everyone's favorite) because it was packed with flavor. I had the chicken and it was a little dry for me. We also shared a bottle of wine. The prices were reasonable.

Holyyyyyyy shiet you guys, first time in NOLA & I'm in love with the food & Lüke's. It's a pescetarian's dreaaaaam come true. 

Service:
Absolutely excellent. Our waitress was so friendly & kind. They ran out of wild boar ragu that Josh G. wanted, so she gifted us bread pudding for freeeeee.

Prices:
Reasonable. Slightly on the expensive, but reasonable. Definitely worth every goddamn penny though because it was so good. 

Food:
I ordered a small cup of seafood gumbo & shrimp & grits, while Josh G. got the shrimp cavatelli. We inhaled everything; it was amazing. Best shrimp grits of my friggin' life. So cheesy & full bodied umami. Shrimp was large & juicy, while the gravy was to die for. The seafood gumbo was also a great dish. So earthy & flavorful with large hunks of oyster & shrimp. A little disappointed how small the cup is. It is literally the size of 1 cup, so if you expected it to be like a mug (2 cups), nope. Josh's shrimp cavatelli was also phenomenal. Full of umami - the tomato sauce was fantastic, I would straight up bathe in dat. It was savory, not too rich, creamy, perfect mount of sweetness, & very fresh. I need that tomato sauce recipe right meow.

Then came the bread pudding. Holy expletive, batman. You done good, Chef John Besh. That vanilla ice cream atop a sweet baked bread pudding with delicious pecans & caramel was "melt in your chair, swooning over the moon or seeing your celebrity crush" good. I would like a very large bowl of that right now. Can y'all deliver to Boston plzzzz?? 

Environment:
Large restaurant with pretty decent lighting. Perfect date night or a night out with friends. 10/10 would absolutely recommend. Left so full & happy.

edited: was drunk when I wrote this, so yeah.

I feel like I should have come here for dinner! We stopped by for breakfast. The shrimp and grits were amazing (high calorie).  According to the waiter it's also his favorite dish and that it's even better with crawfish during the season for it! I like dark roast coffee. I think the roast used in their press is lighter. My husband had the Southern breakfast and the biscuit was too mushy. I would replace it with toast. Hope this helps breakfast hunting!

I went there for breakfast after some of the tourist trap places were too busy for me to wait.  I had the shrimp and grits which came with an over easy egg on top and andouille sausage in the mix.  It was dynamite!  Very rich, but super tasty.  It's billed as a french brasserie so you know it's not going to be cheap walking in, but the food quality is excellent and worth the price.

We only went there for he half price oyster happy hour 3-6 but OMG!!!! Sooo sooo good...we always were able to sit at the bar (which our favorite). We spent 3 or 4 days in a week from 3-6pm back in November. My husband and I ate more than anyone that works there has ever seen 8 dozen!!!! 

Btw, we went to Acme just to see.... Thumbs way down

Food is delicious.  We ate there twice in one day.  Polite but detached service left something to be desired in both cases, particularly when it was obvious that we wouldn't be ordering anything further.  Sad, really, as I'd have given it 5 stars had it not been for the tag-team 'Are you done yet?' routine.  TWO of us went in for drinks and h'ors d'oeuvres are 3pm, we left at 5:30 with a bill of nearly $100.  Still, I leave a 4-star review, despite sub-par service.
Decent service but a bit uppity for my tastes and the staff seemed 'put out' by any requests we made. Food was good although it was pricey.

Shrimp and grits was spectacular! I couldn't stop eating. Oyster happy hour was definitely worth it as well! Boyfriend and I killed 2 dozen easily! We would've ate more but had to make room for the many other delicious cuisines in NOLA! Their cocktails were also awesome! Mint juleps = just the right touch

I had no idea that this place was owned by a celebrity chef. I came here on a whim after eating dinner and headed home. Passing by, we decided to check it out. Unfortunately for us, the place was booked solid. The hostess apologized that she didn't have any availability tonight and wanted to see if we wanted to wait for an opening.

Almost immediately, a lady in glasses and grayish hair smiled and came over and see if maybe we would be interested in dining at the bar, even though it was completely filled.  When we couldn't find anywhere to sit at the bar, the lady re-approached us, and offered a series of other wonderful recommendations in the area that we could try since we couldn't get seated at a table or a bar. She gave us a brief introduction as to why they were such a busy location and that the company has a few other fairly similar restaurants. She told us how she absolutely loved working there and enjoying the great food at the other restaurants as well as that one we were at.

Before we had another minute to think about it, she asked to see if we were interested in dining at the end of the bar. We advised her that we already ate and was looking for dessert only. She immediate gave us some fabulous suggestions on popular desserts and offered us to get the Gateau Basque, because she's been eating it for years!

The waitress at the bar greeted us and was incredibly nice. We had a small discussion about oysters and where they were from. We ended up getting a dozen oysters. Although the PJ Oysters weren't anything too special for me, it was still very fresh and delicious. I think I'm biased because I'm a big fan of Kumamoto (which they have) and Shigoku. As mentioned above, we ordered the Gateau Basque, which was basically a vanilla sponge cake with creme fraiche and Louisiana berry marmalade poured on top. It was incredible.

As far as desserts go, that was the highlight of all the desserts we ordered in a week's timespan in New Orleans. Before we finished, the lady in glasses came to check up on us again. She was very nice and asked to make sure that we enjoyed the food. She told us that she'll check on us again before we leave. But we didn't get to say goodbye! She was probably busy making sure the rest of the patrons were having a good time.

The staff here is worth recommending on coming here to New Orleans. The food is great, and the service is incredible. We had a stunning of a time, thanks for the Southern hospitality of Luke.

Great atmosphere, AMAZING happy hour specials, and top-notch service. 

We were a party of 7 and the restaurant was super accommodating even when we were 20 minutes late to our reservation during happy hour! The happy hour specials are half off drinks and $0.75 oysters which were what we were coming here for. The drinks were cute and refreshing and the oysters were fresh. The server also came by to make sure we were doing okay and was very prompt about attending to our needs. 
Unfortunately, I didn't end up getting food here but got a taste of the soup which was amazing and the food coming out of the kitchen all looked really good. Definitely one of my top places to come back to next time I'm in New Orleans.

We had Luke's for dinner and i must say i was not impressed with a lot of factors. 

The items we tried were: 
Baked pesto oysters: People said this was amazing, but i thought this was alright. I'd rather have the char-boiled oysters or fresh oysters. 
Gumbo: This was alright as well. Nothing stood out about it to me. 
Ribeye steak: Pretty good flavor to the steak, however, not as tender as the other places. 

Overall, I thought this place was pretty mediocre. They forgot our dinner and other tables who came in later got their dinner first, so we had to remind them. They also forgot my bread that came with the steak. It just seemed like an off day for them. Customer service was good, but not fantastic.

I wish I had something nice to say about this place but I'm afraid not. I recently visited New Orleans for Mardi Gras and was super excited to try out different places for some true Louisiana fare food. 

Sadly, my boyfriend and I arrived at Luke's for breakfast and took a seat at the bar when it was not seemingly super busy. The waitress/ bartender at the bar asked if we were dining in and we said yes and that we were looking forward to trying some authentic cajun food. (First meal in the area during our visit by the way). Anyway, she handed us a menu and we immediately asked for two coffees which we received. So far so good. 

Then about 20 minutes pass by and mind you we were sitting dead center in the middle of the bar area and the waitress and waiter both took orders for drinks and meals from patrons on either side of us without thinking twice to offer us a coffee refill or to take our order. Then about another 15-20 minutes passed and I got up because the waitress ignored me when I tried to get her attention and grabbed a bus boy and asked him the price of the coffee so that my boyfriend and I could leave cash for the two cups of coffee we had consumed almost 45 minutes upon arriving to the restaurant. 

We left money, and then left the restaurant and headed down the street for breakfast. I was sad, because the menu which I must say while looked rather pricey, we were looking forward to trying. The irony of the whole visit is that my boyfriend actually works as a food critic and columnist for Food & Wine magazine and will certainly not be recommending Luke to his associates. 

Instead if you want delicious food with a lot of flavor, but with fantastic service; New Orleans Cake Cafe & Bakery is the way to go! Out of this world shrimp and grits, very reasonably priced, friendly atmosphere and lovely neighborhood.

Tried for a second time to eat this place. Both times I never received my food. the first time was 60 minutes of waiting for my order which I never received. The second time was 90 minutes. This time they simply forgot to make it. Organization at this place is not existent. attitude is equally as bad. On a side note...avoid the Hilton Hotel it is attached to as well. 

I've ate here last and it was adequate. Staff was rude but the food was okay. Staff is still rude. Food? Avoid this joint at all cost.

This is my first time reviewing a place and felt the need to just because the front of the house service was so, so awful. Long story short, my two friends and I arrived around 5:30 for happy hour and the hosts -- all four or five of them inexplicably gathered around the podium -- were so inattentive, unorganized and rude that we ended up giving up and leaving. We're all very polite, undemanding people but the staff literally ignored us and demonstrated zero interest in having us as customers. I was really bummed because I wanted those oysters so bad!!! But the service was so terrible that it would take a lot of persuading for me to consider trying again. My tip for them would be to have one or two front of house persons who know what they're doing/remotely want to be there, instead of whatever it is they're doing now.

I didn't even realize it was John Besh's restaurant until I stepped inside. My group of 4 came here for breakfast before heading to meet a group for lunch so we wanted to try a few things but the intention was not to fill up.

We ordered the gumbo -- it was something I wanted to try at every single restaurant I went to -- and it was pretty good. A tad salty, but I'd rather that than bland.

The local crab omelette was decent, the egg part was fluffy and it was stuffed with plump morsels of crab. I was really happy to see that there was no skimping on ingredients here.

The piece de resistance was indeed the shrimp and grits. The shrimp are fried -- there are 6 of them -- and hangs off the lip of a mason jar filled with jalapeno grits and topped with soft poached eggs and a very light Hollandaise sauce. It was absolutely incredible!! The shrimp were perfect crispy on the outside with a great snap while the grits is just a smooth, luxurious, velvety, unctuous, gooey blob of deliciousness.

Really happy that we stopped in here!

3-6PM Happy Hour with .75 oysters and half price drinks/wine is a great deal. AND they take reservations for Happy Hour - we didn't know, but our nice hostess found a table for us. Very nice. (they do have mignonette sauce - but have to ask , and it's just ok)

I've eaten at Luke in San Antonio several times and have been a fan since my first bite there. When I planned our trip to New Orleans, it seemed a no-brainer that we needed to try the NOLA Luke.. and I'm so glad we did. If it's possible, this location far surpasses the SA location in terms of atmosphere and quality. We were seated next to the kitchen which has windows to allow patrons to see all the action. It was a lot of fun watching the process of all the food being prepared and plated. We started with a River Bend cocktail (YUM!) and the Crispy Brussels Sprouts appetizer. Holy Hell. I have been scouring the internet trying to find a similar recipe and I can't find one.. the description doesn't mention that it's a spicy dish but don't let that scare you away. It might be one of the best things I've ever eaten. I got the shrimp and grits, because duh. New Orleans. My boyfriend got their Fresh Gulf Fish amandine style with the veggies. The first that night was drum and it was amazing. We opted against dessert because we had some sweets we'd picked up earlier in the day, but I have no doubts their desserts are as tasty as their entrees. If you've never been to Luke, I suggest you do it at least once in your life. You can thank me later.
We loved it, a bit pricey but most places in NOLA are.  Gumbo was the best in NOLA.  Hubby had Shrimp and grits.  I had pasta with boar meat.  Flavors were incredible and we had a great time.

The happy hour here is ridiculous (3-6pm) .  Totally ridonkelous.  

$0.75 cent oysters, $1.25 fried oysters, and half off drinks.  That means $5 old fashions, sazeracs, mint juleps (too sweet for my taste), and other libations.  Great deal.  

Quality of the raw oysters was only slightly below acme's but at $0.75 a pop, it's basically a steal.  The fried oysters were also really good.

Hopefully you get lucky and find bar seating as it is first come first serve.  

5 stars!

Great and taste.Love it!This place is a treasure - great food, fantastic service.Great menu that can satisfy either the savory or the sweet.
Highly recommend!

Great place for happy hour. Oysters were deLISH! My friend and I had 2 dozen and we had some cocktails! The riverbend and champagne au poir we quite tasty. I had a side of fries and she had a side a grits. Best grits I've eaten. Definitely coming back. The server was great too. Just the right amount of attention!

By far New Orleans at it's finest. We went around lunchtime and surprisingly it was not too crowded. It was our second time to try Luke and I have to say we loved it. We love how the kitchen is open so we could see the them preparing our meal. When we sat down, our waiter greeted us instantly. My girlfriend was looking forward to the mussels, but unfortunately they didn't have any prepared for the lunchtime menu. THEY ARE A MUST TRY! Some of the best mussels in the city. Instead, my girlfriend ordered the beet salad and the fish entree and I ordered the chicken and red beans and rice. Not saying that was settling (poor us right). :) I can say as second time customers we definitely were equally as impressed as the first. It has become one of our favorite spots in the city.

What a perfect way and meal to end our trip. 

One of several restaurants owned by Chef John Besh In New Orleans.  From appetizer to entrees all the way to the end, dessert. 

For our appetizer we split the Crab Meat Maison, served with fresh herbs, touch of horseradish and country bread croutons. 

My choice of entree was the Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp over Roasted Jalapeño Cheese Grits and Andouille/green onion sausage.  I have never been a fan of grits before.  They have always been kind of bland, this one knocked my socks off. 

The wife went with the Fresh Gulf Fish done Amandine Style.  It was lightly battered with buttermilk and flour, then fried and topped with Almonds in a brown butter sauce.  Served with new potatoes, green beans and roasted vegetables. 

Please, try to save room for dessert.  Somehow we did. With two Cappuccinos we ordered Brendan's Bread Pudding. This is to die for! It is topped with Vanilla Bean Ice Cream and is accompanied by a buttered pecan sauce.  Also ordered the Chocolate Bourbon Pecan Tart, made with bittersweet chocolate and topped with Coconut Sorbet. 

Put this place on your bucket list of restaurants in NOLA. You won't be disappointed.

Came here for lunch on the last day of our trip to New Orleans. It was amazing. I had the gumbo and the gulf white shrimp and cucuzza stew. The perfect way to end the trip because I really wanted to take in New Orleans' cuisine and this was just the restaurant to do it.

Happy hour from 3-6pm is the bomb! Oysters, fried oysters, and beer. What more could I ask for? How about great service from Richie Rich and the staff? If you can ask for his service area, do so. He makes the meal so entertaining. This restaurant is just outside of the French Quarter, but the 10 minute walk is so worth it.

I went here for lunch and started off with the crawfish bisque and it was the perfect way to start off a chilly morning. It was creamy, rich, and truly tasted like crawfish. I wish I had some right now in this cold NY blizzard. What's a lunch without some champagne au poire? It was light and complimented my heavy jumbo Louisiana shrimp en cocette well. The shrimp sucked up such much flavor of the broth that every bite was juicy. The creamy fluffy texture of the grit balanced out the heavy sauce. Come here for lunch. You won't be disappointed.
The food was just not good enough to match the price.  Very expensive and the food did not particularly wow me.  It was overall OK.

We both enjoyed our meals, although I wish the portions were a little bigger. We were sat next to gentleman that had less then stellar service. He said he was sitting, waiting for his server for almost 30 minutes. We didn't have any problem with service. 

We did have some oysters and they small, but good. I would have no problem going back here for oysters. 

For an entree, I had a lobster and it was cooked perfectly...only issue was that it was a small lobster so I was't full after eating it. 

She got the fish and enjoyed it. She did ask for brussel sprouts to be grilled instead made crispy and they happily complied. She did enjoy her meal.

We will go back...very nice atmosphere and experience for us.

We've eaten there many times, and have never had a bad dining experience. From small intimate dinners to large groups, they have accommodated us. Happy hour is awesome with drink and raw oyster specials.

Not so impressed, and I am easily impressed.  Despite this being an outpost of local superstar chef John Besh, I found it pricey and non-exceptional for the price.  Service was perfunctory or less.  You might sample at happy hour for half price drinks and cheaper oysters, and see if you want to commit to a full meal sometime.  I didn't.  Oh, and there was a flea infested dog on the floor at the bar.
Fantastic service. Better Food. The burger was delicious but the baked oysters, shrimp, and crab are worth the money inexpensive. Hospitality is out if this world.

This was one of my favorite places in New Orleans. We had to make reservations because it's a small cozy homey place that gets packed! I had the rib eye steak it came with fries. I got the steak medium well and it was so juicy and probably the best steak I've tried yet! We also got baked oysters they had a pesto sauce and tasted incredible! My coworker had the shrimp and grits which was a recommendation from a friend and it did not disappoint. The bottle of wine added amazing to the rib eye steak I had. Yum!
Was there for breakfast.  I had the healthy breakfast- yogurt with granola and berries.  It was ok.  Service was decent.  Not a place I'd go back, but I am glad I tried it once.
Neat atmosphere, good price on raw oysters for happy hour, limited seating, touristy close to bourbon, I wouldn't seek out again
I had my first breakfast here in New Orleans. Try the southern breakfast, their ham is delicious!!!

Except for that horrific steakhouse that they have in the boring casino, John Besh is a talented chef and this is his best restaurant -according to me- especially when you consider the price and what you get (aka performance).

Luke has the best burger in town, maybe the state or the south. It is HUGE though (seriously, could be the biggest burger i have ever had) and it comes with delicious fries (thin and crispy).

Other entrees worth a try are the shrimp en cocotte which comes in a rather small dish and the pork schnitzel, which is good. Chicken liver with rabbit pate is the best appetizer (for someone who does not really like oysters)

Shrimp and grits are another favorite. That should be tried. For breakfast.

The bread pudding is the best i have ever had and i do not even have a liking for bread pudding (i actually find the idea behind this dessert appalling especially when you consider the conditions in which it transpired.) Though, this prone-to-be-dry pastry becomes a delicious treat here and is huge. Comes with ice cream on top. Try.

Steamed chocolate is another dessert worth trying, though it is rather small and this makes it just ok. 

Overall, a very good spot not to be missed. Especially if you are just dropping by to have couple appetizers.

We were excited to dine here and were not disappointed!  The Crispy Brussel Sprouts were perfection. They had just the right amount of crisp, sweet, tang, nuttiness, and heat. The Pork Schnitzel was deliciousness . Don't ignore the lemons on top...the juice squeezed into the schnitzel enhances the flavor of the wild mushroom ragout...which is brought out on the side so that your schnitzel doesn't get soggy before you're ready to eat it. 
The atmosphere is nice and overall it was a pleasant dining experience.
Great cocktails. The 75s are fantastic. Good cold seafood dishes. It's good,not great,but good Excluding the cocktails which are Great.
Went for Happy Hour after work. Oysters and drinks great way to end the week! Bartenders weren't too friendly but the servers were. Definitely going back.

They refused to seat us despite having a reservation.

We stopped by Luke at 5 pm today for happy hour. Upon entering, we were told that they were booked up for the evening as a result of the St. Patrick's Day parade. So, we stepped over to the bar to look for a seat and also went onto Open Table to see if there were reservations available. We were in luck! There was a reservation at 5:15, which we promptly booked. When we returned to the hostess stand, they told us that they weren't honoring Open Table reservations. Why be on Open Table then? 

This is not the first time they have pretended to be fully booked when trying to walk in. Last time at least they honored the reservation.

Best fried oysters ever. And best brussel sprouts ever. Hands down. No question. We wanted to get more food but weren't starving so we decided on fried oyster salad which came with a generous amount of oysters and were perfectly fried and with a perfect texture! The shrimp and grits was also just perfect and the brussel sprouts....I need that recipes- some magical honey balsamic vinaigrette w almonds and cheese on top.
The pancakes were on point. The pecan butter in them excellent. A little pricey though for breakfast

Luke is a "German" restaurant in New Orleans.  I didn't get the German part but I did get an excellent meal. The setting is fine, it's actually in a hotel.  I didn't think it was intimate or romantic, but I wasn't looking for that.  It was a full and busy room.  The food is by John Besh and it is good.  Three of us loved pretty much everything we had.  Highlights for me were the crawfish bisque and a Fried Quail.  The bisque is like butter and cream meet sweet crawfish.  The flavors were exquisite.  Quail had a seasoned batter that exemplifies New Orleans flavor.  We had oysters that were super fresh and super tasty.  You have to traipse out of the French Quarter for Luke; but it is well worth it.
We really just pigged out on the .75c happy hour oysters and 1/2 price drinks. Great value and if we had more time we wanted to try a 'real' meal there. This was our 2nd favorite spot on our visit.
Smallest portion ever. Taste awful and crazy expensive for trash. We wait so long for the food and it wasn't worth waiting and paying that much

Their Happy Hour is simply amazing. I mean we came back here 3 times during our 3 day trip just so we can partake of their happy hour. Where else can you get fresh raw oysters for $.75 each?? 

Each time we stopped by there was little to no wait. The second time we were smart and made reservations in advance. 

We were seated pretty promptly and of course we immediately knew what to order- this time we each got our own dozen of oysters, which come with a small loaf of fresh bread and butter, as well as spicy horseradish and cocktail sauce. Absolutely the best oyster happy hour I have ever had.

If I ever go back to New Orleans, I will definitely be back to this gem!

A solid four star restaurant. The small seafood platter is pretty good and enough portion for two. The seafood jumbo soup is a must. Rice soaking in salty seafood and creamy soup is so good! Yum! Besides the service is really good. The waiters are attentive and friendly. 

But the fresh gulf fish is not impressive. I understand it's "fresh" so it had little sauce and salt in it, making it kinda bland. Besides it is a bit greasy for a fish dish. 

Would definitely come back if revisiting NOLA but would pass the fish dish as well.

The food was amazing and the staff was equally amazing!!! We had the roasted chicken, raw oysters, and shrimp and grits. We also ordered to go for a friend that has several allergies and they made the food to order and didn't give us any trouble! Richie was our waiter and he was very personable!

We would absolutely come here again and highly recommend this place if you are in New Orleans!

My husband and I had a 1pm lunch reservation. We were seated promptly. The server came over, after a short while, and asked about drinks. After a long while, he came and took our order. My husband had the Monday Expess...soup & fried chicken. He chose the crawfish bisque. ..it was outstanding. The chicken was served with red beans & rice. The red beans & rice, took the crispiness away from the chicken. I had the shrimp & grits. The shrimp were nicely cooked, but I expected more spiciness from the dish. Our main complaint,  was the lack of service. The server was not attentive, we had to ask for bread. He was nice enough,  he seemed a little lost.
Happy hour oysters were outstanding.  The little neck clams were a totally new preparation.  And the charcuterie plate?  BAZINGA!  Go here!

We were wowed. Lunch served until 4 with Happy Hour from 3 to 6pm. Staff was attentive without hovering. Food was good but the Happy Hour is incredible!  Raw oysters were .75 each, fried oysters 1.25 each with half price drinks. What's not to love? Good food with great prices. Wanna go back for more!

I visited Luke last Oct. for a friend's birthday.  We had a lovely private room. Although my day long hangover killed my appetite (and my drink order), the service and the dish I ate was wonderful. The waiter was very sweet, even offered me bitters to help with that good ol' NOLA hangover. Go there BEFORE the night you decide to drink 4-6 Hurricanes, among other NOLA libations.

As my first John Besh restaurant, Lüke left me a bit underwhelmed. I went with my co workers who had always said great things about the restaurant. I went with the red fish, which was good, but not something better than a fish dish you might get at a chain like Cheesecake Factory. My colleague got the roasted chicken which actually looked amazing, and will be my choice should we return.

Ambiance was simple but nice. Service was attentive, but nothing spectacular. Bottom line, Lüke is a good restaurant, but with so many other great restaurants in the area, it doesn't seem to stand out to me.

I don't really have ANYTHING nice to say, so I'm tempted to say nothing at all... But in the spirit of helping others I will say that our service and food was poor... in fact my partner was served a salad with rotten lettuce pieces and a brown avocado. Upon sending it back because who'd eat that (especially for what they are charging...) The waiter snatched the plate off the table and didn't say a word. I realize he didn't make the salad and technically he's not responsible for it but his reaction was a little unreal... My $21 crab app was meh... so we didn't even bother to order mains and left. I'm so confused by all of the reviews raving about this place. In a word? OVERRATED.

Was very impressed with Lüke. The three of us shared a medium seafood starter, which had generous portions of oysters, crab legs, shirimp, etc. Very fresh and delicious. The main courses were excellent also (I had the minced boar). And the price /quality relationship was excellent. Good service, too.

Between the two John Besh, Lüke and August, August wins hands down. Granted we went to Lüke for lunch and August for dinner. The food at Lüke was ordinary and the lunch menu extremely small. 

Go to August.

Came here for brunch...their have a variety of brunch dishes and great appetizer dishes.. a definitely must try if u looking for a more classy comfortable great service restaurant at NOLA..

It blocks from French Quarter, so walkable if u staying around central area of French Quarter.
Can be busy..if u have large group, best to make rsvp.

5 stars for food, 1 star for service ! This was our first dinner in New Orleans... We live in Chicago, and like to think of our selves as foodies, and I have to say this place was delicious-- best Brussels sprouts we've ever eaten and the pasta was delicious!!!

Our complaint lies with the service. Our waitress was not attentive, rude at times and just seemed preoccupied with chatting to co workers and annoyed to have to serve customers. It was so strange and not expected at a nice restaurant  . We were looking forward to the "southern hospitality" and ended up being more appreciative of the Midwestern charm of Chicago. John besh-- you may want to check in on your staff, your foods great but management is slipping if your staff can't thrown on a smile and pretend to care

This is a happy hour review only. We came here a couple times with focus. No nonsense focus. We came for oysters. Fresh, giant, tender, succulent, $.75 oysters. And half price drinks. But you can get those a lot of places. But the oysters? They are spectacular. We didn't try them at Acme or Felix's. Saw no reason to do that! These are the kind you want to eat for hours on end. We ate till we were full. 

We started with a dozen each and then added more, as needed. Add a few drinks and you can leave here with a full belly and a huge smile. And that we did. 

The place is small and is off the lobby of the Roosevelt Hotel but with a separate street entrance. There can be a wait during happy hour, which is from 3-6, so get here early. Service was ok, not great when we sat at a table. It was better when we were able to get a seat at the bar.  If I lived here, I'd have my own seat at the bar like Norm on Cheers. I'm talking everyday kind of regular. Amazing.

Thank you Lüke (and John Besh) for showing me what red beans & rice could and should be! We ordered a daily special of Tabasco Fried Chicken served with red beans & rice. The chicken was good but not the star of the dish. The red beans and rice packed so much flavor, superb seasoning & porky goodness that I will never think of them in quite the same way ever again!!! 

The oyster shuckers work very hard here & do a superb job! The $0.75 cent oysters during happy hour (3-6pm) are enormous, super sweet, tasty & served with a side of horseradish that will give you a head rush! We managed to eat a lot of those during our recent visit to New Orleans. And the Hopitoulas IPA on tap was also half off during happy hour. 

It's a great little spot to squeeze into for some delicious food, fresh oysters or a drink. It's not a large space and can get pretty packed.
This place has amazing Brussel sprouts.  Absolutely fantastic, best dish I've ever tried. If your going definitely order as side.

If you're a gal eating alone and DARE to make a reservation and get a table, be prepared to be ignored. I had to flag a hostess down to even order a drink. Food is good and worth a wait, but I am not sure it is worth being treated Luke a second class citizen. Hello, John Besh, are you listening?? How about you, Hilton hotels??

First, I'd like to say that the service wasn't the best. Our waiter was inattentive at times. He didn't even bother to say hi when he initially came by our table to give us water. He just sat it down and left and then came back later and asked us what we wanted. I had a hunch he might have been discriminating against small tables or tables not ordering drinks based on his assumption that we wouldn't tip well (it was just two of us).

As for the food, it was overall good. We each ordered a cup of seafood gumbo and shared a half dozen of the P&J oysters. The gumbo was a little too "oystery" for my taste. I'm more of a sausage and chicken gumbo person, but I wanted to try the one here. The P&J oysters were okay, but I just wasn't a huge fan of the herbsaint, persillade crust. It felt a little too buttery/greasy for me. Finally, we shared the Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "en Cocotte". This was the dish that elevated the whole meal. It was a divine bowl of melty, cheesy, jalopeno shrimp & grit goodness. I basically gave the restaurant 4 stars because of this one. I definitely recommend coming here for their shrimp and grits if nothing else.

Happy hour is the time to go! We had reservations for a party of 15, split in two different tables, different areas..understandable. 5:45 and 6:00 seating times, but we were there a little early and they seated us early. We were able to take advantage of the HH .75 raw oysters & 1.25 fried. Order by the doz...Fried can be ordered by half doz.  

Crispy Brussel sprouts are really tasty! We had a few different dishes at our table, shrimp with grits, matzo ball soup, shrimp pasta, rosemary potatoes. 

Our waiter could've been a little more attentive, the bus boys had more personality. 

Great meal with colleagues.

Not my Favorite Besh restaurant. I went with a group of 4. We all ordered something different so we could share.  We were here on a Thursday and had the express meal, the Jambalaya and the best part was the sausage, the rice was bland and  had a similar appeal as Uncle Bens Rice Mix. The cornbread was savory not sweet.
The Burger was pretty good, we all concluded though we have had better but the fries were above average. 
The Shrimp and Grits, the highlight was the grits, we left majority of the shrimp as the flavor was not that appetizing . 
Gulf Fish Amandine..just as expected and as described by Besh himself at the RCA convention
Crispy Brussels Sprout hands down the best thing we tried. The flavors were great combination of sweet and Spicy that hits you athe end
Matzo Ball & Roast Chicken Soup Pretty sure had pork in it. Just okay

Service. Slow to refill our drinks and slow to bring the check and slow to run the credit card!

Atmosphere: Didnt seem to fit the theme of the food.

Overall, it was okay but Besh Has other restaurants in the area that outshine this one

I swear every time that I've come
here my palette has always left extremely happy and tummy full. the mister and I have been having some trouble amidst our paradise so a nice stroll downtown in the CBD to a late brunch was extremely needed. 

the lovely hostess was very accommodating allowing us to sit in the corner away from a more crowded area, I don't like sitting that close to people ... esp when I'm that hungry.
the service was great as well. 
in lieu of happy hour we got the half cocktails. I ordered the French 75 which was a nice frothy cocktail and the mister the champagne cocktail with the rosemary and peach vodka I think? we both agreed the French 75 was the better choice all thanks to server's suggestion. 

for starters we ordered a dozen raw oysters bc it was happy hour, .75 cents an oyster, fried oysters 1.75 for one to start off with. the fried oysters? phenomenal. raw oysters were a nice size too. 

for entrees I had the assortment de charcuterie which came with an assortment of hog's head cheese, rabbit and chicken liver pâté, pickled melon pieces and more! it was all too delicious! I think the board became a massacre almost bc we did a killing on it. 

the mister ordered the grilled ribeye. which was cooked to perfection! had customers breaking their necks like "oh.. my.. God. Becky, look... at.. her.. steak" and I'm
just like "yeeea.. I know -cuts off piece and plops in mouth-. 
we just couldn't finish all of charcuterie and the ribeye though so we "doggy-bagged" it. LOL

I'll say though ... I've never once left this place unhappy. from the service to the food....  well executed. I prefer Sundays to come here... no parking meters, no school or work to rush off to afterwards,.... and if Mother Nature allows it the good weather when you stroll through the CBD to get to and fro here. it was def the best Sunday brunch I've had in a good while.

75-cent oyster happy hour special 3-6pm! Couldn't find any places in the French Quarter to get a good deal on oysters so made the trek across Canal St to come here. It was totally worth it.  Upscale but casual spot. It super packed for happy hour but we were seated pretty quickly even with a party of 5. Also, great service.

We ordered a ton of oysters, the crawfish bisque, fries and a side of truffle butter (I didn't even know that was something you could actually order but now I want it always). I'd recommend them all.

Just had to try John Besh's place in NOLA.  I am so glad I did as it was well worth the experience.  We started out with a dozen of oysters on the half shell and they were so fresh and delightful.  We then had the fried oyster and avocado salad which was very tasty.  It had big chunks of bacon in addition to a very tasty dressing.  
   For the main course I had the ribeye with Bearnaise sauce which was good to perfection.  The Bearnaise sauce was amazing.  The wife had the Cajun pasta with Gulf shrimp which I tried and it was very good.  We made a reservation which was a good idea as they were very busy. 
   the service was perfect - attentive but not to overbearing.  They serve coke in little bottles which was a neat thing since we were in the South.  A nice way to finish our 4 day trip to NOLA.

After a crazy night in NOLA we needed food. Good food. 

Hopped on yelp, saw the reviews/the rating and walked out the hotel door. 

I noticed the menu changes seasonally or daily or I don't even know. But a lot of the pictures I saw were not what was happening when we came in today but nonetheless such a good array of food options for brunch. 

We got the crispy Brussels 10/10. So damn good 

Seafood gumbo was good. I personally like my gumbo a little spicier but there were plenty of oysters and shrimp and sausage in mine so I was a happy girl. 

Fried chicken and biscuit- If you've been to Texas and have hada whataburger honey butter chicken biscuit this is that... but upgraded. I was so full at this point but I ate a good portion of it still. What made this absolutely delicious was the Tabasco honey. good lord. 

I tried my friend's shrimp and jalapeño cheese grits. Delicious. 
The burger looked good as well but my tummy was telling me noooo 




Preston our waiter and Rob the manager took SUCH good care of us. Can't wait to be back in New Orleans

Found this place close to our hotel. Read the menu, read the reviews and decided to give it a shot. Glad we did. This was the best meal we have had in New Orleans. They started us with some really fresh bread. Good fresh bread is usually a mark of a good restaurant. I ordered a cup of gumbo. It was a little cup, but it is was loaded with shrimp and oysters. Very good! 

For our entree, I got to the shrimp and grits. Like another reviewer, I'm usually not a fan of shrimp and grits. But I was mopping this stuff up. I couldn't get enough. My wife ordered the shrimp cavatelli and she loved it as well. The kids got chicken tenders and the biggest grilled cheese I've ever seen. We were a little out of place with kids, but whatcha gonna do. 

I capped it off with the bread pudding which is also a must have. 

Other details. It's s pretty tight squeeze in here and it was loud. And it was pricey. But none of that should take away from the fact that it was an amazing meal.  People have knocked the service, but our waiter, Kyle, did a great job. 

You need to eat here.

Of all of the restaurants that we visited during a long weekend in New Orleans (and there were many) we thought Lukes had the best food across the board. This Franco-German John Besh restaurant left us craving for more and seeking out more of his restaurants during our stay. 

We came in for lunch on Friday and this appeared to be a popular "power lunch" spot as many people were dressed in business attire. It took us about 30 minutes to get a table for 4 without a reservation.  It was well worth the wait!

Rarely, have I gone into a restaurant with several other people each ordering different things and each person leaving extremely impressed, full, and enjoying each dish we shared. For the rest of our trip, we kept visiting other restaurants and while individual plates may have been just as good, nothing compared across the board to what we had at Luke's.

I highly recommend the Lamb Ragout (listed as boar on menu online, but changed to lamb). While we could not determine our overall favorite dish, someone at our table who claimed they "do not like lamb" could not stop talking about how good this dish was. The croque-monsieur  (grilled ham and cheese) was also very good and the fries that came with it where crispy and very well-seasoned. We shared (devoured) an order of oysters and shrimp and thought these were among the best we have had in the city. The Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp was a delicious mix of jalapenos, sausage, and shrimp and was perfectly seasoned and spiced. Everything was delicious here and we look forward to our next visit.

Hmmm. Went here during happy hour with my fiancée. We made reservations (I highly recommend this or you'll be standing forever hoping by some miracle you'll get a coveted spot at the bar). So all was well. We were seated, ordered drinks and a dozen oysters (75 cents, baby!) And half-priced beer and wine? Awesome! We then ordered the flammenkuchen. My god, so good. So much bacon. Do this! But then!!! Things took a dramatic nosedive when we ordered another round of drinks and oysters. Boom, the 5-star service/experience disappeared. Our waiter basically abandoned us, and we waited no less than 45 minutes before we finally got our second round. They did apologize, but come on. Not sure what happened, but know this place can be, very quickly, hit and miss. Still, those oysters were amaaaaazing.
Very good food, well presented. Cut the prices and we'd be sold. Came for breakfast but paid like it was dinner

Disappointing.  We went for brunch on a Saturday after reading some good reviews here.  The food was ok but overpriced for what it was, especially a dozen TINY West Coast oysters for $45. But the real issue here was the service or the lack there of.  We had to chase the waiter down several times to refill water glasses and to find out why 1 appetizer came out right away but we waited 10 minutes for the oysters and Bloody Mary's.  Burgers were ordered rare and medium but came out well with cold fries. We assume the problem was the burgers were cooked before the appetizers were even delivered to the table.  Overall, can't recommend when there are so many better options in New Orleans!

We were in New Orleans for a girls weekend and happened upon this place for brunch one morning.  The menu looked great so we sat down.   Our server was very attentive and all of the food was great!  I had the fried chicken biscuit.  The jalapeño cheese grits were to die for!  I didn't have one but my friends raved about the bloody Mary's.  Great spot for a nice brunch in NOLA!

Excellent drinks!  The mint julep and Bloody Mary were favorites.  Also, the food is second to none.  Oysters are a major draw here but even if you're not a fan, you can't go wrong with anything on the menu.  Standouts for us included the crawfish bisque and the croque madam.  We will be back!

I was in New Orleans for four days and this was by far the best meal I had while I was in town.  The Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp 'en cocotte' was out of this world.  It's a bit heavy for a lunch dish, so skip breakfast if you want this.  

Service was perfectly non-existent except when taking orders and bringing food, which is exactly what you want during a business meeting.  Food came out very quickly as well, so they're used to accommodating business lunches.

I don't have much more to add that the 1,200 reviews haven't already covered, so go give it a shot!
Wow is all I have to say. Must try the friend oysters!we ordered that and crawfish bisque and shrimp with grits. All the dishes were delicious. Make sure to make reservation.

$0.75 oysters everyday 3-6 pm! This is a great deal if you like P&J oysters. We also ordered the crawfish bisque which was creamy smooth. We shared the rib eye entree, seasoned well and came with decent fries. There was some lulls in the service.

This place was amazing for being gluten free! Our waitress knew the menu and was aware of how the chief could accommodate our gluten free needs! She had the cooks make us fried oysters in a GF coating and fried in separate fryer. Acacia's recommendations were out of this world. We had the mahi and the shrimp and both were so yummy!

WORDS CAN NOT DESCRIBE!!!

I am telling you, NOLA has it hands down when it comes to great food but Luke was a treat EVERYONE needs to experience.

I actually ate fried oysters and I don't like oysters...and enjoyed them!

We sampled so many items it's hard to remember what was what but let me just say....I don't care for shrimp all that much (texture issues) and grits are not my favorite, but put them together at Luke and you have a mouth full of HEAVEN!!!

I can not eat any added sugar or honey or molasses or the like but I had the brussels sprouts without the glaze and when I was finished asked for a side of glaze so my husband could have the full experience!  We both loved loved loved them each way!!

NOW, my husband rarely ever gets dessert but this night he did, and BOY, I have never seen his eyes roll so much.....Some chocolate pecan tart with a coconut sorbet and people, let me tell you.......he almost ATE THE WHOLE THING!!!  I must have picked the plate up 5 times to smell this scrumptious looking dish.....and I can tell by the smell alone THIS would be worth getting sick over.......but I didn't!!  I lived vicariously through him and enjoyed the rest of the evening....service was wonderful everyone friendly LIFE IS GOOD at Luke!!

p.s. I don't remember what my husband ordered but I can tell you he was a happy man!!
Fantastic service. Steak was AMAZING. Best steak I have had in a restaurant in years. Monday is a good night to eat: decent crowd, fast service. I would go there again for any occasion.

BLUF:  Great food and service.  Fancy atmosphere and gorgeous dinning area.  Great happy hour.  Make a reservation.  Get a sazerac.  

Went there on a sunday early dinner.  Made reservations and glad I did cuz it filled up shortly past 6.  Got there just in time for the happy hour deals.  Half off oysters which were huge and amazing.  Half off cocktails; the sazerac was one of the better ones I have had in the city (not too sweet).  

Waiter was great.  No complaints.  Atmosphere was intimate yet still a full house.  The actual restaurant was huge with super high ceilings.  Very nice place.

I got the shrimp and grits.  They were jalapeno cheese grits and jumbo shrimp with a brown gravy.  It was amazing.  Not a huge portion though so I suggest getting appetizers or dessert too.

My lady got the squash crepes (maybe?) and she really liked it.  Bro-in-law got fish cuz he couldnt eat anymore fried foods that weekend (sissy).  He liked his too. 

All the portions were a little small.  i know that is a very "american" and crass observation/opinion cuz size doesn't matter...but too bad; I like to be in pain after dinner especially when spending $30 an entree.  A true foodie would not note this but i am not a professional, I just want to eat.

Overall the place is great.  Def recommend going to knock if off your list and get some great food.  I don't think I would become a regular.
Shawn is the BEST!!! Ate shrimp and grits, shrimp and cavatelli, and bread pudding dessert for dinner. All were beyond amazing!!!

I had to wait to write this review because I wanted a point of comparison.  

Simply put best meal in  New Orleans.  I am not sure everything is going to fantastic... BUT you have to have  the Shrimp with Jalapeno cheesy  grits AND the Brussel Sprouts  are to die for!! 

I am thinking of going back AGAIN.  It was that good. Oh and service was great as well. :)

Came for brunch after a night of drinking. The food was awesome. Quality southern cooking. And the service was just as fantastic. The servers, Nick & Nicole, made us feel welcomed & treated us with their southern hospitality like no other. Definitely going to come back next time I'm in town.

Wonderful brunch location...classy and clean. The chicken liver pate is my favorite.  The strawberry French toast was nice and I loved the cappuccino. There was a Brussel spout side that the chef sent to our table that was absolutely amazing.
They have a wonderful happy hour. Delicious  sweet oysters 75 cents each. Great atmosphere.

First night in NO and ways looking forward to a Besh restaurant...upon arrival the host/manager had trouble finding our reservation and searched for some time with no explanation or eye contact as to what seemed like a 10 minute wait, while talking to the hostess?  Once they figured it out and seated us, we placed our drink order and appetizer of a dozen oysters...they were just ok, very small oysters, nothing like Acme.  We had to ask for bread and butter...once the bread arrived, it was fantastic! 

We then placed our entree order of black drum with crab meat and shrimp and grits.  We also ordered the gumbo to share for an appetizer, unfortunately they brought it at the same time as entrees (they apologized and removed from the bill) My drum was fried/sautéed and was very soggy, crab was sparse for a $13 dollar addon, taste was just ok and I was disappointed.  My wife swears that although her shrimp and grits were drenched in butter, it was the best she had ever had! She would go back just for that dish.

As we were celebrating my birthday they brought us a comp steamed chocolate with salted caramel ice cream...it was great!!

Service was very good, not sure I would return...we may give it another try next visit.
I like Luke. I send a lot of people here from where I work. Good cocktails, easy prices, and they have mussels with fries. Really good brunch menu.

This must be one of the best places for oysters in New Orleans.  I went with a group during their happy hour and we tried fresh and fried oysters and both were exquisite.  They even made some of the fried ones gluten free for us.  The cocktails were delicious, simple traditional flavors that are half price at happy hour.  Highly recommended!

The last meal I had in New Orleans was here. We ordered crawfish biscuit, jumbo shrimp, and crawfish omelette. I LOVE the omelette. It is healthy - with asparagus and homemade salad on the side, and tasty - crawfish in the omelette tastes awesome together with asparagus. The fried potatoes were too salty for me but I don't like fries anyway, so that's ok. 

In general, foods I had here are not way better than other restaurants. However, it is very popular and hard to make a reservation. If you call at noon for the same day seat, you'll possibly have to reserve for a 4pm time slot. If you walk in, there is very few chance to get seated in a short time. So make sure to reserve seats if you want to come.

I had a lovely breakfast here! I had an omelette and it was really light but also very tasty. The waiter was really nice that he was able to get me potatoes on the side instead of salad. He was also attentive and made sure to refill my hot water throughout. My friend ordered a frittata and it was delicious. It was quiet and a great spot to catch up with your friend!

Food was top notch - we had crab legs, beet salad and crespelle - all were spectacular. Unfortunately, the service was sub par. The courses were served on top of one another (half way into the salad, they delivered the main course) and shortly after, they were asking about dessert. We were clearly being rushed out. Expected much better from this type of establishment. Borderline offensive.

This restaurant is highly recommended on yelp and we were in the area during happy hour. When we arrived, the hostess was totally rude & we were shocked! After she told us that we could wait hours for an empty table or sit at the bar, we told her we were happy to sit at the bar and said thank you. She literally ignored us & looked away. We were so mad by the time we pulled out our seats at the bar that when the first, then the second, then the third bartender greeted us, we nearly dropped our jaws! We sat there quietly shocked instead while all three bartenders continually checked on us, offered us more drinks, & made recommendations on the menu. It was probably the best service I've ever had at a bar (and by the way, the BEST oysters I've ever had). I couldn't help but wonder why that hostess what trying to ruin what these people are trying to do so we let one of the bartenders know. She sounded like she'd heard this story before and asked if we would speak with the Manager. We agreed & the manager came over (which was really nice though she seemed too busy to really care). Moral of the story? Act like you give a shit & you'll get a big tip! Oh & you'll keep your stars too.

My word!  On my third trip to New Orleans, I returned to Luke with a few friends.  We decided to try one of everything on the hors d'oeuvres menu except for the tuna.  Everything was so delicious, and surprisingly, a table of three women and two men did not finish everything we ordered, even though it was all super tasty.

The highlight for me was the charcuterie platter with the addition of rabbit liver pate and chicken liver pate.  Wow!  It was all so delicious!  The sausages looked and tasted super fresh; one of the pates, I forget which was which, was absolutely amazing!  The onion jam was a perfect accompaniment, as were the pickled watermelon bits-- who would have thought!  I could have stayed with that platter, for a long time.  No, seriously.  I still think about going some place comparable in NYC and ordering some wine and a platter.  No sharing, limited conversation, just a good drink and tasty eats.

We also enjoyed the crispy Brussel sprouts, jalepeno grits, crabmeat maison (super fresh and delicious!), baked oysters and a flatbread type pizza with the best bacon ever (a.k.a. Flamenkuchen).  

Again, everything was delicious with quality, thoughtful ingredients.  I get all the hype now after tasting an assortment from the menu and it all being absolutely, perfectly delicious.

To drink, I enjoyed the French 75.  It was well-made and tasty, but the highlight was the food.

I will be back next time I'm in NOLA.

I have dined here three times and find the food and service to be flawless. Outstanding seafood selections and perfect steaks.   Round out the meal with a beautifully prepared cocktail and you will get the full treatment.

Jalapeño grits are AH-mazing!   Great beer on tap. Oysters are delish!  The ambience is nice - there are two rooms - one that's near the bar and another that's a little fancier (you'd want to sit with your parents  in the fancy area unless you drink with them in which case the bar area seating is fantastic). 

Service and food is great here - enough that I'm coming back for the second time in two days (thank you grits and gumbo!).  Our server last night was personable and knowledgable.   I'll definitely be coming back the next time I'm in NOLA and will be looking out for my next Besh experience!

I'm a big John Besh fan.  But I have to say that I was a bit disappointed with this restaurant.  Our seats were in a very busy spot with lots of passing traffic. If we had known we would have asked for the back room. The table was too small to hold all of our food.  Drinks took too long to come.  We had the brussel sprouts. ...they were very interesting and tasty.  Other than that, the food was okay.  I guess I had my expectations too high.

Really good Croquet Madame!  Tip - only difference between a Croquet Madame and a Croquet Monsieur is the Madame has an egg on it!  

The Crab Maison is basically lump crab with some sauces/spices.  If you don't like horseradish, don't get this.  

We also got the seafood tower.  EVERYTHING was so fresh.  Pricey but worth it.  Goes really well with a nice bottle of champagne.  Good wine list and a lot of the bottles are reasonably priced.  

Service was really friendly and helpful!  I'll definitely come back for the Croquet Madame!

Horrible experience.  Will never go back.  I've never experienced such a rude waiter in my entire life.  Was visiting New Orleans with my boyfriend and made a reservation at Luke based on a friend who is a local.  She suggested I we go to Luke for his birthday dinner.  Upon being seated, the waiter came by and rudely asked what we wanted to drink.  At first I wasn't sure if I was being sensitive but no, he acted like we were inconveniencing him.  I watched him as he went from table to table and he continued to show this attitude.  I couldn't believe it.  We ordered appetizers and again with the lackadaisical "what do you want" attitude.  I was pissed.  My boyfriend, on his birthday ended up going to talk to the manager because I would have laid into them. What makes it worse is that everyone knew it was his birthday. I called specifically to let them know. Well needless to say, after the appetizers, I was too upset to stay.  We left and I'll never go back there again. That guy should not be working there. Complete disappointment!!

Came here for brunch on a Monday and this was probably my favorite meal of my visit in New Orleans. The place has an old school vibe from the dapper looking wait staff to sections of the day's newspaper hanging up for patrons to read. The brunch menu is not nearly as extensive as what you typically see at a diner these days, but the selections are high quality. My girlfriend and I ordered the egg white frittata and fried chicken biscuit to share. The frittata was conveniently served for us in two small portions. It was perfectly seasoned and so full of flavor that I didn't even miss the egg yolks. The fried chicken biscuit was also excellent. Chicken was crispy on the outside, moist on the inside and the biscuit was warm and fresh. The chicken biscuit also came with a seasonal jam that added a little sweet/tart dimension to the plate. From top to bottom, the ambiance, service, and most importantly the food were all very good. I definitely recommend brunch at Lüke!
Great burger and New Orleans atmosphere. Went went large group and service was great. Raw oysters were fresh and delicious.

The oysters were good. Service was a little slow but none the less very friendly. I had the salad with buttermilk dressing. If every salad I ever had was this good it would definitely be the only thing I'd eat every day. The sugar beets were yummy! Best salad I've ever had :)

Luke was on my bucket list for 2015 and it didn't disappoint. I went for the .75 oyster happy hour. The oysters were quite good but not any better than Acme. Had they not had the price right I would have passed on this one.

I ate at Lüke and now brunch will never be the same. 

Dwarfed by the huge Charles st. Hilton hotel right next door, one could easily walk right past this John Besh restaurant, but after the experience I just had there, it's safe to say that I'll sing praises of Lüke every time I'm asked about where to eat in New Orleans. 

The ambiance is professional and clean, casual and refined. Diners are greeted by quick-witted, smiling hostess and the servers here are incredible.  As a matter of fact, it's safe to say that this place has some of the best service I've ever received in a restaurant. And when you taste the food, you realize why the workers take such pride in their operation. 

The food at Lüke is magnificent. Southern cooking meets French influence here, and the food (and wine) options are all very tempting.
