Walked here from the Marriott and had a fantastic dinner with my sons. If you go here ask to sit in the back and if you are lucky enough to sit back there you will be treated to a show. The kitchen is surrounded by glass and we watched the chefs prepare monumental amounts of food. It was like watching dancers maneuvering around each other creating one tasty dish after another. The Brussel sprouts could be the best I ever had and if you ask they have recipe already printed out so you can attempt to make them at home.  Steak was top shelf, chicken was moist and the pasta was cooked perfectly. 'Look over there the chef is using a torch to toast something on that desert' was a frequent comment as we chowed down. We ended the meal with some bread pudding that I would consider world case. This is a great place to eat.

We ended up here for brunch after being told it would be a 2-hour wait at Willa Jean. There was no wait and our waiter Desmond was incredibly pleasant and helpful, so do look out for him. Out of the cocktails, the French75 was strong yet delicious (cognac, lime juice and champagne). PJ oysters were fresh and excellent. Ask to be seated by the open kitchen for the full experience!
In NOLA for a conference, and on my own for dinner one night, I sat at the bar at Lüke and had their blackened drum fillet. Quite possibly the best piece of fish I've ever eaten!

Really delicious seafoods. The first meal we took when we got here. Highly recommended. However, I am not really satisfied with the server. We waited for a lot time until he finally appeared. And the server was not around the table ALL THE TIME. Foods are super good.

I came here for a weekday lunch, and the place was packed with people. Everyone was dressed very nicely, so you could tell that it was a very business crowd. However, this place is huge, so seating was not a problem.

I really enjoyed their special that day, the jambalaya. It seemed that everybody was getting it, and the portions were huge. I ate my meal, but it barely looks like I touched it. Their lunch specials come with soup or salad and bread, so definitely fills you up.

I also saw a lot of people getting the burger, so must've been good! The service was also phenomenal, and the place looks very upscale for the price. Definitely would come back!

OMG...do delicious..I had the pasta and shrimp..so look delicious. Perfect...not to spicy..just delicious. Hubby had the potatoes chicken also so delicious. Can't go wrong..guy next to me ordered the burger OMG..looks devine..

You can't go to New Orleans without getting some seafood, I've always said (I haven't always said that,) so after a glowing recommendation from my coworker, my boyfriend and I tried out the happy hour at Luke. Happy hour prices, cute ambiance, and one of the nicest servers ever = 5 star experience.

So basically, happy hour runs like 4 to 6pm and its dirt cheap. Oysters are $.75/each (YEAH), fried oysters are $1.25/each, and drinks are half off. Are you kidding? We had 2 dozen oysters, a half dozen fried oysters, the ricotta gnocchi, and I had 2 french 75s. The oysters were MASSIVE, the fried oysters were crispy and delicious, and the gnocchi was soft and hot. I couldn't even try to complain about the French 75 - they even drew a little syrup-y heart on top of the foam. Not a single complaint from us, the food blew us away.

The inside of the place feels very lavish 90s hotel, but I'm not saying that's a bad thing. It was fancy, without the pretense. When we got there around 5:30pm, we had to wait for about 5 minutes to give the servers time to sit the groups they had just sat, but it wasn't a big deal. Our server (his name escapes) was a young man and was super duper sweet, knowledgeable, and just one of those individuals who loved talking to people. On top of that, our food and drinks all came out super quickly, despite the restaurant being pretty packed. The crowd drew all sorts: business men/women, young people getting after-work drinks, tourists (like ourselves) trying out some seafood.

For the amount of food and drink we had, the happy hour prices are unbeatable. Affordable, relaxed, and excellent service. I'd love to come back and try some other dishes on the menu... but I'd still need the oysters again.

Luke has recently done a rebranding.  The got rid of the umlaut and made the menu a bit more NOLA style.  We had a reservation and were seated immediately.  The restaurant is much larger than it appears.  The front looks very much like a trendy bistro whereas the back is a bit more American looking.  We sat in the back and they have the clear walled kitchen, which I liked.  Being a Besh restaurant, I expected to be blown away and wasn't but thought it was very good.  Our server was very good.  She was prompt and friendly and knowledgeable.  

There were four of us and we shared several dishes.  My least favorite was probably the flammenkuchen.  It was a standard flatbread.  Nothing really wowed me.  The crust wasn't that great or crispy.  The pate was quite a surprise.  I sometimes do not care for rabbit but this was really tasty.  The flavor was really wonderful as well as the accompaniments.  We had to get some jalapeno grits, which were good but not great.  I would have liked some more spice but the texture was good.  The 'etouffee' was very tasty, albeit not a traditional etouffee.  However the pasta that came with it was actually extremely good.  Overall, I expected a bit more but struggled with only giving 3 stars cause the food, ambiance and service were all above average.

Had dinner with a business associate on Monday Evening at Luke.  We were both staying at the Hilton, making Luke an easy option.

Loved the atmosphere, our waiter was awesome.  However, the food clearly had some challenges.  We wanted to get the 75 cent Happy Hour oysters (regularly $2.00 each); however, the special ended at 6PM and it was now 604 PM.  Ugh.  So I asked the waiter which oysters were the very best.  He suggested the ones at $3.25 each.  So I ordered a dozen for $39.00 expecting nirvana.  What we got were mediocre oysters, a small amount of overly hot cocktail sauce and horseradish.  Bad oysters in New Orleans is something I don't understand? 

The waiter suggested a Brando Cocktail, stating that it is similar yet better than a Sazerac.  It looked good but was too sweet for my taste.  There was way too much Amaretto within.

Then had a fried oyster salad.  It was a 3 star salad, nothing very special.  The french fries on the other hand were wonderful, glad we ordered lots of them.

By the time I had these few items I was done with this place.  Next time I am at the Hilton I won't be lazy, will make an effort to find better local fare.

Started with fried oysters and they were tasty, plump, and cooked perfectly. Had the burger and fries for my entrée and it was outstanding; cooked to order, a little messy, but really good. Would definitely return

Good service = good food = happy customers ! We shared the stuffed P&J oysters and the Brussels sprouts and both were fantastic! I had the duck fried rice entree and there was a lot of rice but the duck was tender and flavorful. My dinner mates had the shrimp and grits and étouffée and I didn't hear any complaints ! I only wish I would've had time to stop in for the happy hour during my visit. Ah well next time ...

Wanted to try the happy hour on the recommendation of friends/locals. The service was somewhat cold and unfriendly. The Happy Hour oysters are a great price but they quite large - not everyone's favorite. Jumbo shrimp were really rubbery and hard to get out of the shell. Sour cocktail, excellent; fries, good; vegetable sides, okay. We didn't particularly like the atmosphere or the service, so we'll be investigating other oyster happy hours.
While the food was ok, I am not accustomed to begging for a coffee refill. I do not like being treated as if I am invisible.

During my 5 days in New Orleans, I came to Luke twice! The happy hour oysters are amazing. Not only are they cheap, but also huge, sweet, and not sandy! I've been craving them ever since and am slightly upset that they have ruined all other oysters for me, especially the puny ones served in NYC. 

I also got the Pate of Rabbit and Chicken, and it was so so delicious. The flavors were strong, but not overwhelming, and I savored every last bit almost as much as I savored the oysters. Luke is definitely a must-go-to in New Orleans!
Oyster happy hour for the win.  Baked and raw hit the spot.  Don't neglect the Bloody Mary to Accompany the moment

I had this restaurant scouted out before we even visited NOLA. We made reservations our last night in town, after a week of amazing eats. 

   The restaurant its self had a very classy modern euro modern feel, upscale. 

    The service was stellar. We had 2 servers, both men. There personalities were great. The one gentleman was such a character.

   Our food was good. The cocktails were very nice. I will say, there large raw platter was a bit overpriced and I'm not one to complain about price. I think it was 10'raw oysters, a baby food sized jar (literally) of ahi tartar and another of mixed crab, for the price of $52, for an appetizer. It was. It that impressive, just to be honest. I would skip it. 

    
 I also ordered the crab & corn bisque. It was great. The seafood gumbo was nothing to write home about. 

   Our 4 entrees were all very good. My dessert was okay. The pastry was a bit on the dry side and lackluster. The cream cheese ice that accompanied it, was so good.

This place is excellent across the board! The food was 5 star and the portions very generous. We had the Lüke Breakfast. Best grits, eggs and bacon I have ever tasted. The bisque and gumbo are excellent too. The wine selection was excellent. Melanie our waitress was 5 Star. She demonstrated the art of customer service. She was professional, warm and gracious. Before we even had to ask for refills or accommodations she was tending to our table. The restaurant is classy and clean. I will definitely return every time I am in NOLA.

Was very excited to try Luke but was disappointed. Was with a group with a set menu with choices which all sounded great. Gumbo which was described as one of the city's best was average at best. Duck w/ crispy rice had all the right flavors but duck was medium well w/o any crispy skin. The bread pudding was all pecans and little bread to contrast. Service was good. Maybe individual dining would be better but in a city that lives for groups you have to get this right.

First restaurant we are at while in New Orleans for my Birthday. We had reservations. It was great! Ordered the chicken and the dessert. I recommend!!! After a weekend at Nee Orleans, Luke's was on the top of the list.

I looked forward to Monday lunch my whole trip because I was so excited to get the Tabasco honey chicken here at Luke. What a disappointment! Let's start at the beginning: the hostess was very friendly and promptly seated us. The waiter came over quickly enough and we had water in a timely fashion. However that is where it ended. My boyfriend ordered a beer and it was at least 10 min before he got it, that was after the waiter came back and we had to ask where it was... the waiter did not come back much after that. I ordered the crab bisque which was actually the best part of the whole meal. I recommend it if you decide to go! Then comes the lunch I have been looking forward too. It looks delicious and is presented in a cute little cast iron pan. I took a piece of the chicken out and put it on a plate to cut it, it was like trying to cut rubber. It was so dry and had no flavor  the only saving grace of the dish was the rice and beans. They were tolerable. Maybe I caught the cooks on an off day? I could not believe when I looked up must do's and eats, that this is what came up! Save your money and go elsewhere...
One the best spots we visited during our stay. Service was a 10! We had the oysters on happy hour and it is a deal you do not want to miss!

This place is good/decent. Before visiting New Orleans, I contacted a few friends for food recommendations and this place came up a couple of times. I would say it was good, but it didn't meet my expectations. The waiter highly recommended the shrimp and grits, but it wasn't great. I had other shrimp and grits at other restaurants over the course of the weekend that were much better and more flavorful. The gnocchi appetizer was very good, and probably the highlight of the meal. My sister got the crispy rice duck confit plate, which was also okay but not great. If I was a local, I would probably go here again but if I was just visiting and in town for only a few days I would go to other places first. The service was very good.

Great staff. Awesome food! 
Even without a reservation, we didn't have to wait for more than 10 minutes for a table for 2 on a busy Friday night.
Very good Gumbo, granacha, P&J oysters and a beer called Granley. The price is high. The service is excellent. And the quality is unquestionable.
Favorite restaurant on our visit to New Orleans. Some of the best shrimp and grits ever! The crab and corn bisque was amazing as well as the stuffed oysters. Be sure and make reservations for dinner.
Simply the best Cajun/Creole food I've had. The freshest oysters and the best shrimp and grits you will ever have. Husband and I had to go back TWICE, it was that good!

Scoped this place out and made a res prior to arriving in NOLA. Definitely recommend a reservation as it was happening even on a Tuesday night! The baked oysters were delicious as was the shrimp and grits dish. These are probably their most well known dishes and I am glad to say they lived up to the hype. Skipped dessert but the waiter tried to sell us on a smores thing that sounded yum, so will have to try that if I make it back. 

TBH the table service left something to be desired.. it was friendly but nothing above and beyond. Two guys were working in a team and one was more attentive than the other. Although, I will say the manager brought us a complimentary soup due to a minor delay on our app. That was totally unnecessary but very much appreciated, and it was delicious. So that was redeeming. 

Overall food was delish, so would come again!

When I made my 1st RETURN to New Orleans in OVER 20 years I searched and inquired from friends the best places to see, eat and drink... Lüke (like a few other places) had popped up in many searches and recommended by many fellow yelpers).... 

On our flight from Florida I locked in a reservation for a rather late night dinner (enough time to travel to our hotel, unpack and grab a pre-dinner drink... On the flight I also checked out the menu and pictures online and was impressed but was not expecting find more than one article rating Lüke as serving one of the best burgers in Louisiana... 

10 pm reservation on a weeknight and they were packed but our table was ready for us upon arrival.  The place is bright with impressive wood features like the eat-at bar and table partitions... the floors are should be for walking but they were drawing my eyes down to see the tile and wood inlay floors. The lighting fixtures and tin-ceiling tiles added to the charm. I also loved the way they displayed their seafood selection in a cold section at the bar.

I was very much in the mood to eat traditional New Orleans dishes like Shrimp 'N Grits or Étouffée, but I kept thinking of that burger so I went for it.... 

The Lüke Burger was legit.... bacon (glazed I believe), caramelized onions, tomatoes and emmenthaler cheese (I never heard of it either)... very pleased with my decision !

I also managed to steal a bite or two of their Shrimp 'N Grits (En Cocotte) which was absolutely spectacular !

Also enjoyed a Sazerac before dinner... they did New Orleans righteous with the city's signature drink

Best French 75 of my life - almost creamy but in the best way. The shrimp & crab "etouffee" was spectacular as well - perfect amount of spice in a delicious sauce. I would definitely make reservations - the space isn't that big and they had a huge wait.
Great food. Shrimp and grits, Luke salad and Brussel sprouts were our favorites. Kid friendly. Good service unlike some of the reviews said.
Went in while being remodeled, and still had great food. Two thumbs up. Can't wait to go back to NO and have some more! Hostess were very welcomed and made great recommendations.

Start off with a French 75 - a light but potent drink for the seasoned drinker. Then enjoyed a half dozen PJ oysters - delectable and super fresh. Shared an amazing gourmet burger with hubby. Servers (Matt took care of us) are inviting, highly attentive and friendly. Seating allows for casual conversation with diners. Would recommend this place 1000%.

Went with my husband and another couple to celebrate my birthday and had the best night ever. The food was fantastic and the service was impeccable. The manager was beyond helpful in recommending our entree selections and even delighted the table with an off-the menu favorite of hers, french fries and crab/corn bisque. Now a favorite of ours as well. To top off the evening, the server brought us all glasses of champagne and toasted to my birthday. Atmosphere, food and service definitely made this a memorable birthday.

Great service, great vibe. Food was delicious but a little non-traditional which is not my preference. MAKE SURE you order the s'mores torte for dessert. Top 3 dessert in the United States in my opinion.

This place is literally like heaven in my mouth. It is everything I thought NOLA cuisine is and could be. After flying in earlier that evening, I was looking for a place to eat and stumbled upon this restaurant. Thank goodness I did and thank goodness that despite the restaurant being packed full, the bar had a couple of seats for me and my boyfriend. 

I ordered the shrimp and grits. Do NOT go here and ignore the shrimp and grits. I had never had grits before and after this meal, every restaurant I went to, I was craving shrimp and grits. None were as great as these though. They're creamy and rich, but light and fluffy. So good.

If you do decide to visit during the evening during the weekends, though, I would recommend getting a reservation. The bar was packed for the next few hours while we were eating.

It's a little weird reviewing this John Besh restaurant after the sexual harassment allegations. We went before then so my how times have changed. We specifically came here to try Besh's food on a Sunday brunch.

The two of us shared the brussel sprouts appetizers, a cup of gumbo and the shrimp and grits. The waitress of course told us it was the best shrimp and grits in town. That's a pretty big statement in this town! Everything, including the shrimp and grits, were pretty good. What really surprised me was how tasty the brussel sprouts were! If you're not a sweet sauce fan, you might not like it as much but I loved the flavor and texture.

Breakfast has been delicious the past two days. The food and coffee is fantastic. They get very busy on the weekends but they're still very responsive. I specially enjoyed the Lux breakfast and the biscuits and andouille sausage that came with it. The coffee at Luke's is French press and very aromatic. I would recommend Luke's to anybody for the breakfast at least having not had anything other than a breakfast and brunch.

Lousiana rabbit terrine was dope. 

Fried oyster salad w/ thick cut bacon - amazeballs.

Shrimp and grits - too much hype, disappointing. My shrimp was mealy...

Good but not great.

Luke is the best place for happy hour.
The oysters are the best of my life.
And the French 75 cocktail and crispy Brussels is awesome. I will trip  to New Orleans to visit this restaurant!!! Awesome!!!!!

Yum. Everything we ate was so good. I highly recommend the shrimp and grits. So good. The oysters were amazingly fresh and a great deal during happy hour. The onion tart was a really interesting, different type of appetizer. Salads were fresh and high quality too.

Good atmosphere for friends, family, happy hour after the big game, or for date night.

Great place with good service. Highly recommend.

Fried brussels sprouts are the bomb but look out for the tiny tiny seemingly harmless pieces of jalapeño in there!  They pack a lot a' heat.  Service was mediocre at best.  A bottle of beer was forgotten and drinks took way too long to receive

Went for 3-6p Tuesday happy hour before our flight home. The $9/dozen oysters were very fresh and they were huge. The shrimp and grits was my favorite food item eaten in New Orleans all weekend and the gumbo was perfect. We had the pleasure of sitting at the bar- all the staff were very friendly and attentive and there seemed to be a mix of travelers and regular customers. The oyster shuckers were very lively and made the mood of our meal a lot of fun. Our server/bartender gave great wine recs and established very friendly repoire. We came in on the early side of happy hour and were some of the first guests there, but by 5:15 the restaurant was packed. Excellent meal, would be interested in staying for dinner one day. Will definitely return on the next trip to New Orleans!

This place is awesome. They accommodated two of our friends who came in late. There fried ouster salad is a must try. The oysters we're crunchy and there were huge pieces of bacon in it. Yum yum yum! They recommended jumbo shrimp and grits which was served in a cast iron skillet. I shared both orders with my husband and they split the orders in separate plates. We totally devoured both items. Highly recommended

Hubba hubba those jalapeño grits!!!! No regrits.

Don't stop there, be sure to try the gumbo. Super rich and delicious. The Luke salad was divine. Very colorful and full of tangy deliciousness. 

My friend and sister ordered the burger but the smokey bacon flavor and strong cheese was a bit intense.

This Central Business District located restaurant will not disappoint in my opinion.I can't say much about this restaurant but I will say they have the best Happy Hour for beers  and Oysters! From 3:00pm -6:00pm they have $0.75 cent raw oysters,  $1.25 for the fried oysters and Half Priced Select Beers, Cocktails, and Wine by the Glass. I don't know what you know but this is the best deal I've heard of in a long time. 

Get there on-time, the bar and dining room area fill up pretty quick!

From what I viewed they have a traditional menu that has a French/German/Creole themed selection by the renowned chef/restaurateur John Besh.

Came for happy hour at the recommendation of friends. (Happy hour is not just at the bar, by the way!)
The 75 cent raw oysters and half off drinks are an awesome deal. The oysters were huge and delicious, freshly shucked right in front of us at the bar. The Rosemary gin drink I got has a nice flavor. We also had the crispy brussel sprouts-- definitely recommend. The service  was spot on. 
Overall, we loved everything and felt like we got a great value and a memorable meal.

Amazing. Started out with happy hour oysters (raw and fried) and drinks. Great draft beer selection and mixed drinks options. Ordered burger and frammenkuchen. Both were amazing. Never thought I'd order a burger for dinner at a NOLA restaurant but this was worth every bite. Spent $100 and left extremely full and satisfied. I've been here for brunch and it was just as great. Can't wait to return. Great food, great atmosphere.

Had the turdunken from the thanksgiving day menu, was very good, coiuld have been heated a bit more thorough as I had cold spots in all of my food. The flavor made up for it. The jambalaya soup and crab and corn soup where both very good. It was a bit expensive coming in at just over $130 for a party of 3.

We had our Thanksgiving dinner here.  I had the short ribs and my wife had a shrimp pasta.  

The short rib was satisfactory and would have been better if there had been less fat on the bone.  It came with a shrimp dressing which was delicious.

My wife's shrimp pasta was wonderful.

Luke serves a bread which could be better.  It is an easy problem to solve by simply having lunch at Galatoire's and determining where their bread comes from.  Their butter too.

We always enjoy Luke.

We decided to give the Luke happy hour a try to get our fill of oysters and we were not disappointed. The fresh oysters were humongous and the fried ones were crispy with some spice to them. On to dinner where we had the  shrimp and grits and the Brussel sprouts with the citrus cured gulf tuna tartar. The food was excellent with the Brussel sprouts being the winner. The only reason there aren't four stars is that the service was a bit spotty with there being several table visits at once and then none for a long while. Regardless, I recommend this restaurant especially if you love oysters or Brussel sprouts.

I was so excited to eat at Luke's that I made sure it was our choice for Thanksgiving dinner.. our first night in New Orleans. I booked our reservation in advance, Robert confirmed and we were set. 

The restaurant was a let down in so many ways. The hostess was not friendly at all. We waited 20 minutes to get seated, even though we saw empty tables and we had a reservation. After finally being seated, we we're not helped for another 10 minutes. Service was slow, to say the least. Our waiter had no interest in helping us to understand the menu and the ingredients that I was not used to. 

The food:
Brussels sprouts- the only thing we enjoyed eating
Lump blue crab ravigote- so much horseradish and such a small portion
Luke burger- salty and unsatisfying
Shrimp and grits- salty and the grits were lumpy
Herbed shrimp pasta (turkey special with two dressings)- most blang pasta I've ever had

I hope this is read by management so it can be fixed.

Came for happy hour at the recommendation of friends. (Happy hour is not just at the bar, by the way!)
The 75 cent raw oysters and half off drinks are an awesome deal. The oysters were huge and delicious, freshly shucked right in front of us at the bar. The rosemary Gintelly lace drink has a nice flavor. We also had the crispy brussel sprouts-- definitely recommend. The service  was spot on. We did not try the shrimp & grits entree since we were just in for a drink and a snack, but several friends raved about it, as did the customer next to us at the bar.  
Overall, we loved everything and felt like we got a great value and a memorable meal.

UPDATE: Came back again and had another stellar experience. I stand by my previous review. Sit at the bar-- the bartenders are super nice.

I came here for their happy hour, which is a GREAT deal. The prices may be something outside of what I'd want to spend normally, but the happy hour is what you come for - 75 cent oysters on the half shell, $1.25 per fried oysters, and half off wines, beers, and cocktails. Their cocktail list isn't very expansive but their wine list definitely is (~$9-12 per cocktail normally but half off during HH). 

I'd say to skip the fried oysters and just go for the raw ones. They served B&J oysters for 75 cents and the dish came with horseradish, ketchup, and saltines. I'd never had oysters come with these sides in Seattle before, but the horseradish and oyster combo was surprisingly delish. 

It's hard to beat the ambience and HH deals in NOLA I'd say. 

Taste: 4.5/5
Bang for buck: 4.5/5
Overall: 5/5

First official meal in NOLA! A fine restaurant to dine in. The service is good and the speed to serve disjes is fast . We ordered 8 oyster for happy hour. We also ordered rabbit liver plate and seafood gumbo and shrimp with grit. Generally good but salty...Drink a lot of water...The oysters were great and very fresh.

I downgraded it by one star after the trip in NOLA. Really mediocre food and way too salty...
Really nice atmosphere. Staff were so nice and helpful. We loved our food and drinks. Don't forget to order yourself their nice Bloody Mary . Located in the French Quarter and so easy to park.

Had to stop in for their happy hour oysters, $.75/raw $1.25/ fried and half price wine/beer/cocktails. A dozen and a half oysters later and a gin lace cocktail and I am honestly a happy customer. The price was on point and the fresh bread was an added bonus. 

Note: the service could definitely use some work. I saw one waiter working our section who was great friendly and talkative with customers and attentive. Unfortunately when seated we waited five minutes to be acknowledged by anyone despite many staff walking around. Our waiter finally came by, but then disappeared. We would have ordered a second round of drinks but he never asked - literally had to waive him down for the bill.

AMAZING!!!

I ordered the fried oysters. It was so good! I never had fried oysters before but the taste of it was delicious. The batter was so crispy and tasty. I ordered half a dozen and wished I ordered more but I ordered shrimp and grits for my entree and didn't want to get so full from it. The shrimp and grits were heavy to eat but I ate the whole thing! It was so flavorful and rich. It was the best shrimp and grits I've ever eaten. I found myself dancing while eating. A habit I have grown accustomed to when eating delicious food. One of my favorite brunches of all time! It is definitely a spot to check when you're visiting New Orleans.

Luke, a John Besh original and mainstay on St. Charles Street....333 St. Charles to be exact.  I am from San Antonio and used to frequent his Luke attached to the Embassy Suites on the corner of Houston Street downtown.  In its heyday, it was THE placed to go.  Happy hour was the bomb.  Tumultuous and trendy all in one setting.  Sadly, its management changed REGULARLY and the place just went to Hades in a hand-basket - it is now closed.  Oops...too much reminiscing of  place gone away...on to Luke, New Orleans.  Happy hour is 3-6 and they have $.75 oysters on the half-shell.  Yep, you heard me right..FRESH gulf oysters on the half-shell for a mere 3/4s of a dollar each.  So, my son and I ate 36 of those bad boys on November 21st upon arrival in the city.  I wanted to compare the "glory days" of Luke San Antonio with Luke New Orleans.  The oysters were scrumptious.  Literally.  They had ample bar specials and I drank two draft lagers - bartenders call - and he hit the mark.  Complimented the oysters spot-on.  My son had a Sazerac and tried the French 75 (a drink made of brandy, French champagne w/egg whites which give it a delightful froth on the top).  Some may call it a - at the expense of being called "inappropriate" - a girl's drink, but it is good stuff people.  Leave it for the last drink and call it dessert.  AND, if you still want to call it a drink for the fairer sex, then you can again realize why women rule the world and they just LET us think that we do.  Anyway, if in New Orleans and near Bourbon Street, go to the happy hour at Luke, suck down (or chew and swallow!!!) some oysters, have a drink or two or three at their full service bar and enjoy.  You will, I guarantee you that.  Oysters away.  Oh yeah, eat a meal there and you won't be sorry either...these folks can cook...try the shrimp and grits....a mainstay and worth the money spent.  Exceedingly New Orleans appropriate.  Off to the next spot....enjoy and God bless !

Whatever they do here, I hope they keep it the way it is! This was the first meal I have ever had in NOLA.  We had an amazing customer service duo as well as delicious food.  The oysters are by far some of the best I have had and doesn't leave you with all of the salt that west coast oysters do.  Everything from the bread to the soups and the seafood dishes, were simply magnificent! The sauces and the dishes were all made so very well.  I could not believe how delicious all the dishes were.  The dessert was just okay though, but maybe it was what we ordered.  I hope to be back for sure!

From all the staff on our first and our second, we received unparalleled service. Not only did your staff find a way to seat us on an incredibly busy day but, they remembered us the next day we came in for our last meal of the trip. I would like to specifically thank Richie Rich and Chi for sending some love to thank us for visiting 2 days in a row.

This was the first time one of my best friends and I have ever taken a trip together. Ya'll made it a memorable experience for the both of us.

I will continue to visit every time I'm in NOLA.

This was definitely a moment after which I wish I had left a bigger tip lol.

This is a MINT JULEP review, we didn't have food.

We got our Mint Juleps to go. 

In short, this is most likely the strongest drink you'll have in the French quarter. Every sip, felt weirdly good in the sense that you know you'll lost fine motor skills in your body but you can't NOT finish a Mint Julep. 

Come here when you're ready to be fancy drunk, as this is a fancy place.

Pro Tip: get your Mint Julep To Go! We went there on a Saturday afternoon and the place was PACKED! No sitting or standing room, simply go to the bar, get your drinks, enjoy a clean hotel bathroom and bounce!!!

Luke was great! We got off the airplane and this was our first pit stop for dinner.

We tried:
Large Platter for Raw Bar
Jumbo Louisiana Shrimp "En Cocotte"(aka Shrimp&Grits)
Shrimp & Crab "Etouffée" (aka Seafood w/ Cavatelli)

Service was so great, Rosalynn and Elliott were very attentive and answered all our questions. Food came out quickly.

The Raw Bar Platter came with oysters, tuna tartare, crab ravigote. I loved the homemade shrimp chips and remoulade. The tuna tartare tasted a little bit like spicy mayo tuna in sushi rolls, tbh. But they were nice enough to give us some complimentary  oysters! ANY SHRIMP HERE IS DELICIOUS. Everything is so fresh. However, I felt like the portion size for the tuna and the crab were a little small.

The entrees were delicious. I am usually not a fan of tomato based sauces, but the pasta was very good. Again, the shrimp is SOOO fresh. The crab meat was in the sauce, rather than chunks on top, so I couldn't taste it as much.

I only tried a bit of grits, but it was very good. The gravy-like sauce on top was delicious though.

Would come back again for ambiance, food, and service.

We love this place. Happy hour is our favorite time to come. The oysters are a great deal and the atmosphere is awesome. The staff is always pleasant and professional. I love the Brussel sprouts and my husband loves the fried oysters.

So I have high(ish) grits standards. So many places offer grits that are too runny and/or completely lacking in flavor.

Luke, however, is not one of those places. I had the shrimp and jalapeno cheese grits for my meal. Now the shrimp were good enough, but the grits were excellent. The texture was perfect, and the flavoring was somehow even more perfect. Perhaps because of the good mood this dish put me in, I decided to indulge in a dessert. I ended up getting the bread pudding, which was an excellent choice. The various components of the dessert, such as the vanilla ice cream and the hot buttered rum sauce, all played really nicely together.

It was pretty busy here around dinner time, so keep that in mind if you plan to check it out.

Came to New Orleans to visit and eat as much sea food as possible, so I went to Luke...randomly picked the place..didn't know what to eat but stuffed oysters sounded good so here I was 1/2 dozen stuffed oysters..shortly after I figured how to eat them (with the spoon to get all of it, as the manager said) there were none left!!! So good

Excellent shrimp and grits but portion sizes are way too small for the price. I give 5 stars for Kevin's customer service because they were closing the kitchen and we had a few friends who were running behind that joined us right as they we closing the kitchen, they allowed us to still put the order in so they wouldn't be hungry for the night.

Fantastic, I repeat fantastic place to go for breakfast or brunch. We were steered here by 2 different locals, a bar tender and a fellow working in a hot sauce shop. The grits, andouille sausage, bacon were all perfect. The grits in particular.....we came back a few days later and had their breakfast burrata. It was spectacular. Deconstructed to its individual parts then allowing you to put each bite together however you like. So unbelievably good.......we will definitely be back next time in town!!

Luke was very delicious. I do not remember the "official" menu names but I had the grilled ham and cheese with an egg on top and the fried brussel sprouts. Soooooooooooo yummy! The atmosphere was great and Nicole was super helpful and attentive. She was also very pleasant to talk to. If not for the food, have yourself a drink and visit Nicole.

This is the place to come for oysters!!! 95% of the tables dining here had massive displays of oysters!!! I believe that the tables that did not hadn't yet place their order!

Let me start by saying they have a phenomenal happy hour and what I mean by phenomenal is every glass of wine doesn't matter the price point from high to low is half off for happy hour in addition to $.75 oysters! You cannot beat that for an upscale restaurant! I had a fairly pricey glass(well two) of Pinot Grigio that was the cost of the house white glass and was thrilled lol 

Oyster - 4 STARS 
I got four of the $.75 happy hour oysters and two of the smaller size oysters from Alabama unfortunately I forgot their name but I recall the price point at $2. each! The happy hour oyster were large and a mix between salty and sweet, they were pretty good but I preferred the Alabama small and sweet oysters that day they paired perfectly with my wine!

Bowl of gumbo - 5 STARS
Divine! For my three day business trip I had gumbo everyday if not twice! I'm so serious! Why?! Umm, there's so many ways to try it! It was amazing here and highly recommend it!

Tuna tartare - 1 STAR
Blah... the cubes of fish were hardened together by what I'm assuming as sitting in the chiller pre-molded, not saying the fish wasn't Fresh it just wasn't freshly prepared and you can tell by how the pieces hard stuck together(I do sashimi weekly) and they weren't easy to break up with a little chips that they provided! My friend doesn't like spicy and they came in a spicy sauce however didn't state anything about it being spicy of the menu. They should consider adding that.
 
Burrata mozzarella salad - 5 STARS
Only tried a lil bite, was saddened my colleague didn't wish to share. Lol 

Oyster salad - 5 STARS
Doing a little dance right now as I reminisce on how delicious this salad was! Just something about it the thick cubes of bacon and the fried oysters mixed with fresh greens that really set my soul on fire! I've never had bacon served this way but let me tell you I am forever a fan! Gotta check out my photo! Top 10 salads I've ever had! Get ready to droll! 

Luke's I'm a big fan of your food and service! I'll for sure be back when in town!

The service and hospitality at Luke is amazing! Our server Kenny was friendly and knowledgeable about the food and drinks. He went above and beyond to make our experience at Luke a pleasant dinner. I had the shrimp and crab étouffée it was delicious. We went back for happy hour the next day and the service was the same. Service, food and drinks are consistent all around! If you visit New Orleans stop at Luke and if you live in NOLA make sure to stop at Luke.

I completely spaced taking photos. This place was unique and delicious...lots of great choices and was very torn. I ended up getting the burger because its been feature in Travel and Leisure magazine. It was so so good. The bread was soft and light...was told its baked fresh daily. The caramelized onions and then the fresh tomatoes and lettuce made the burger. It had thick sliced bacon too. Yummy!!! I got the Luke said and it had delicious beets both red and yellow. The dressing made this salad. Also, had the shrimp etouffee, which is served over pasta made the dish unique; was delicious. 

I was so full, so I skipped the bread pudding which pains me. I regret not trying it because I bet it is spectacular. This is a must visit if you are in town.

This place is simply amazing. The first night in NOLA my group and I went to Luke's for dinner. Our server Kenny made us feel welcomed. Kenny is one of the best servers I've had in a while. He made our experience unforgettable. The food and drinks were also amazing. If you are in NOLA you need to visit this place!

are you kidding me luke's knocks it out of the park best food ever drop ! this is where yelp makes me type more words in order to post a review so how about this ......... greatnesssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssssss !

We came for brunch. We ordered the duck and rabbit pate, brussel sprouts, gulf shrimp and grits, and burger. I really enjoyed the duck and rabbit pate- the flavor combo was yummy. The gulf shrimp and grits was my favorite out of all that I've tried in NOLA- I could eat it every day. I didn't care for the brussel sprouts- it was overly done with too much sauce. That being said, I love brussel sprouts done clean with a little salt and pepper and roasted with a little char so you can taste the flavors. Otherwise everything was tasty.

Modern twist on the NOLA cuisine. The chicken and reboot liver pate was really good. The sides and sauces that come with it add to the flavors. The Brussels were okay and drenched in sauce that masked the nicely cooked sprouts. The shrimps and grits were amazing! Huge gulf shrimp and creamy grits with flavors that kept going! Recommended to someone who wants a flair on the common Nola menu.
With a great happy hour, a delicious burger, a blt with a literal fried crab on it, and killer margaritas, I would say this is one of my favorite restaurants in New Orleans!

We always stay at the Hilton St Charles, so Luke is a must.  We actually love the bar here and it is tough to get a seat, but so worth it.  We had breakfast here before the football game, and wow!!! The grits were off the chart delicious.  Cheesey jalapeño grits cooked to absolute perfection. The bacon and sausage were pretty darn good too!

We stopped by this little historic setting restaurant for a late night snack after checking in at our hotel. The ambience, atmosphere and the crowd just showered us with what we came to this creole city for. From the wood carving details at the bar where we sat because tables were not available on Sunday night without a reservation to the pulley driven row of fans with decorative ceiling as a backdrop, the gem of a find set us on the right mood for the Big Easy good times. We split the order of delicious shrimps with grits and sumptuous ginger bread á la mode on hot skillet dessert which were catered by the attentive servers at the bar while watching the oyster shucking show on the side. It's Mardi Gras time in our tummies!
Shey and Des were great bartenders. Cocktails were fantastic on happy hour and oysters for 75 cents. Lots of stuff close by. Best place to chill !

I can't really recommend that you come here anymore.  I've eaten here 20 or more times over the past dozen years and they have no idea where they're going right now.  They're suffering from an identity crisis and now it's just corporate tourist food.  I would just move on.  I would give them 1 star after last nights meal if it were for all the good memories I've had.  The past few years have been hit and miss but last night I just wanted my money back.

We showed up for an overpriced and terribly executed Reveillon dinner.  The shrimp remoulade salad was way too spicy (not that it should even be a little spicy).  The weird turtle soup was vastly over seasoned.  The hangar steak was blue, raw.  I did love the demi-glace and the stuffing, although dry, was delicious.  The finish was an eggnog pot-de-creme that had gelatin!  OMG.  Really, you don't know how to make a creme?  The texture was like jello.  Awful.  It was a little too sweet with the figs and crumble too, by the way,

The service wasn't brilliant.  In fact was the worst I've had here.  The bread service is embarrassing.  It's Sysco par-baked garbage.  Inedible and beneath them.  It kinda shows how little they understand their own restaurant concept.  They've ruined the menu.  It's confused and without direction.  You can't even get the classic cocktails you used to get on the happy hour menu.  You can't have a Sazarac?  Really?  It's just Sazarac Rye!  I used to order one here.  It's New Orleans.  

I'm starting to really have my doubts about this restaurant group.

Even better than the last time I was there! Our server, Richie Rich (really!!), was funny and personable, and didn't even blink when I ordered eggnog and oysters. Yes, it's a disgusting combination, I know. Mostly the eggnog came before the oysters. But I digress...

The house made eggnog was simply delicious. As I write this, I want to go back and have another. But I like eggnog.

My friend and I split a dozen local oysters, which were amazing. They were sweet and briny and super fresh. So good. I think I ate most of them. 

We then had a few other dishes. The crab and corn bisque is very rich and creamy, but with a nicely balanced flavor and enough crab to make you know you're eating it.

The burrata is a giant sized salad wig a great big hunk of creamy cheese, and was fabulous as well. Not to be outdone, the ricotta gnocchi were pillowy little morsels of deliciousness.

Can I go back yet?

I recently went on a trip with my girlfriends to New Orleans for my birthday and let me tell you this restaurant did not disappoint. The chicken and potatoes was so good, but not only that but the service was amazing to say the least. They were very generous and kind people. They gave us champagne and desserts on the house because it was my birthday. I don't think I lifted a finger because their staff was always on top of everything. If I'm ever in New Orleans again I'm coming here without a doubt.

Worst experience I've had in a restaurant in my entire life. Staff were rude from the moment we walked in the door. Obviously has just become a tourist trap where they no longer care about delivering customer service. Wine list is horrible. Enjoyed the pate appetizer but that was about it

This restaurant was a last minute decision- we wanted delicious food and a good happy hour but we needed a break from heavy Cajun style food. It's a beautiful restaurant, classy designs, lots of natural wood, it's lovely! Our server was extremely kind and helpful, we always love a waiter willing to chat and joke around a little. We initially went for happy hour, got some delicious oysters (the happy hour deal is amazing- 75cents for a raw oyster!!!). We were so impressed that we decided to get 12 more oysters and share the Flammekuchen for dinner. The oysters were all around impressive and I highly recommend this place for happy hour and snacks! The flammekuchen was slightly disappointing for us. It's originally a thin crust pizza from the Alsace region of France and that's where we first were introduced to it. We expected it to have lots of cheese and appropriate toppings. It came out mostly onion and bacon, with a very small portion of cheese sprinkled on top. The flavors were good but it was TOO much onion. We were pretty sad about it, and it definitely lost the restaurant a star. However, if you love caramelized onions and bacon, you will likely love this!

Overall this space is cute, convenient, and they have great happy hour deals! I hope that if we don't make it back by this trip, we will on a future trip because the entire menu was mouth-watering. Plus, it's hard to beat 75 cent oysters!

This place was amazing! We had it on Thursday night and we were seated rather quickly which was great! We took a recommendation from here about the shrimp and grits and it was THE BEST! My husband and I both had it and we loved every bite! Price is pretty high for the amount of food you get but MAN it was worth it! I also recommend their delicious bread pudding! Perfect dinner for our first night in new
Amazing! Late night arrival in NOLA so got amazing service from Gary! Food was amazing. Highly recommend the seafood platter! Highest quality and freshness...
One of the best dinners I've ever had! We ate the Shrimp and Grits and Luke Cheeseburger.

Yum!!! Our servers were Gary and Kevin. They did a great job taking care of us. They patiently answered all our questions and were super attentive to our needs. The gnocchi ricotta is really good! The vegetarian pasta (off menu) was really good. It's seasonal vegetables so that can vary, but it was full of flavor and the sauce was freshly made. My significant other ordered the burger. The burger was really heavy, but tasted good. The fries were crispy on the outside and soft on the inside. Next time we would plan better so we have room for dessert!

Poor breakfast spot. We asked for an americano and latte and they brought drip coffee and drip coffee with milk. I'd prefer some honesty that they don't have an espresso machine. Also no fresh orange juice.

Service was exceptional and food was amazing. Nice cocktails, wine and beer for happy hour half off. Oysters .75 cents and seriously great quality. I think happy hour ended at 7. One of my favorite dining experiences of the many times I've been to New Orleans

Amazing ribeye here; the star of the show.

Crab & corn chowder: 5 stars all the way. So light, not too cheesy or heavy. Good amount of crab meat.

Crab and shrimp etouffee: 4 stars. Sauce was decent. Instead of rice, pasta was the base starch. It was a thick rolled pasta so the interior was sauce-free and with every bite, a plain pasta noodle would be tasted. I think I would have preferred a open macaroni or rice (so the sauce could coat more surfaces).

Spiced apple glacee with rum ice cream: I loved the ice cream a lot. The spiced apple was really wonderful. The pastry holding the filling was good, but I suppose I wanted a wetter dessert so I didn't enjoy it as much as I wanted to. 4 stars.

I tried the bread pudding and it was nice. I only got a small spoonful but I'll give it 5 stars.

I tried many bites of my friend's ribeye: I want to give it 6 stars out of 5! It's the reason that even though I have hangups about the etouffee and my apple dessert, I have to give Luke 5 stars. The steak was perfefctly cooked, wonderful buttery texture. But the flavor, the flavor was out of this world. It was like the steak was infused with a nice beef broth (think a fine pho soup). I didn't know beef could have such strong beefy flavor - I've never experienced that before. I would come here to eat that ribeye every day if I could.

Great french fries.

The only BAD: During the meal, there was a incredibly loud drunk man who came in and started conversing with a drunk spanish speaking family(?)/friends. The 'family' group sat at the table next to ours (each person had their own Bourbon St. fishbowl) and proceeded to yell loudly over other diners to their guy at the bar. That I didn't mind as much as other diners. HOWEVER, the man's laugh was shockingly disruptive to all conversation at our table. So loud and piercing. I've *never* before had my thoughts interrupted by the laugh of someone across the room in a crowded restaurant. He laughed at a rate about once a minute. The staff did tell the family they couldn't yell to their friend anymore after 10 minutes or so. They did nothing about the laughing man, much to my dismay. The flavor of the steak was actually good enough for me not to knock my rating of Luke down because of the atmosphere I experienced. But there is still a part of me disappointed in the restaurant as a whole due to that man.

Please order their raw oyster during happy hour, it's fresh, big and yumm.

drinks are soso though.

We ordered the Shrimp n grits and side of gumbo.  Very rich in flavor but very good.  It's a shock to the taste buds.  Recommended that you call for a reservation, the place gets crowded early.  Nice ambiance, friendly staff and good food.

Went there for lunch about 6 months ago.
Delicious. 
Was in New Orleans again recently, I was upset that we did not have time to return again. 
Very memorable meal. I would recommend if you are not afraid of trying new things.

This is the only time I've ever walked out of a meal.
The service was insulting. The food was inedible.

We arrived on time for our dinner reservation. We were hungry and excited by the really great reviews we had seen on yelp.

The hostess (we later found out manager) was cold and inattentive in welcoming us, but it sounded like she was dealing with another unhappy table, so we didn't take it personally at first. We were told to wait while our table was prepared. She ignored us for a while but did greet other guests warmly. Finally another hostess asked what was going on with our table and was told that we were standing right there waiting.

We were seated brusquely, and did not receive bread which all the other tables had. At this point we were starting to feel a bit neglected. 
We ordered the Reveillon dinner. 5 minutes after taking our order, the waiter came back to asked us how we wanted the steak done.

At this point we figured that service was going to be bad and settled for hoping that the food would make up for it. For us, good food makes up for bad service.

The first course was a shrimp remoulade. The shrimp was fine, slightly overcooked. The main problem was that the dressing was overly spicy and incredibly sour. The dish was drenched in it. We literally couldn't eat any of the stuff at the bottom of the plate because the dressing was so strong. This was the first of a 4-course $60 meal. Presentation was a mess, like someone slapped it down with no care. And it looked like the garnish was canned mandarine orange pieces (soft and syrupy sweet). Neither of us finished the dish.

The waiter eventually came by and took away the half-eaten dish, but didn't ask if it was okay or if anything was wrong. At this point we really just didn't think that they gave a damn how we were doing.

Second course was turtle soup. It was completely overseasoned. The whole thing tasted like they dumped a bottle of italian seasoning in. We tried 2 spoonfuls and literally couldn't bring ourselves to continue eating it.

At this point I talked to the waiter, offered to pay for the meal so far, but made it clear that we did not want the rest of the meal. To their credit, the manager didn't charge us for it and apologized.

Maybe they don't know how to prepare their Reveillon menu properly? Maybe the staff was flustered with dealing with the other unhappy table?

It was a very disappointing experience for us since Luke had such a good reputation. We came back on yelp and saw that other people had recently had similarly bad experiences. I really don't know what's going on, maybe they had a change of management. I really just want to warn other people. I wouldn't want them to experience the kind of disappointment that we went through.

Visited twice now in last few months, last time for Thanksgiving Day lunch. They had Turducken and five kinds of stuffing. I chose oyster.

Son ordered the steak and wife had fish. Food was grand, ambience perfect and after meal cappuccino spot on. 

Fresh oysters at the bar. Bistro style casualness with an energetic vibe. 

Too full for dessert but will try next trip in.

Recommend and will return.

We had a great brunch at Luke's. My wife ordered a Bloody Mary that was perfect. It was spicy but not overwhelming. We ordered the Brussel Sprouts and they are to die for. The omelette was very good. And as you would expect the waiter was professional.

One of the best restaurants in town - Luke is a can't miss.  The shrimp and grits are the best I have ever had. The stuffed oysters and bread pudding are perfection. I have had breakfast lunch and dinner here and I haven't had a bad meal yet. They get it right at Luke.

The staff deserve a five star because they were still open on Christmas Eve. We walked in 20 minutes before closing and were welcomed in instead of turned away and they were still nice and polite, never rushed us the whole time. The food is great, char-grilled oysters were delicious and gumbo was tasty.

I picked Luke solely because it was one of the few restaurants open on Christmas for dinner. It is a hotel restaurant with a generic NOLA menu, raw seafood to steak. The cuisine tilts toward French what with rabbit pate, crab en ravigote, etc. Some dishes are served en cocotte, small cast iron deep pans, and the portions are fairly large, perfect to split. After ordering the mixed seafood platter and waiting a while we received without explanation a slightly altered variation. When we inquired we were told the kitchen had run out of one of the items, so they had upped the oysters. Had to send it back, because one of us can't eat oysters and miffed that the plate was plopped on the table without any explanation. One of the two servers who took care of our table was an absolutely clueless airhead. Luckily, we had the better one wait on us the rest of the meal.
As a second alternative,  we had the boiled gulf shrimp, not deveined and unpeeled. Somewhat messy to eat and the veins soiled the whole experience by making the texture somewhat gritty. The server brought us soaking wet napkins to wipe our hands. LOL. 
We split the grilled drum and ended with a simple salad, both fairly good. 
The kitchen is not where the restaurant is and I think the temperature of the dishes suffer for the distance, the room temp.  fish and accompanying veggies, as well as the butter emulsion, almost solidified. 
The space is large with a handsome main dining room, a pressed tin ceiling and a dark wood bar, newspapers hanging on dowels. I'd avoid the rear room/the Siberia.

My wife and I spent our honeymoon in New Orleans over Christmas and ate Christmas dinner at Luke. 

It was by far our best meal in New Orleans. The staff was incredibly friendly and generous, and the food was unbelievable. I kept thinking I was too full to go on, but each bite was better than the next - from the oysters and shrimp through the brussel sprouts (a must) through the bread pudding. Eat here!

We were so excited to eat here that we made a reservation over a month in advance for Christmas day so that we could take part in the special Revillion menu. What a dissappoint. The food was bland/ under seasoned and cold. Over $300 for cold food? You must be joking. We sent it back and when it returned it was better, but still not hot. Hey "chef" maybe if you weren't reheating day old prep... Just a thought from someone with a clue. Wine parings showed up after the food and were dropped at the table by dissappearing waiters with no explanation of varietal, region or vintage (yeah we asked to back track and find out what we were drinking, but should we have to?) We told the manager how terribly dissappointed we were with our entire experience, and oh hey SURPRISE she didn't care. Do not eat here. Seriously, anywhere else is better then this garbage on a plate.

Happy hour! They have .75 cent oysters with half off drinks from 3-6pm. It is next to the Hilton hotel and the place was barely full. They have some of the best P&J oysters I have ever had. The are usually priced at $2-4 and I don't think there is a better deal in the area.

Nothing posted on yelp is around. They change their menu very often apparently and that was a disappointment.

We ordered 2 dozen oysters and asked if we can try al 4 types, which are exactly the same price. He said no and wanted to charge us 4 halves.

I would have rated 3 stars but with the options around, it's not worth wasting the money here or time or stomach space.

Four of us went there for their Happy Hour, and what a happy hour we had!!! Make sure you request to be served by a gentleman, Rich, he goes by Richie Rich. Hands down the best waiter in the world! 

The oysters, cocktails, soups, Brussel sprouts and brownie desert are world class! Great value for money and great way to kick off your evening!
75 cents per oyster in the happy hour time!!! We come for lunch and cannot help to order one dozen and another dozen after that!!! Highly recommend this place. Everything is delicious.

We did not have reservation but they accommodated and sat us in the back room near the kitchen, which is actually cool because you get to watch all the chefs in action through the glass. 
The place is modern new American, Southern cooking.  It's upscale but casual friendly.  They have a daily lunch that is reasonable.  The food was so deliciously rich, especially the shrimp grit, I could eat this everyday, but definitely would come back when I'm in the area.

Let me preface by saying that I hate "Southern food." All of it. Oysters, shrimps, grits, fried crap... I hate every bit of it. 
Was stuck in NOLA for a few months this year and had to endure. 
Came to Luke twice for breakfast with some friends. 
They LOVED it. LOVED it. Still talk about it... 
I had the Luke breakfast (had none of the Southern items I so hate) and it was EXCELLENT. Bacon, andouille sausage, massive biscuits, fresh 'taters ... top shelf food. Coffee was a French press w/ fresh cream. 
YES please. 
Had a Luke burger too. Solid burger for a joint that specializes in oysters and shrimps. 
Highly recommended.

Tried out this place for lunch with my SO. We ordered the tried eggplant, a bowl of their gumbo, and the jumbo Louisiana shrimp "en cocotte."

The waiter brought us bread and butter. Normal baguette and nothing special.

The fried eggplant is served with a marinara sauce. I would have personally wanted more cheese in the eggplant and a thicker sauce, but this was not too bad. The presentation of the dish is also exquisite. The eggplant was served in a small fryer basket on top of a thick cutting board. The sauce was served in a creme brulee sort of cup and also on the same board. I probably won't order the fried eggplant again since I didn't love it, but my SO loved it a lot.

The gumbo has fantastic flavor. The portion is quite small, but the flavors make up for it. It's served with a bit of white rice.

The shrimp and grits is fantastic. Jumbo shrimp was slightly overcooked, but shrimp tastes good regardless. The grits were cooked perfectly with a sauce and served with sausage. This is a delicious Southern staple.

The portions are okay and prices are not too bad for food in Louisiana.
Amazing food. Great service, the shrimp are amazing and fresh. The Gulf Fish are the best though. If you are around Canal Street the restaurant is one you cannot miss.

I had the shrimp and grits and they were just okay. We went at prime brunch time on a Friday and the place was pretty empty which should have tipped us off. The service was good but I wouldn't make it a point to come back here.

Was happy to hear that New Orleans has a number of restaurants open during the Christmas holiday. My fiancé and I came here for Christmas dinner and really enjoyed ourselves. We ordered 1 appetizer, 2 entrees and 1 cocktail. 
Appetizer was Gnocchi which though decent, the sauce it was dressed in tasted like pizza rolls from my childhood. Definitely pass on those next time. 
I ordered shrimp and grits - very flavorful and well seasoned. My fiancé ordered the rib eye which came with fries. We were happy when the food came out because the portions were appropriate. Cocktail was great and definitely strong so worth the cost. 
Overall really nice time and good ambiance.

Let me start by saying the food was "Amaaazing" we had the Duck Duck Rice, and the shrimp and Grits, corn and crab soup, shrimp and crab stuffed oysters, French 75 cocktail, apple fall dumpling, and a chocolate tort.

Luke has a great atmosphere the ambiance was very nice. Our server Gary was on point, and was excellent with all of his recommendations and conversation and the same goes for the manager.

 I believe her Name was Elizabeth though we had dinner there on 12/29/17, so it's been a few days....so sorry if I didn't get her name right. Gary and Elizabeth made the experience very enjoyable for us and our little service dog. We will definitely go back, everything on the menu looked appetizing.
Best burger ever! The sauce makes it perfect! The French 75 cocktail is a must have ! ( cognac and apple cider)

Tasty food for decent value.

We arrived a bit early with a reservation, but it took the staff at least 10 minutes to figure out a place to seat us early despite there being plenty of available seats; overall, the service was much less helpful than other places we ate at during our stay in New Orleans. However, the food was quite good--we split the seafood platter to start, which included very tasty oysters and other fresh seafood jars, while we split the ricotta gnocchi with butternut squash as an appetizer, which had very nice flavor from the squash and the change in texture from the chickory crumble. My slow braised lamb and chestnut pasta entree was also tasty, while the duck duck rice my friend had quite a bit of an Asian tilt to it and was just okay. The food was overall tasty and is a good place to grab a meal.

We were able to get a reservation so we are lucky to avoid the lines. We ordered stuffed oyster, crab bisque, fried chicken&waffle, and brussels sprouts. All the dishes are great, and the sprouts is the best we ever have, I would say all these dishes are must try.

Came here on a whim for a late lunch/ early dinner. They have happy hour on Sunday- discount oysters and half price cocktails. We split the corn and crab chowder and gumbo. Both were delicious! I preferred the chowder. We also split the shrimp en cocotte. That was so good. Huge shrimp and sausage on a bed of jalapeño grits. Yum! We also had an order of fries. Service was good. Definitely a favorite meal while visiting NOLA.

We reserved a table for New Year's Eve.  Had a lovely time, the bar is beautiful inside is nicely done, though crowded.  Had the champagne cognac with lemon juice --can you say YUM. The roasted Brussels sprouts were out of this world. Had the fish and husband had the   ÉTOUFFÉE. We both cleared our plates and I saved room for dessert. We would definitely go back just for the cocktails and Brussels sprouts . The table next to us had a burger and fries and that is my next order. Love me a good burger

What can I say?  Happy hour at Luke's is THE BEST!!!! Oysters at $0.75 each and 50% off selected wines and beers.  The oysters came out ice cold, plump, and sweet.  
We were in NOLA for 4 days and my wife booked Luke's for happy hour starting at 3pm to 6pm.  It's best to make reservations as this place will quickly fill and the only other option is the few seats along the bar.
We started with a half dozen raw and half dozen fried.  The raw oysters fall outweighed the sweetness and taste over the fried ones.  We then proceeded to go through another dozen, then another dozen.  
Service was attentive and Kevin came around continuously to make sure we were okay and had enough drinks and food.
Although the check arrived with the first dozen (6 raw/6 fried) at the non-happy hour price, I brought this to Kevin's attention and he quickly took care of honoring the happy hour prices.
All in all, this was the best place for getting your fix of oysters at rock bottom prices.
The bar itself is very modern and upscale, although it didn't feel stuffy or uncomfortable for someone in jeans.
I highly recommend you checking out this place.

Came here for New Year's Day brunch. Arrived 5 minutes before our 1215 reservation and were seated promptly. It is in an historic building that is currently a Hilton hotel. The decor is period and is beautifully preserved early 20th century. The waitstaff has very smart white jackets and ties. We started with a tasty Bloody Mary and a drink called w2 which is a combo of whiskey, wine and a syrup. I didn't try it but the husband said it was good. 
   We ordered a cup of crab and corn bisque and one of roasted chicken matzo ball soup. The soups were piping hot and both were excellent. They were both packed with their respective meats. The crab was fresh and sweet. We weren't terribly hungry so we decided to split the red beans and rice which the kitchen was kind enough to do for us. It came with a crispy chicken breast drizzled with tobasco honey. The chicken and the red beans and rice were both very good, with the rice being fragrant- possibly jasmine. Some of the best I have had. 
   Our daughter chose the shrimp and crab crepes though I'm not sure what the sauce was- she pronounced it excellent. It was a lovely meal and the service was exemplary. There is also a great deal of raw oyster selections of one chooses. This is a great place for a special brunch or dinner.
The PJ oysters are very fresh and tasty. We also ordered a shrimp entree which is good but not excellent. Recommend the raw bar.

Wow, I loved this place. The comfort of the place and the comfort of the food. So, so good.

Happy hour is your friend. Get 75 cent raw P&J oysters, not just half off drinks.

Creole gumbo is a must. So is the gnocchi. Rabbit pate could've been better, but maybe it's a required taste. 

A lot of help from different servers. So you always seem to have somebody and that's good. 

Would go again, just for the oysters and brews.
Very delicious! The seafood gumbo was amazing as well as the crab meat oysters. Waiter staff was fun.
Great margaritas, amazing BLT which has a fried crab right on it, awesome oyster happy hour, great burger & fries!

We're from New York. Not to sound like snobs but we know great food. This restaurant is on point! From the warm bread and sweet butter upon being seated at your table to the friendly staff, Luke has an awesome thing going here. We had the shared plate of brussel sprouts that is to die for! The sauce is sweet and spicy along with the sliced apples to cut the heat. This shared plate is like a meal! It is truly for 2. We also had the croque monsieur with a fried egg on top. The bread was fluffy in the middle and crispy on the outside. The fries were definitely hand cut and super crispy. We also had the jumbo Louisiana shrimp en cocotte with  grits which was to die for! It's super rich but totally worth the food coma after. Word to the wise don't order both the soft boiled eggs and crawfish on top of the cocotte unless 3 of you are sharing it haha. 
We were so happy we chose this restaurant for our first New Orleans experience.
We went here for lunch ahhhh the food was incredible it was freezing cold and I got the motzo ball soup and salad it was fantastic! Service was on point too I would highly recommend this place.

Probably best meal we had in NOLA which says a lot as we had many great meals.  Brussel sprouts gave me new found respect for fine cooking with hot sauce. Burger was perfect.  Friends' steak and shrimp and grits hit the mark.  Bread pudding was piece de la resistance!   Secretly wanted to go back every night!

The place was amazing! We actually went on NYE without a reservation and they accommodated us. The food was fantastic...right from the drinks, through appetizers and dessert. Our server was great as well.

The place looks very fancy and well-kept. I was actually quite intimidated by the place and was afraid it would be beyond my budget.
We came here just in time for happy hour on a Thursday. There was no wait but you could tell that people were starting to trickle in.
We were immediately seated.

We ordered a bowl of Gumbo, some fried oysters, and some fresh oysters.
Everything we had was great and came at a reasonable time. 

For happy hour you get 75c oysters which is pretty good.
We also had a couple of cocktails (half off during happy hour) to start off the vacation.
The service was on point and our needs were addressed immediately.

Overall it was a good experience, I would say well worth the money you pay.
I would come back if I was in the area again.

One of my favorite restaurants in New Orleans is this little gem by one of New Orleans own Chef Luke. This upscale restaurant is nice enough to be classified as fine dining without being stuffy. When you walk in you're greeted by a long lit bar with feeding on the side for drinks and appetizers. In the back area the room opens up with seating all around the open Kitchen in the center. The place itself is gorgeous. 

The menu has so many different options from Chef Luke that it was truly hard to pick. The wait staff was extremely helpful and attentive. They started off good old classic Sazerac. The drinks are Madewell here, strong drinks at a decent price point, comparable to New York or any City restaurant. Also started with the oyster platter, one of their specialties, and they were served on ice. Delicious and fresh who's excited for our main course. I ordered the steak with fries and my husband got the Luke Burger. Wanting to try everything we split our dishes and we're happy with both. The steak was tender and well seasoned and the fries came out in a little cone and were crisped to perfection with just the right amount of salt. The Luke Burger, also tender and juicy, was amazing. We thoroughly enjoyed everything here. I would come back in an instant if I could.

This place is a treat. I found this place on yelp during my trip to the beloved Nola. It was a last stop on Christmas Eve. It was very elegant and exquisite. The wine was good in quality and flavor. The food was very fresh and delectable. I tried the pate and it was a culinary experience. That ended up being my main meal since my sweetheart did not want any. I also tried the bread pudding which was amazing. The ice cream was made fresh. The drizzling and pecans  where the best part. I can't wait to go back and try more offerings.
Continues to be my favorite. Recently went to get the seafood tower which was ah-mazing. A lovely dinner splurge. Ask for Rich! He's the best. The epitome of southern service.

Saw this place had great reviews and a happy hour oyster deal so we decided to come. Disclaimer - I'm only really reviewing this place based on their happy hour oysters, which is a shame because everyone else dining in who wasn't just doing the oysters was eating such yummy looking meals! Anyways, we got seated rather quickly, pretty much immediately, which was surprising given how full the place seemed. The interior was really nice inside, and I felt like we were dining somewhere a bit classier, but still with a chill relaxed atmosphere, if that even makes any sense.

Somehow I couldn't find info on their happy hour on yelp or their website, so if I remember correctly it runs from 3pm - 6pm, although I'm not sure what on which days specifically. You can get their P & J oysters for $.75 each, which is a lot better than their usual non-happy hour price of $2 each. And I think their fried oysters are $1.25 each during happy hour.

P & J gulf oysters - these were great! Very meaty, juicy, and fresh, and I especially loved the horseradish that came along with it. Somehow I don't think I've ever had horseradish with oysters before, and now it seems like such a natural sauce to add along with the customary splash of lemon. My only critique is the lack of selection of oyster type. I felt extremely limited because there was really only one type of oyster (unless you count the fried oyster) I could order during their happy hour (I think they had other oysters, but no happy hour deals on them), and indeed I only consumed the P & Js while here.

Roasted jalapeño grits - had to try some grits too. They were great! The layer of gooey cheese atop the dish was pretty mild in flavor, but awesome, as it provided that comforting melted cheese texture. The jalapeños, however, didn't add too much flavor to the dish in my opinion, and I would have liked it if there was a bit more of a kick to the dish.

Overall, a really nice restaurant! I feel bad giving this place a 4 because I'm almost sure I would have given this place a 5 had I come here and got other dishes besides happy hour oysters. Everyone else's food looked and smelled so delicious! But no, I was here on a mission and one mission only - happy hour oysters. And it was a pretty good deal, but just not enough variety. And for that I give this place a 4. Nonetheless, I think this place is still great, just don't come here for happy hour oysters if you seek variety in your oysters.

Best restaurant we dined at in NOLA. Top quality service, food, drinks-to-food pairing.  
We got lucky and hit Luke's happy hour, giving us half-price oysters and drinks ordered before 6pm.  My wife loved the pairing with her "French 75" drink. 
Fried oysters were perfectly enhanced by its accompanying creamy sauce, and the raw PJ oysters delightfully melted in our mouths.
My wife had the puppy drum fish over roasted root vegetables -- not typical NOLA fare but she her favorite dish during our whole trip.  She could not stop raving how great it was.  Especially paired with her chardonnay.
I had the shrimp & grits at my daughter's urging (she highly recommended Luke to us) and it was delicious, except one shrimp that was bad.  It was perfectly paired with a sauvignon blanc.
Wonderful experience.

Best happy hour I have ever been to, hands down. The deals here are amazing - 75¢ raw oysters. $1.25 fried oysters, and half off basically all cocktails, beers, and wines. We ended up getting 36 raw oysters because they were so smooth and fresh, 6 fried oysters, and some drinks. The fried oysters are a must get item - the crispy and crunchy breading contrasts perfectly with the juiciness of the oyster on the inside. The ones we got were also huge so 6 of them ended up being very satisfying for 2 people. The cocktails were great as well, we tried the jalepaloma and the gintilly lace. Strong and flavorful, especially worth at half the price. Will definitely visit again when I am back in NOLA!

It is really unfortunate to leave this review as it is not indicative to the food at Luke. I was in town on vacation a couple of weeks back and stopped in for a bite. The burger was great and the service was fantastic! 

However, during my visit I accidentally left a really nice pair of sunglasses. The next day I went in to see if they were there - the great waitress that served me previously said she stashed them in case I came back. Which was really awesome - it goes to show there are great people everywhere in this world.

Unfortunately, this is where the reason for the poor review comes in. In between the time I had left and she had stashed the glasses for my return - someone who worked at the restaurant stole them. It sucks to know I won't be coming back because this place is great in terms of food and service. I can't support a place where workers will steal their customers stuff.

- disclaimer: I never leave reviews for places (good or bad) but this incident compelled me to

My fiance and I were visiting New Orleans and stumbled across the Luke restaurant. I must say, this dining experience was phenomenal. The appetizer we shared was the flammenkuchen. The onions were caramelized to that sweet goodness, bacon smoked to perfection and the cheese was delicious. For an entree I HIGHLY recommend the shrimp and grits. It's a cuisine unique to New Orleans and it was exceptional. I was told by a few people this place has the absolute best shrimp and grits in the city and it lived up to that expectation.
